course_title: Alberti Bass Like a Guitar Pro – Part 1
course_content:
Highlights

  • A stronger, faster, and more precise thumb.
  • Getting familiar with Alberti Bass acompaniment.
  • Developing voice treatment capacity, both in phrasing and dynamic range.

Description

In the part 1 of this course you will be practicing one of the most used techniques during the classical era for classical guitar - the Alberti style bass and accompaniment. You will begin with easier pieces, but difficulty will rise with every step! This course consists of an etude selection from Le Papillon, Op. 50 by Mauro Giuliani. There is a continuous rise in the difficulty level throughout the method, so it is recommended that you feel comfortable playing the etudes from the first steps before engaging on a harder piece of a later step. You can listen to the whole set of pieces and understand that they do share similar classical vocabulary, therefore knowing one piece WILL make it easier to learn the next one.

Requirement

  • Beginner-Intermediate level in right hand arpeggio playing.
  • Novice level of chords and melody playing on first position.

What's next

Next course: Alberti Bass Like a Guitar Pro - Part 2

lessons.lesson_title: Introduction to ‘Alberti Bass Like a Guitar Pro 1’
lessons.lesson_content:
In the part 1 of this course you will be practicing one of the most used techniques during the classical era for classical guitar - the Alberti style bass and accompaniment. You will begin with easier pieces, but difficulty will rise with every step!

This method consists of an etude selection from Le Papillon, Op. 50 by Mauro Giuliani.

There is a continuous rise in the difficulty level throughout the method, so it is recommended that you feel comfortable playing the etudes from the first steps before engaging on a harder piece of a later step. You can listen to the whole set of pieces and understand that they do share similar classical vocabulary, therefore knowing one piece WILL make it easier to learn the next one.

lessons.lesson_title: Le Papillon, Op. 50 – No. 14, Andantino
lessons.lesson_content:
by Mauro Giuliani

In this second etude you will find a variation of the Alberti bass, which is also a very common practice in this era. “P-m, i” right hand arpeggios are one of the most used techniques to play melody and accompaniment very harmoniously. Make sure the bass line does not sound louder that the main melody.

lessons.lesson_title: Le Papillon, Op. 50 – No. 16, Vivace
lessons.lesson_content:
by Mauro Giuliani

Here you see combined the model of Alberti bass accompaniment on the first etude, with the arpeggiated texture of the “p-m, i” of the second etude. This movement is to be played at a faster tempo than the previous pieces, which will demand more from your fingers’ agility and independence.

2 pages

lessons.lesson_title: Le Papillon, Op. 50 – No. 19, Tempo di polacca
lessons.lesson_content:
by Mauro Giuliani

In this etude of a ¾ time signature, you will intertwine textures of Alberti bass with other contrasting textures, such as small scales, slur passages, and even moments with dotted rhythm. The piece is agile and light, and so should you be when practicing it! ;)
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12920/2559 Le Papillon Op 50 - No 19 Tempo di polacca-1.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12920/2559 Le Papillon Op 50 - No 19 Tempo di polacca 2.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Le Papillon, Op. 50 – No. 29, Allegretto
lessons.lesson_content:
by Mauro Giuliani

The next Alberti bass challenge included playing sixteenth notes in the bass line and main melody simultaneously. Practice these short passages individually, and in a much slower tempo, so that you fully understand how to coordinate the fingers of the right hand. Besides that, you will find new harmonies that will lead you to different fingerings for the left hand.

course_title: Alberti Bass Like a Guitar Pro – Part 2
course_content:
Highlights

  • A stronger, faster, and more precise thumb.
  • Specializing in Alberti Bass acompaniment.
  • Developing virtuosic voice treatment capacity, both in phrasing and dynamic range.

Description

In the part 2 of this course you will be practicing one of the most used techniques during the classical era for classical guitar – the Alberti style bass and accompaniment. You will begin with easier pieces, but difficulty will rise with every step! This method consists of an etude selection from Le Papillon, Op. 50 by Mauro Giuliani, 24 Progressive Lessons, Op. 31, 24 Etudes, Op. 35, and Theme Varies et 12 Menuets, Op. 11 by Fernando Sor. There is a continuous rise in the difficulty level throughout the method, so it is recommended that you feel comfortable playing the etudes from the first steps before engaging on a harder piece of a later step. You can listen to the whole set of pieces and understand that they do share similar classical vocabulary, therefore knowing one piece WILL make it easier to learn the next one.

Requirement

  • Beginner-Intermediate level in right hand arpeggio playing.
  • Novice level of chords and melody playing on first position.
  • Intermediate level of reading scores ability.
  • Fluency in performing in 1st and 2nd position.
  • Intermediate level right hand arpeggio playing skills.

course_title: Basis for Even Sounding Bow Strokes (Demo)
course_content:
Highlights

  • Developing longer bow strokes.
  • Maintaining even sounding bow strokes.
  • Intonation in G Major and D Major.
  • Practicing smoothening the shifts.

Description

With this violin method you are able to experience Scorewind's didactic approach to music for free! We hope you apreciate the "step by step" model we have developed. If so, we welcome you to enroll in the other music methods we have available for you. Have fun! Dancla is well known for his melodic approach to teaching violin technique. This course is prepared for players who have a basic understanding on how to read notes. Both the exercises prepared for the end goal piece and the piece itself must be played with calm, soft sounding and even bow strokes. Since what is demanded from the left hand is not extremely challenging, there is space for focusing on this peculiar quality in this course. After step by step exercises picked to guide the player to the end result, the piece itself gets so much easier to learn!

Requirement

  • Novice level of score reading ability. (slow but steady deciphering skills for the notes that coincide 1st position on the violin fretboard)
  • Mobility of 2nd finger. (to switch between 1-23 / 12-3 hand positions)
  • Proficiency in maintaining stable tempo.
  • (optional): proficiency in using 4th finger.

What's next

Next course: Get Better at String Crossing Melodiously

lessons.lesson_title: Introduction to ‘Violin Method (Demo): Basis for Even Sounding Bow Strokes’
lessons.lesson_content:
With this violin method you are able to experience Scorewind's didactic approach to music for free! We hope you apreciate the "step by step" model we have developed. If so, we welcome you to enroll in the other music methods we have available for you. Have fun!

Dancla is well known for his melodic approach to teaching violin technique. This course is prepared for players who have a basic understanding on how to read notes. Both the exercises prepared for the end goal piece and the piece itself must be played with calm, soft sounding and even bow strokes. Since what is demanded from the left hand is not extremely challenging, there is space for focusing on this peculiar quality in this course. After step by step exercises picked to guide the player to the end result, the piece itself gets so much easier to learn!

lessons.lesson_title: Bow Workout – Open String Playing – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content: Playing the open strings with as long of a bow stroke as possible is very helpful as a warm up exercise. At this point a beginner must not force their muscles to go all the way to the end or start right at the frog. These areas that may be tough to control will get easier within a week or two. Pay attention to tilting the bow towards the frog and widening the point of contact by straightening it towards the tip.

lessons.lesson_title: G major scale starting on D string – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

G Major scale in this octave is slightly more complicated than the one in the lower octave due to the change of placement of the 1st finger. The learner must keep the 1st and 2nd fingers very close to each other and play the 1st finger in a way that it gets “resolved” on the second finger.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12126/3712 12126 G Major Scale Starting On D String.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12126/3712 G major scale starting on D string.xml

lessons.lesson_title: G major Arpeggios and inversions starting on D string – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Learners can focus on the parallel movements of the fingers in this arpeggio. It is also essential to prepare the finger position of the next note while playing the current note. This way of thinking can apply to the string crossings as well.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12176/3652 12176 G Major Arpeggios Starting On D String.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12176/3652 G major Arpeggios and inversions starting on D string.xml

lessons.lesson_title: D Major Scale – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

D Major follows the "1-23" finger pattern in the middle strings which is why it is often used as one of the first scales to start playing the violin. On the way up while playing the 3rd finger the player can prepare the elbows for the next string’s position, and on the way down the open string can be used for the same purpose.

lessons.lesson_title: D Major Arpeggios and Inversions – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Arpeggios are perfect workouts for fingers to gain autonomy, meaning braking the step by step pattern and act individually within larger intervals. To place the 2nd correctly after open string, one can “imagine” to place the 1st finger and then place the 2nd finger accordingly.

While playing the D Major arpeggio, players should be aware of the diagonal relation between the 2nd and the 3rd finger. This will help to play in tune in the future by associating notes not only to other notes on the same string but to notes that are on the other strings

lessons.lesson_title: Left Hand Workout – G Major Fingering – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Exercises

When there is a passage with a repetitive note, the fingers must stay near the string as much as possible for the replacement to be as effortless and rapid as possible. At slow tempos the left hand fingers can “hammer” on the strings as well.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12125/3713 12125 Left Hand Workout - G Major Fingering Exercise.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12125/3713 Left Hand Workout - G Major Fingering Exercise.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Left Hand Workout – Step by step 3rd and 4th fingers – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

This exercise should first played as third finger and open string for the ear to get used to the sound. In the second round the 4th finger can be introduced if it is not too much of a muscle effort at this point. Pressing the pinky with a round manner is not the priority. Fingers can be put on the fingerboard rather flatly to not over work the muscles. A firm press on the pinky does not require too much pressure so keep in mind the trick of "touching the string to the wood" instead of "pressing down deeply".
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12170/3659 12170 Left Hand Workout - Step By Step 3Rd And 4Th Fingers.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12170/3659 Left Hand Workout - Step by step 3rd and 4th fingers.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Bow Workout – String Crossing 1 – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content: When crossing between strings, the player can prepare the new angle through the right elbow by the end of the current note. Adapting to the position of the “new” string before playing it makes the string crosses as smooth as possible. Same rule applies to the left elbow when playing notes on the strings.

lessons.lesson_title: Broken 3rds – D Major – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

This exercise for bettering the broken 3rds on the violin must be played very carefully and only after playing the D Major itself is an achievable task. Although it might seem confusing in the beginning, this pattern is very often used in classical music, so getting to used to it will help develop vocabulary for the future, and make learning other pieces a lot easier!

course_title: Become Better at Long Lasting 8th Note Phrases
course_content:
Highlights

  • Executing chromatic crescending lines
  • Playing long lasting eight note runs.
  • Learning to shift from long strokes to short strokes rapidly.
  • Chromatic intonation control.

Description

This step-by-step guide prepares you to perform the Etude No. 8 from Dancla's Op. 84, 36 Melodic Studies book. The piece is played around the keys C Major and of course its relative minor A Minor, which is why the course contains exercises to make these tonalities familiar to your left hand. Pro Tip: When playing the goal piece at the end of the course make sure to breath in and out regularly!

Requirement

  • Novice level of score reading ability. (slow but steady deciphering skills for the notes that coincide 1st position on the violin fretboard)
  • Mobility of 2nd and 3rd fingers.
  • Proficiency in using 4th finger.
  • Proficiency in half, quarter, eight notes.

What's next

Next course: First Step Towards Rhythmic Challenges
course_short_description: This step-by-step guide prepares you to perform the Etude No. 8 from Dancla's Op. 84, 36 Melodic Studies book. This course contains exercises to make the C major and A minor tonalities familiar to your left hand.

lessons.lesson_title: Introduction to ‘Become Better at Long Lasting 8th Note Phrases’
lessons.lesson_content: This step-by-step guide prepares you to perform the Etude No. 8 from Dancla's Op. 84, 36 Melodic Studies book. The piece is played around the keys C Major and of course its relative minor A Minor, which is why the course contains exercises to make these tonalities familiar to your left hand. Pro Tip: When playing the goal piece at the end of the course make sure to breath in and out regularly!

lessons.lesson_title: A Minor Melodic Scale starting on A string – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Playing a melodic scale, the player must be very careful about the 6th and 7th notes of the scale since they will be altering between directions. This is highly used in classical music since it keeps the tonality minor and the harmonic tension within melody is distributed evenly.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12183/3643 12183 A Minor Melodic Scale Starting on A String.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12183/3643 A Minor Melodic Scale starting on A string.xml

lessons.lesson_title: A Minor Melodic Scale starting on G string – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Lower octave of the A minor melodic scale needs extended 3rd finger position on the D string. In slow tempo practice this note can be played with the 4th finger instead of the 3rd but in faster tempos it would not be as practical unless the tonic (A) is going to be played on the open string.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12182/3644 12182 A Minor Melodic Scale Starting on G String.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12182/3644 A Minor Melodic Scale starting on G string.xml

lessons.lesson_title: A Minor Arpeggio and Inversions – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

For beginners, arpeggios of minor scales are slightly harder than the major ones. In this situation the player should be aware that there will be a diagonal and large gap between the 2nd and 3rd finger in the 1st inversion and 2nd and 1st finger in the 2nd inversion.

lessons.lesson_title: Left Hand Workout – Speeding up Fingers (A minor melodic) – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

When playing this exercise learners must remember that the bow stroke is a simple long bow stroke and keep the left hand fingers as round as possible for precision of timing the 8th notes. Although hammering each note may not be necessary it can be useful to gain strength.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12153/3681 12153 Left Hand Workout Speed up Finger A Minor Mel.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12153/3681 Left Hand Workout - Speeding up Fingers (A minor melodic).xml

lessons.lesson_title: Intonation Workout – B half diminished chord – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Half diminished chords are few of the chords that the fingers are not placed entirely parallel to each other between the strings. Pay attention to the 1st finger; from one string to the other it will shift diagonally. For fine-tuning most beginners must exaggerate this difference.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12152/3682 12152 Intonation Workout B Half Diminished Chord.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12152/3682 Intonation Workout - B half diminished chord.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Broken 3rds – C Major – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Broken 3rds are a big part of classical music vocabulary. While playing them slow; preparing the string change from both elbows can help the learner to speed up. In faster tempos the elbows should stand in a middle zone between two strings. Focus on breathing in and out regularly while playing this exercise!

lessons.lesson_title: Case Specific – Chromatism Workout – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

This exercise is not meant to sound nice! :) While practicing chromatic passages it is important to not slide on the string with full pressure. Finger numbers can alter from one method to the other, but it is mostly safe to play the note with the common 1st position finger that gets together with it. Example; C on the G string is played with the 3rd finger, doesn't matter if it is sharp or not; or B on th G string is played with the 2nd finger, so both flat and natural B will be played with the 2nd finger.

course_title: Classical Homophony and Arpeggiation
course_content:
Highlights

  • Learn how to treat homophonic voicing.
  • Dynamic range control.
  • Precision in playing various notes at the same time.
  • Focus on arpeggio technique.

Description

This step by step method will help you practice an etude by Mauro Giuliani. In the first part of his etude you will work on homophonic voicing, and the challenges there include the precision of playing them exactly at the same time and with a balanced intensity. On the second part, the intervals become wider, allowing space for an arpeggiated acompaniment technique for the right hand, from which the middle line should be played with lower volume than the singing melody and the bass line.

Requirement

  • Completion of course: ‘Introduction to Chords and Arpeggios’.
  • Novice level of score reading ability.
  • Novice experience in one voice treatment and playing.
  • Familiar with essential beginner chords (Check 'Introduction to Chords and Arpeggios' otherwise).
  • Beginner level in left hand vertical finger extension.
  • Beginner level in right hand arpeggiation.

What's next

Next course: Practice the "Feeling in Three"
course_short_description: This step by step method will help you practice an etude by Mauro Giuliani. In the first part of his etude you will work on homophonic voicing, and on the second part, you will practice wider intervals together with an arpeggiated acompaniment technique for the right hand.

lessons.lesson_title: Introduction to “Classical Homophony and Arpeggiation”
lessons.lesson_content: This step by step method will help you practice an etude by Mauro Giuliani. In the first part of his etude you will work on homophonic voicing, and the challenges there include the precision of playing them exactly at the same time and with a balanced intensity. On the second part, the intervals become wider, allowing space for an arpeggiated acompaniment technique for the right hand, from which the middle line should be played with lower volume than the singing melody and the bass line.

lessons.lesson_title: 3/4 Count With 6ths – Guitar Exercises
lessons.lesson_content:
In this exercise you will be practicing two things, parallel 6ths and the feeling of the ternary pulse. Remember to place the weight on the first beat of each bar. Finding the right place for your left elbow will help you play throught the various vertical extensions.

by ScoreWind Teachers

lessons.lesson_title: Arpeggio Technique for the Right Hand
lessons.lesson_content:
In this step you will focus on the arpeggiated technique of accompaniment. Both melody and harmony are integrated in a right hand arpeggiated fingering combination. Try reaching the strings by moving the place of your hand rather than stretching your fingers to reach to each string.

by ScoreWind Teachers

lessons.lesson_title: Open Broken Thirds in p-m-i Arpeggio – All Available Notes in 1st Position (C Major) – Guitar Exercises
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

This exercise will help you to get familiar with the technical challenges over the vertical finger extensions existing in this type of intervals. Make sure to feel comfortable playing them, because they often appear throughout the music of this era.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12101/12101 3761 Open Thirds in p-m-i Arpeggio - All Available Notes in 1st Position (C Major).mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12101/3761 Open Thirds in p-m-i Arpeggio - All Available Notes in 1st Position (C Major).xml

lessons.lesson_title: Close Broken Thirds in C Major – Guitar Exercises
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Close thirds do not require large finger extensions, as the open thirds usually do, but they often bring uncomfortable finger placement, and challenging finger independence for the left hand. Practice carefully this exercise and the thirds of the music piece will become easier for you.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12100/12100 3762 Close Broken Thirds in C Major.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12100/3762 Close Broken Thirds in C Major.xml

course_title: Classical Vocabulary for Violin – Part 1 (Demo)
course_content:
Highlights

  • Playing pieces that introduce the classical vocabulary that will be used in almost all musical pieces in future repetroire.

Description

A course dedicated to an etude selection from the 36 Easy and Melodic Studies, Op. 84 by Dancla. A good way to introduce the learner to the basic vocabulary of classical music. It is designed for musicians that know their basic note reading skills, that are aware of whereabouts of notes on the first position and are establishing their rhythmic understanding. Spread through the pieces, the learner can practice various beginner friendly and intermediate tonalities. Phrases and forms of these etudes are rather musical than technical. This can help violin learners to establish essential storytelling skills within melodies.  Although technical difficulties of each piece is rather similar within this collected group of pieces, they are not meant to be played precisely with the given order. Yet they can help each other out; since learning classical vocabulary is like learning a new language; knowing one piece WILL make it easier to learn the next one. There is a difficulty level rise to some extend towards the last pieces. You can listen to the whole set of pieces and start from whichever piece you feel the interest for.

Requirement

  • Novice level of score reading ability. (slow but steady deciphering skills for the notes that coincide 1st position on the violin fretboard)
  • Mobility of 2nd and 3rd fingers.
  • Proficiency in using 4th finger.
  • Proficiency in half, quarter, eight notes.

What's next

Next course: Classical Vocabulary for Violin - Part 2

  • Playing pieces that include various technical challenges within the classical vocabulary that will be used in almost all musical pieces in future repertoire.

Description

A course (part 2) dedicated to an etude selection from the 36 Easy and Melodic Studies, Op. 84 by Dancla. A good way to introduce the learner to the basic vocabulary of classical music. It is designed for musicians that know their basic note reading skills, that are aware of whereabouts of notes on the first position and are establishing their rhythmic understanding. Spread through the pieces, the learner can practice various beginner friendly and intermediate tonalities. Phrases and forms of these etudes are rather musical than technical. This can help violin learners to establish essential storytelling skills within melodies.  Although technical difficulties of each piece is rather similar within this collected group of pieces, they are not meant to be played precisely with the given order. course_title: Contrasting Musical Ideas
course_content:
Highlights

  • Executing vibrato on long notes
  • (Optional): playing passages on 3rd position.
  • Switching between wide spread musical phrases and staccato 8th note runs.

Description

This step-by-step guide is planned to help players execute a 3/4 piece that has two very contrasting parts, one that is very lineal and melodic, other that is relatively fast and to be played with a very active attitude. As well as that, the end goal piece have two alternatives fingerings to perform, one on 1st position and the other that includes 3rd position. We recommend the player to first focus on playing the entire piece on 1st position. Only after this goal is reached, the learners can move on to the next challenge, which is to use the fingerings indicated on the score.

Requirement

  • Novice experience in executing staccato technique.
  • Proficiency in 3/4 time signature.
  • Mobility of 2nd finger.
  • Proficiency in half, quarter, eight and dotted notes.
  • (Optional): Novice experience in position shifting.

What's next

Next course: Get Better at Slurred String Changes

lessons.lesson_title: D Dorian Scale – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

D Dorian is a modal scale rather than a tonal scale. Scales like this were more used in medieval times and in early music. After that they have been borrowed time to time by classical musicians and came back to use only in the beginning of 20th century. Pay attention to the color of this scale, it does sound a bit minor and a bit major at the same time!

lessons.lesson_title: Left Hand Workout – C Major 3/4 – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Arpeggiating a chord can sound very melodic and can be a bit demanding as well. If performing this exercise is too hard for you, try to play each note twice and thrice before going for the actual line. These sort of repetitions give you chance to relax and rapidly prepare the next note.

lessons.lesson_title: Broken 3rds – C Major – 2 – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Broken 3rds are a big part of classical music vocabulary. While playing them slow; preparing the string change not only from the hands but also from both elbows can help the learner to speed up. In faster tempos the elbows should be positioned to stand rihgt in between position required to play the two strings.

lessons.lesson_title: Bow Workout – Stacattos in 3/4 – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

This exercise requires very slow practice at the beginning. Try to start each note after the bow’s point of contact is well established on the string. Only then with a rapid and clear beginning begin the bow stroke. The right hand can get relaxed right after the start, instead of staying stiff. The ending needs to be stopped but not muted on the string. Start playing the next note only after establishing a good position to begin. This will become easier and faster only in time.

lessons.lesson_title: Bow Workout – Staccatos With String Change in 3/4 – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

String crossing while playing staccato is actually not that hard once string change combination is cleared out. It is recommended to play this line once without staccato to achieve this comfort level, after that applying the staccato technique described in other staccatto exercises on it must be easier.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12136/3699 Bow Workout - Staccatos With String Change In 3 4.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12136/3699 Bow Workout - Stacattos With String Change in 34.xml

lessons.lesson_title: D Major Scale Starting on A String (3rd Position) – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

While playing on higher positions, players must be careful about their left thumb; it needs to follow their index finger precisely to the point of the position. Once the hand position is correct, getting used to slightly smaller intervals is not going to be that hard. The note D can be compared to the open string D to make sure the intonation is well at the start point. Same trick is recommended to check if A is in tune as well.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12135/3700 D Major Scale Starting On A String (3Rd Position).mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12135/3700 D Major Scale Starting on A String (3rd Position).xml

lessons.lesson_title: Case Specific – Position Changes 1 – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

When playing scales or melodies on position, if the learner is new to playing in higher positions, it is recommended to play the same content one octave below or if possible, as is on the 1st position. This way the ear figures out what needs to be done, and most often fingers follow that. While sliding to the new position, player can move the pivot finger (marked with smaller notes) on the string but should not press it down.

course_title: Developing Piano Arpeggios – Part 1
course_content:
Highlights

  • Learning to play in 3/4 measure.
  • Learning to play in 6/8 measure.
  • Foundations of left hand arpeggiated accompaniment.
  • Melodic parallel voicing on the right hand (parallel 3rds).
  • Arpeggiated melody playing on the right hand.

Description

Knowing well your arpeggios is an important part of your growth as a piano player. This Part 1 of the arpeggio's course for piano will take you to beginner level etudes from Practical Exercises for Beginners, Op. 599, and 100 Progressive Studies, Op. 139, in which you get introduced to essential melodic arpeggios, as well as arpeggiated accompaniment including arpeggios in triplets, and Alberti bass. There is a continuous rise in the difficulty level throughout the method, so it is recommended that you feel comfortable playing the etudes from the first steps before engaging on a harder piece of a later step. You can listen to the whole set of pieces and understand that they do share similar classical vocabulary, therefore knowing one piece WILL make it easier to learn the next one.

Requirement

  • Novice level of score reading ability (Reading notes on G clef).
  • Knowing basic note values (8th, quarter, half, whole notes).
  • Novice level autonomy in both hands.
  • Fluent in C Major scale melodic lines.
  • 3 octave playing experience.

What's next

Next course: Developing Piano Arpeggios - Part 2
course_short_description: Knowing well your arpeggios is an important part of your growth as a piano player. This course will show you beginner friendly etudes for essential melodic arpeggios, arpeggiated accompaniment, and Alberti bass.

lessons.lesson_content:

lessons.lesson_title: Practical Exercises for Beginners, Op. 599 – Etude No. 11
lessons.lesson_content:
by Carl Czerny

This etude trains the hands to gain different roles while playing. Such as a melodic content and a harmonic content. It is recommended to practice each hand separately before playing both parts together. It is important to play the chords as relaxed as possible with the left hand since chords are after all notes of arpeggios which are played at the same time.

lessons.lesson_title: 100 Progressive Studies, Op. 139 – Etude No. 5
lessons.lesson_content:
by Carl Czerny

With this piece the player is introduced to 3/4 time where there are 3 quarter notes instead of 4. The left hand accompanies rather straight ahead while right hand is playing a relatively repetitive melody which helps the learner to focus on the movement of the left hand.

lessons.lesson_title: Practical Exercises for Beginners, Op. 599 – Etude No. 15
lessons.lesson_content:
by Carl Czerny

In this etude the arpeggio is spread on the left hand. It is most important to keep the left hand motion as round as possible, by preparing the next bar in advance all the time. This can be done by the 5th finger, reaching for the next note while the 1st finger is playing the current note.

lessons.lesson_title: Practical Exercises for Beginners, Op. 599 – Etude No. 23
lessons.lesson_content:
by Carl Czerny

This piece combines arpeggios in two different speeds since the right hand line consists on arpeggios as well as left hand. Once the melody notes are established and are comfortable to play, players must focus on phrasing the line with the slurs indicated by the score. 

2 pages

course_title: Developing Piano Arpeggios – Part 2
course_content:
Highlights

  • Learning to play triplets.
  • Learning to play phrases with anarcusis (anacruse).
  • Repetitive triads and dryads in right hand.
  • Gaining proficiency in Albertsi bass style.
  • Playing Waltz rhythm.
  • Developing dynamic range.
  • Switching between G clef and F clef on the left hand.

Description

Knowing well your arpeggios is an important part of your growth as a piano player. The Part 2 of the arpeggio's course for piano will take you to beginner level etudes from Practical Exercises for Beginners, Op. 599, and 100 Progressive Studies, Op. 139, in which you get introduced to essential melodic arpeggios, as well as arpeggiated accompaniment including arpeggios in triplets, and Alberti bass. There is a continuous rise in the difficulty level throughout the method, so it is recommended that you feel comfortable playing the etudes from the first steps before engaging on a harder piece of a later step. You can listen to the whole set of pieces and understand that they do share similar classical vocabulary, therefore knowing one piece WILL make it easier to learn the next one.

Requirement

  • Novice level of score reading ability (Reading notes on G clef).
  • Knowing basic note values (8th, quarter, half, whole notes).
  • Novice level autonomy in both hands.
  • Fluent in C Major scale melodic lines.
  • 3 octave playing experience.

What's next

Next course: Scales and Finger Speed for Piano - Part 1
course_short_description: Knowing well your arpeggios is an important part of your growth as a piano player. This course (part 2) will show you beginner friendly etudes for essential melodic arpeggios, arpeggiated accompaniment, and Alberti bass.

course_title: Dotted Rhythm of the Classical Era for Guitar – Part 1
course_content:
Highlights

  • Playing dotted rhythm correctly in intermediate level repertoire.
  • Quickly adapting to playing isolated motifs, or continuous patterns of dotted rhythm.
  • Playing single notes, and up to two notes at the same time, in dotted rhythm.
  • Developing parallel thirds playing.

Description

The part 1 of this course will progressively lead you to perfect the art of dotted rhythm through mid-beginner to intermediate levels pieces of the Classical-Romantic era of the classical guitar.  With each one of the following ten etudes you will be practicing dotted rhythm in various musical contexts, which come with their unique challenges. Sometimes you will find a piece where you will be playing a dotted rhythm pattern in a constant, and in other situations the appearance of this precise rhythmical figure is crucially placed in individual musical moments. Dotted rhythm was frequently used by the guitar composers of the Classical-Romantic era, and they have left us an enormous source with which we can master this characteristic figure. The method consists of an etude selection from Le Papillon, Op. 50 by Mauro Giuliani, 24 Very Easy Exercises, Op. 35, and 24 Short Progressive Pieces, Op. 44 by Fernando Sor,. There is a continuous rise in the difficulty level throughout the method, so it is recommended that you feel comfortable playing the etudes from the first steps before engaging on a harder piece of a later step. You can listen to the whole set of pieces and understand that they do share similar classical vocabulary, therefore knowing one piece WILL make it easier to learn the next one.

Requirement

  • Recognizing dotted rhythm and how to reproduce it.
  • Familiarity with dotted rhythm in beginner level repertoire.

What's next

Next course: Dotted Rhythm of the Classical Era for Guitar - Part 2

lessons.lesson_title: Le Papillon, Op. 50 – No. 21, Andantino
lessons.lesson_content:
by Mauro Giuliani

You will find in this etude two different kinds of dotted rhythms; one faster and other slower. Acknowledge both of them and pay special attention to the precision of their uniqueness. Do not rush the rhythmic figures at any moment. The more precise you are with the dotted rhythm, the more “royal” will the piece sound.

2 pages

lessons.lesson_title: Le Papillon, Op. 50 – No. 31, Allegretto
lessons.lesson_content:
by Mauro Giuliani

This piece does not pose a difficult challenge for the left hand, for the fingerings will come naturally, but the rhythmic precision on a 6/8 bar might be harder to achieve. Pay attention as well to the cleanliness of the notes on the appoggiaturas and the dotted figures that appear after.

lessons.lesson_title: 24 Short Progressive Pieces, Op. 44 – Etude No. 18, Marcha
lessons.lesson_content:
by Fernando Sor

With this etude you will be practicing dotted figures in mid and high pitch registers, while changing your technique through normal playing and harmonics passages of the piece. Make sure to have a musical intention suitable to a march.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13063/2326 24 Short Progressive Pieces, Op. 44 - Etude No. 18, Marcha-2.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13063/2326 24 Short Progressive Pieces, Op. 44 - Etude No. 18, Marcha 2.xml

course_title: Dotted Rhythm of the Classical Era for Guitar – Part 2
course_content:
Highlights

  • Playing dotted rhythm correctly in intermediate-advanced level repertoire.
  • Quickly adapting to playing isolated motifs, or continuous patterns of dotted rhythm.
  • Playing up to three notes at the same time in dotted rhythm.

Description

The part 2 of this course will progressively lead you to perfect the art of dotted rhythm through mid-beginner to intermediate levels pieces of the Classical-Romantic era of the classical guitar.  With each one of the following ten etudes you will be practicing dotted rhythm in various musical contexts, which come with their unique challenges. Sometimes you will find a piece where you will be playing a dotted rhythm pattern in a constant, and in other situations the appearance of this precise rhythmical figure is crucially placed in individual musical moments. Dotted rhythm was frequently used by the guitar composers of the Classical-Romantic era, and they have left us an enormous source with which we can master this characteristic figure. The method consists of an etude selection from 24 Very Easy Exercises, Op. 35, 6 Divertimentos Op. 1, 6 Short Pieces Op. 32, and 24 Short Progressive Pieces, Op. 44 by Fernando Sor. There is a continuous rise in the difficulty level throughout the method, so it is recommended that you feel comfortable playing the etudes from the first steps before engaging on a harder piece of a later step. You can listen to the whole set of pieces and understand that they do share similar classical vocabulary, therefore knowing one piece WILL make it easier to learn the next one.

Requirement

  • Fluency in basic and dotted rhythm patterns.
  • Intermediate level of score reading ability.
  • Familiarity with 1st position melody playing.
  • Ability to play pieces in C, G and D Major.
  • Intermediate level of chords and melody playing.

course_title: First Piano Notes With Master Czerny – Part 1 (Demo)
course_content:
Highlights

  • Play your first notes on piano.
  • Learning how to play whole, half and quarter notes.
  • Playing with five fingers of both hands.
  • Playing notes in a 3-octave range.
  • Gain autonomy and start to play melodic lines on the right hand.

Description

The first 10 etudes of Carl Czerny's Practical Exercises for Beginners, Op. 599, are all about learning the first notes on the piano. Practice this method to have by your side the great master Czerny and one of our teachers of Scorewind! On the part 1 of this course, you will be playing the first five etudes. When practicing them, it is essential to start one hand at a time. Only after both hands can play their parts individually we recommend to combine the work of both hands, at a comfortable tempo with space enough to think. There is a continuous rise in the difficulty level throughout the method, so it is recommended that you feel comfortable playing the etudes from the first steps before engaging on a harder piece of a later step. You can listen to the whole set of pieces and understand that they do share similar classical vocabulary, therefore knowing one piece WILL make it easier to learn the next one.

Requirement

  • Novice level of score reading ability (Reading notes on G clef).
  • Knowing the notes coenciding with the white keys within the mid register of the piano.

What's next

Next course: First Piano Notes With Master Czerny - Part 2
course_short_description: With this piano method you will be able to experience Scorewind's didactic 'Path' approach to music for free! Practice this course to have by your side the great master Czerny and one of our teachers of Scorewind!

lessons.lesson_title: Introduction to ‘First Piano Notes With Master Czerny – Part 1 (Demo)’
lessons.lesson_content:

lessons.lesson_title: Practical Exercises for Beginners, Op. 599 – Etude No. 4
lessons.lesson_content:
by Carl Czerny

In this etude you will practice reading notes that are written in very high ledger lines, that accommodate notes that you've played before but in a lower octave. The reading might seem harder at first, but notice how similar the exercises is to previous etudes and you will see that you soon be able to play it.

course_title: First Piano Notes With Master Czerny – Part 2
course_content:
Highlights

  • Gaining a greater sense of rhythm with whole, half and quarter notes.
  • Playing melodies that have “call and response” style.
  • Playing chords (3 notes at the same time) with one hand.
  • Gain autonomy and start to play melodic lines on the left hand.
  • Playing chords on both hands.

Description

The first 10 etudes of Carl Czerny's Practical Exercises for Beginners, Op. 599, are all about learning the first notes on the piano. Practice this method to have by your side the great master Czerny and one of our teachers of Scorewind! On the part 2 of this course, you will be playing five new etudes, that follow the first five from the Part 1 of this course. When practicing them, it is essential to start one hand at a time. Only after both hands can play their parts individually we recommend to combine the work of both hands, at a comfortable tempo with space enough to think. There is a continuous rise in the difficulty level throughout the method, so it is recommended that you feel comfortable playing the etudes from the first steps before engaging on a harder piece of a later step. You can listen to the whole set of pieces and understand that they do share similar classical vocabulary, therefore knowing one piece WILL make it easier to learn the next one.

Requirement

  • Novice level of score reading ability (Reading notes on G clef).
  • Knowing the notes coenciding with the white keys within the mid-high register of the piano.
  • Novice level autonomy in both hands.

What's next

Next course: Introduction to Piano With Romantic Era Etudes - Part 1 (Demo)
course_short_description: Practice this course (part 2) to have by your side the great master Czerny and one of our teachers of Scorewind!

course_title: First Position Foundations (Demo)
course_content:
Highlights

  • Introduction to fundamental techniques.
  • Basic melodic arpeggios.
  • Parallel thirds in open position.
  • Treatment of voices.

Description

With this guitar method you are able to experience Scorewind's didactic approach to music for free! We hope you appreciate the "step by step" model we have developed. If so, we welcome you to enrol in the other music methods we have available for you. Have fun! By the end of the steps within this method you will encounter an etude by Fernando Sor which presents some of the fundamental techniques necessary to know how to play the classical guitar. It introduces melodic arpeggios, parallel thirds in open position, and basic voicing treatment.

Requirement

  • Novice level of score reading ability. (slow but steady deciphering skills for the notes that coincide 1st position on the guitar fretboard)
  • Proficiency in maintaining stable tempo on a 4/4 bar.
  • Familiar with playing two notes at the same time.
  • Novice level of using the 4th finger.

What's next

Next course: Getting Familiar With Melodic Arpeggios and Thirds
course_short_description: With this guitar method you will be able to experience Scorewind's didactic 'step by step' approach to music for free! It introduces melodic arpeggios, parallel thirds in open position, and basic voicing treatment.

lessons.lesson_title: C major Scale in First Position One Octave – Guitar Exercises
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Practicing this scale will give you a better sense of the melodic and harmonic context of the music. It will help your fingers to memorize the place of the notes on the instrument, as well as strengthening them.
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12119/3731 C Major Scale in First Position.xml

lessons.lesson_title: G Major Scale in First Position One Octave – Guitar Exercises
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Practice this scale to get familiar with the notes that you will use on the piece. Follow the fingerings given by the score, paying special attention to the coordination between the second and third fingers when playing on the first string.
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12118/3732 G Major Scale in First Position.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Scale of Available Notes in First Position – Guitar Exercises
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

On this exercise you will play through all the available notes of the scale present on the piece, from its lowest to its highest note. It will help you gain full control of the note spectrum of the music, and improve the coordination of your both hands.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12117/12117 3733 All Available Notes C Major Scale.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12117/3733 Scale of Available Notes in First Position (C major).xml

lessons.lesson_title: C Major Arpeggio in First Position – Guitar Exercises
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

By practicing arpeggios you will be working on the melodic and intervallic patterns of the music. C major arpeggio and chord on the first position usually requires special attention to the horizontal extension of the left hand fingers 3-2-1.
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12116/3734 C Major Arpeggio in First Position.xml

lessons.lesson_title: D Minor Arpeggio in First Position – Guitar Exercises
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

This arpeggio will help you workout the vertical placement of fingers 3-2-4, which can sometimes be a difficult combination. Make sure that the 4th finger is curved and aligned with the 3rd finger.

lessons.lesson_title: G Major Arpeggio on First Position
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

This arpeggio will help you get familiar with the technical challenge of the vertical extension of the second and third finger. The pressed notes of this arpeggio also give you the fingering for playing the G major chord on the first position.
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12114/3736 G Major Arpeggio in First Position.xml

lessons.lesson_title: G Major Open Broken Thirds in First Position – Guitar Exercises
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

This exercise will help you to get familiar with the technical challenges over the vertical finger extensions existing in this type of intervals. Make sure to feel comfortable playing them, because they often appear throughout the music of this era.
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12113/3737 G major open broken thirds in first position.xml

lessons.lesson_title: G Major Open Parallel Thirds on First Position – Guitar Exercises
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

The technical arpeggio p-m, i, is one of the most common styles of playing in this music genre, and together with open thirds they have made some of the most wonderful music for guitar. Pay attention to keep the legato between the notes, and a stable and rounded right hand.
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12111/3739 G Major Open Parallel Thirds on First Position.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Case Specific – Difficult Intervals – Guitar Exercises
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

In the following exercise you will be focusing on individual intervals present on the piece which tend to be uncomfortable for the left hand. If you have practiced the arpeggios on the previous steps, this exercise might be easier for you to play.

course_title: First Step Towards Rhythmic Challenges
course_content:
Highlights

  • Executing a melody with large syncopation between bars.
  • Executing melodies with dotted note content.

Description

This course contains preparation material that will lead the player to perform Dancla's Etude No. 9, Op. 84 successfully. The vocabulary of the piece itself is very similar to some other etudes of his, but this one comes with more dotted rhythm challenges, and a large syncopation at the middle section. Syncopation means running over the beat with a note that starts in the middle of the previous beat, if this sounds complicated, we trust our score viewer will help you understand it!

Requirement

  • Novice level of score reading ability. (slow but steady deciphering skills for the notes that coincide 1st position on the violin fretboard)
  • Mobility of 2nd and 3rd fingers.
  • Proficiency in using 4th finger.
  • Proficiency in half, quarter, eight and dotted notes.
  • Proficiency in slurring 2 to 4 notes in one bow evenly.

What's next

Next course: Starting with Minor Pieces
course_tag: half dotted quarter and eighth notes
course_short_description: This course contains preparation material that will lead the player to perform successfully the rhythmic challenges of Dancla's Etude No. 9, Op. 84.

lessons.lesson_title: Introduction to ‘First Steps Towards Rhythmic Challenges’
lessons.lesson_content: This course contains preparation material that will lead the player to perform Dancla's Etude No. 9, Op. 84 successfully. The vocabulary of the piece itself is very similar to some other etudes of his, but this one comes with more dotted rhythm challenges, and a large syncopation at the middle section. Syncopation means running over the beat with a note that starts in the middle of the previous beat, if this sounds complicated, we trust our score viewer will help you understand it!

lessons.lesson_title: G Major 2 Octave Scale with Slurs of 4 – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Practicing this scale both with open strings and with 4th finger instead can be useful. Try to use the entire bow divided into four equal parts for learning how to use the bow economically. The finger pattern does not stay symmetrical and it is good to be aware of that.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12179/3647 12179 G Major 2 Octave Scale With Slurs of 4.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12179/3647 G Major 2 Octave Scale with Slurs of 4.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Broken 3rds – D Major 2 – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Broken 3rds are a big part of classical music vocabulary. While playing them slow; preparing the string change from both elbows can help the learner to speed up. In faster tempos both elbows should be held in a posture positioned in the middle of the angles necessary to play both strings individually to move as less as possible.

lessons.lesson_title: Rhytmic Workout – Syncopation 1 – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by the ScoreWind Teachers

Syncopation can come in many forms and this is one of the most common patterns. In its repetitive form the bow strokes shift from a down stroke starting pattern to an up stroke pattern. Accenting the second note of each group can emphasise the placement shift and bring out the syncopation more clearly.

lessons.lesson_title: Rhytmic Workout – Syncopation 2 – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Playing this exercise requires a lot of mind work. Dividing the beat to 8th notes in mind and always remembering where the down beat is (which is always in the middle of a note that is being played, so it is hidden from the player) can be frustrating, but accenting each off beat will help gaining control over this lack of visible strong beat.

course_title: Flow of One Single Melody Line
course_content:
Highlights

  • Single melody voice treatment.
  • Right hand’s index-middle finger workout.
  • Ascending and descending scales.
  • Thumb and bass line practice.
  • Broad arpeggios.
  • Broken thirds.
  • Octave technique.
  • Jump to fifth position during a scale.

Description

This step by step method will help to practice an etude by Fernando Sor. The specialty of this etude is that it consists of a single melody line from beginning to end of the piece. Sor's musical talent finds a way to make the guitar sound with its usual full bodied sound, even though there isn't a supporting bass line or an acompaniment. Here you will practice fast and long scales, broad arpeggios, broken thirds, as well as getting introduced to the challenging octave technique. One of the hardest challenges of this etude is the position change happening during a scale, in which you would use the open e string to have a reliable jump.

Requirement

  • Beginner-intermediate level of score reading ability.
  • Proficiency in keeping stable tempo on a ternary pulse.
  • Proficiency in melodic arpeggios.
  • Novice level in broken thirds.
  • Beginner level in scale practice.
  • Familiar in playing with the thumb.

What's next

Next course: Scales, Arpeggios and Flowing Bass Lines!
course_short_description: This step by step method will help to practice an etude by Fernando Sor. The specialty of this etude is that it consists of a single melody line from beginning to end of the piece. Sor's musical talent finds a way to make the guitar sound with its usual full bodied sound, even though there isn't a supporting bass line, or acompaniment.

lessons.lesson_title: Introduction to “Flow of One Single Melody Line”
lessons.lesson_content: This step by step method will help to practice an etude by Fernando Sor. The specialty of this etude is that it consists of a single melody line from beginning to end of the piece. Sor’s musical talent finds a way to make the guitar sound with its usual full bodied sound, even though there isn’t a supporting bass line or an acompaniment. Here you will practice fast and long scales, broad arpeggios, broken thirds, as well as getting introduced to the challenging octave technique. One of the hardest challenges of this etude is the position change happening during a scale, in which you would use the open e string to have a reliable jump.

lessons.lesson_title: G Major Scale With 1st to 5th Position Jump
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

There are times when the scale you want to play requires that you make long position changes. This can interrupt the flow your your scale, leading you to not play legato, or press notes wrongly, resulting in a noise. The best way to make position changes during scales is to use the moment you reach to an open string note. Since you're not pressing any note at that moment, your hand is free to move to the next position, without interrupting the sound. Thus, when you reach to the open E on the first string, you'll  use that moment to drag your 3rd finger from D to F# on the second string. That way you successfully transfer your hand from the 1st to the 5th position.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12095/12095 3772 G Major Scale With Position Change From 1Th To 5Th.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12095/3772 G Major Scale with change from 1st to 5th position.xml

lessons.lesson_title: A Major Arpeggio on 1st Position
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

To successfuly play the A major arpeggio on first position, you must work on the flowing movement of your left hand. The notes of this chord are so tightly packed throughout the second fret, that you will have to adapt your hand placement both at the beginning and the end of the arpeggio in order to reach well to the low C on the 5th string and the high A on the 1st string. The secret for a good change is to let your 4th finger lead your hand as you both go up and down through the notes.

lessons.lesson_title: Ascending Broken Thirds in a Descending G major Scale
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Ascending broken thirds are typically used throughout the guitar's Classical Romantic period. By making sure that you have this technique under control, you will be promoting a much quicker learning of new repertoire, since it won't be an unworked challenge for you anymore. Pay attention to not repeat fingers on your left hand as that will disrupt the amazing flow of this type of passage.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12093/12093 3774 Ascending Broken Thirds In A Descending G Major Scale.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12093/3774 Ascending Broken Thirds in a Descending G major scale.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Octave Technique in G Major Scale on 1st Position
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

As you grow as a classical guitarist and you learn more about the classical romantic repertoire of Sor, Giuliani, Carcassi, Legnani, and others, you will be playing some of the most virtuoso music ever written for the instrument. Octavation of a scale is one of the most aclaimed techniques of this era. The etude on this method already introduces it to you, in a very friendly and accessible context. Practice it right, and you will have created a solid ground to continue developing this incredible technique.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12043/12043 3829 Octave Technique In G Major Scale.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12043/12043 3829 Octave Technique in G Major Scale.xml

course_title: G101.1 – INTRODUCTION TO GUITAR
course_content:
Highlights

  • Discover the parts of the instrument.
  • Learn the classical guitar posture.
  • Learn the names of the fingers: pima & 1234.
  • Introduction to playing with nails.

Description

Hello, and welcome to the first course of the “Guitar 101”. This method was specially designed for those who have a classical guitar, but have no experience with the instrument. All beginner guitar players are welcomed to this method, since it’s essential that you know all the topics of these courses before you engage in more advanced methods.

In this Guitar 101.1 course you will learn about the names of the various parts of the guitar; how to name your fingers according to the classical guitar tradition; get introduced to nail maintenance; and you will learn how to sit with your instrument in the so-called “classical guitar posture”.

Requirement

  • Having a Classical Guitar.

What's next

Next course: G101.2 - Playing With the Right Hand
course_short_description: Hello, and welcome to the first course of the “Guitar 101”. This method was specially designed for those who have a classical guitar, but have no experience with the instrument.

lessons.lesson_title: G101.1.1 – Learning the Parts of the Instrument
lessons.lesson_content:
by Scorewind Teachers

In this lesson you learn the names of the various parts of the classical guitar. You will see in detail the neck, head, and body of this incredible instrument. You get to learn where the tuning pegs are, the difference between the fingerboard (fretboard) and the flat back of the neck, what the nuts and bridges are, and where you can find them. You’ll see the difference between the backside of the body and the front soundboard, where the sound hole of the instrument is placed.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13579/13579 01 Guitar 101 Parts of the Instrument Timing Corrected.mp4

lessons.lesson_title: G101.1.2 – Introducing the Classical Guitar Posture
lessons.lesson_content:
by Scorewind Teachers

In this video you will experiment playing in various positions, and you will see how we naturally reach to a healthy sitting position to play the instrument, which is the classical guitar posture. Here you are also introduced to some tools that we guitarists use to adopt the best position possible, the foot pedal, and non-slippery fabrics.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13580/13580 02 Guitar 101 The Classical Guitar Posture Timing Corrected.mp4

lessons.lesson_title: G101.1.3 – Introduction to Nails Maintenance
lessons.lesson_content:
by Scorewind Teachers

Playing the classical guitar also means playing with nails on your right hand. It is recommended for a beginner guitarist to start playing the guitar with no nails at first, and once the technique of both hands is enough established we add the nails to the playing. Growing your own nails for guitar playing is an art in itself which you will learn in future videos. For now, we want you to get familiar with the concept as well as get to know what tools we use to take care of them.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13581/13581 03 Guitar 101 Introduction to Nails Timing Corrected.mp4

lessons.lesson_title: G101.1.4 – The Classical Guitar Posture in Detail
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

In this lesson you will continue working on your classical guitar posture. Here we don’t experiment with alternative options, but we talk in detail about what you should do every time you play the guitar. Energy efficiency are the keywords that will lead you to find the best placement of every part of your body, from your knees, up to your head, and of course your hands.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13582/13582 04 Guitar 101 The Posture in Detail Timing Corrected.mp4

lessons.lesson_title: G101.1.5 – Learning the Names of the Fingers
lessons.lesson_content:
by

0 page
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13629/G101 1 5 - Learning the Names of the Fingers.mp4

course_title: G101.2 – PLAYING WITH THE RIGHT HAND
course_content:
Highlights

  • Producing the first sounds.
  • How to place the right hand.
  • Playing with the thumb (p).
  • Playing with index, middle and ring fingers (i, m, a).

Description

Hello, and welcome to the second course of the “Guitar 101". Now that you are familiar with your instrument and the classical guitar posture, you are ready to learn how to play with the right hand, the one that will pluck the strings, and produce the beautiful sound of the classical guitar.

The Guitar 101.2 course begins with helping you find the right place and position of the right hand; then you will learn how to play with the thumb while the remaining fingers help you keep a stable hand position; and finally, as you keep your thumb fixed, you learn how to play with the index, the middle, and the ring fingers separately. All will be played in open strings, which means you won’t be pressing any string with your left hand, as this is reserved for the next course.

Requirement

  • Having a Classical Guitar.
  • Knowing the classical guitar posture.

What's next

Next course: G101.3 - Playing With the Left Hand
course_short_description: Now that you are familiar with your instrument and the classical guitar posture, you are ready to learn how to play with the right hand, the one that will pluck the strings, and produce the beautiful sound of the classical guitar.

lessons.lesson_title: G101.2.1 – The Right Hand’s Position
lessons.lesson_content:
by Scorewind Teachers

In this video we are going to produce sound with our right hand. There are various ways in which you can play the guitar; you can strum the strings with one single finger, or use all your fingers for a very virtuosic effect. You can also finger pick every string individually and produce single notes. In this lesson we will mainly focus on correctly placing the right hand and its fingers and get introduced to finger picking, one of the key elements of the foundations of the classical guitar technique.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13583/13583 05 Guitar 101 Right Hand Position timing correction.mp4

lessons.lesson_title: G101.2.2 – Playing with the Right Hand’s Thumb
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Now we will play with the thumb of the right hand, also called p (“pulgar” in Spanish). The string is played by moving not only the tip of your thumb, but the whole finger (including moving the large muscle of the thumb). Via various exercises you will explore the freedom of movement of your finger in order to raise muscle awareness. Keep in mind to always rest the attacks of your thumb on the side of your right index finger. Do not let the thumb go behind your fingers nor too forward away from your hand, as this will alter the correct placement of your fingers.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13584/13584 06 Guitar 101 Playing With the Right Hand Thumb.mp4

lessons.lesson_title: G101.2.3 – Playing with i, m, a
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

In this video we will explore in detail how to play with the index, middle and ring fingers, also known as i, m, a (from the Spanish names: “índice, medio, anular”). The three main rules for playing with these fingers are: 1. Keep a well rounded hand; 2. Move your fingers from their largest knuckles; 3. The string touches the flesh just right under the place where your nail meets your skin.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13585/13585 07 Guitar 101 Playing with i m a.mp4

lessons.lesson_title: G101.2.4 – Right Hand Open String Exercise for Producing Sound
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

In this lesson you will learn an exercise that is essential to establish your right hand technique. It consists of only playing open strings, eight times each string. You’ll start with the repetitions with the i on the third string, then you change to the m on the second string, then a on the first string, and then p on the fourth, fifth and sixth strings. Remember to move your fingers from their big knuckles.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13594/13594 13 Right Hand Open String Exercise for Producing Sound.mp4

lessons.lesson_title: G101.2.5 – Right Hand Open Strings for Producing Sound (Exercise Only)
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

To help you with your daily practice we prepared this video which is the exercise of open strings for the right hand. Play along with this video as many times you would like. The goal is to produce a sound with the highest quality possible.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13595/13595 14 Right Hand Open String for Producing Sound Only Exercise.mp4

course_title: G101.3 – PLAYING WITH THE LEFT HAND
course_content:
Highlights

  • How to place the left hand.
  • Learn how to press the strings.
  • How to place the left thumb.

Description

Hello, and welcome to the third course of the “Guitar 101”. The same way that you previously worked only on your right hand, you will now learn the basics for playing with the left hand. After you complete this course, you will be ready to learn how to play with both hands at the same time.

So, with the Guitar 101.3 course, you will learn where to place your left hand and what is its correct positioning. Not only will you be working on what you do with your left hand fingers (a.k.a. 1, 2, 3,4), but also about your palm, wrist, elbow, shoulder, up to your collarbone. Another aspect you will focus on is the thumb of your left hand, the backbone of every note you will ever press with your left hand’s fingers. All this learning process will happen as you play exciting exercises such as hammering the strings with your fingers.

Requirement

  • Having a classical guitar
  • Knowing the classical guitar posture.

What's next

Next course: G101.4 - Playing with both Hands
course_short_description: With the Guitar 101.3 course, you will learn where to place your left hand, what is its correct positioning, and how to press the strings with your fingers.

lessons.lesson_title: G101.3.1 – Placing the Left Hand Correctly
lessons.lesson_content:
by Scorewind Teachers

In this lesson you will learn in detail how to place your left hand. The hand should be placed over the fretboard in the most relaxed and natural way possible. You can achieve this by shaking your hand and relaxing it just before you place it on the guitar. As you follow the video you will have the chance to practice various times placing the hand on the fretboard, including placing your hand on the so-called “first position”.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13586/13586 08 Guitar 101 Placing the Left Hand Correctly.mp4

lessons.lesson_title: G101.3.2 – Pressing Strings With Fingers of the Left Hand
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Now that you know how to place your left hand, you can learn how to use your fingers correctly. Via various progressive exercises, such as hammering randomly the strings with your fingers or hammering them precisely on a specific fret, you will discover the very foundation of playing with the left hand.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13588/13588 09 Guitar 101 Pressing the strings with left hand fingers.mp4

lessons.lesson_title: G101.3.3 – Placing the Left Hand’s Thumb
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

The left thumb plays a huge role in your playing, even though it doesn’t press or pluck a string. Your thumb should always be placed straight, like your other left hand fingers, and it should rest just behind them, on the guitar neck’s back (and not placed on top of the neck). Keep in mind that you don’t need to do a lot of strength with your thumb to help your other fingers to press the strings (there is a perfect balance to it).
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13589/13589 10 Guitar 101 Placing the left hand Thumb.mp4

course_title: G101.4 – PLAYING WITH BOTH HANDS
course_content:
Highlights

  • Press and play at the same time.
  • Exercises for playing with both hands.

Description

Hello, and welcome to the fourth course of the “Guitar 101”. So far, you’ve got introduced to the classical guitar, the posture, and how to play separately with the right hand and with the left hand. Now it’s finally time to bring all this knowledge together and play with both hands at the same time.

This skill will be presented to you with progressive difficulty, which means you will begin by working on one single finger of the left hand (1), as you play with your thumb of the right hand; then you will do the same thing with the remaining fingers.

Requirement

  • Having a classical guitar.
  • Knowing the classical guitar posture.
  • Knowing the basic rules of playing with each hand separately.

What's next

Next course: G102.1 - The Strings' Note Names and Numbers - Basses With p
course_short_description: This is the final course of the Guitar 101 method.  Now it’s finally time to bring together all that you've learned and play with both hands at the same time.

lessons.lesson_title: G101.4.1 – Introduction to Playing with Both Hands
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

In this video you will combine plucking a string with your right hand and pressing at the same time with a finger of your left hand. In this introduction you will play with your thumb while pressing the fifth fret of the sixth string with your finger 1 (index). We chose to start here because it's the easiest possible placement and movement you can make with both hands.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13590/13590 11 Guitar 101 Introduction to Playing with Both Hands.mp4

lessons.lesson_title: G101.4.2 – Introduction to Playing With Both Hands (Exercise)
lessons.lesson_content:
by Scorewind Teachers

In this lesson you will apply what you’ve learned on the previous videos to every finger of the left hand (1, 2, 3, 4). We keep the hand in the fifth position and we pluck all the notes with p (thumb of the right hand), with a small rhythmic motif: “Long, Short, Short”.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13593/13593 12 Guitar 101 Introductory Exercise to Playing With Both Hands Explanation.mp4

course_title: G102.1 – THE STRINGS’ NOTE NAMES AND NUMBERS – BASSES WITH p
course_content:
Highlights

  • Learn the names of the strings.
  • Play with the thumb, index, middle and ring fingers.
  • Cross bass strings with the thumb.

Description

In this course we will reinforce our knowledge of finger names, learn the names of the strings (by number and note name), and we will start playing on our guitars! During our playing sessions, we will first go through all the strings of our instruments and then we will be focusing on the lowest strings that are called the bass strings, which are E, A and D strings.

Requirement

  • Having a classical guitar.
  • Knowing the classical guitar posture.
  • Knowing the basic rules of playing with the right hand

What's next

Next course: G102.2 - The Strings' Note Names and Numbers - Trebles With i,m,a
course_short_description: In this course we will reinforce our knowledge of finger names, learn the names of the strings (by number and note name), and we will start playing on our guitars! We'll play first all the strings, and then we'll focus on the lowest strings that are called the bass strings, the E, A and D strings.

lessons.lesson_title: G102.1.1 – Revision of the Names of the Right Hand Fingers
lessons.lesson_content:
We will start this chapter by remembering the names given to the right hand fingers; “p i m a”. As there are quite a few finger combinations to play wonderful melodies, getting fluent in recalling which letter stands for what finger plays a very crucial role in learning how to play the guitar. 

The letters we use to define our right hand fingers are the initial letters of Spanish words indicating the fingers; p for pulgar (thumb), i for indice (index finger), m for medio (middle finger) and a for anular (ring finger).
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13630/G102 1 1 - Revision of the names of the fingers.mp4

lessons.lesson_title: G102.1.2 – Learning the Number & Note Names of the Strings
lessons.lesson_content:
As there are plenty of strings on the guitar, there are also various ways of calling them! During our future lessons we will sometimes refer to the strings by their note names (E, A, D, g, b, e) and sometimes by their number in the row of strings (6th, 5th, 4th, 3rd, 2nd, 1st). 

Although it might sound confusing at first, this duality comes from a very valid reason; when talking about melodies, indicating the note name gains importance over the numbers. We wouldn’t say “Play the C after the 4th string louder”, but we would say “Play the C after the D louder”. 

But then again, guitar having many strings, plenty of notes to cover, and many notes that can be played on various strings, at times we approach certain hand positions by shape and number coordination rather than note names, such as “place your 2nd finger on the 3rd fret of the 4th string” instead of “play the F that is the second octave of the instrument on the lowest possible string”.

So, in short, we will start our journey by learning the names and numbers of the strings for future convenience!
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13677/G102 1 2 - Learning the number & note names of the strings.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13677/13677 G102 1 2 - Learning the Number & Note Names of the Strings.xml

lessons.lesson_title: G102.1.3 – Run Through the Six Strings Repeating 8x per String
lessons.lesson_content: Here we go, we are going to make some noise now! In this lesson we will start playing the open strings with a healthy right hand position that guarantees the most efficient movement. Although it looks simple to do, we invite you to pay a great deal of attention to moving your fingers from the knuckles and to not lift your hand up while plucking the strings. Simple exercises help us learn all sorts of complex things.
