lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13631/G102 1 3 - Run Through the Six Strings Repeating 8x per string.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13631/G102 1 3 and 4 - Run Through the Six Strings Repeating 8x per String.xml

lessons.lesson_title: G102.1.4 – Run Through the Six Strings Repeating 8x per String (Exercise)
lessons.lesson_content:
This video is for you to play along while looking at the score explained in the previous lesson without interruption. 

Keep in mind!

Play each note with the indicated finger mentioned on the score (p for thumb, i for index finger, m for middle finger and a for ring finger).

Move your fingers from the big knuckles.

Every time you pluck the string, touch the fingertip to your palm to guarantee that you are moving from the big knuckles.

Make sure that other fingers are resting over or near the strings they are associated with.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13632/G102 1 4 - Run Through the Six Strings Repeating 8x per string (Exercise).mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13632/G102 1 3 and 4 - Run Through the Six Strings Repeating 8x per String.xml

lessons.lesson_title: G102.1.5 – Crossing the Bass Strings With p, With Repetitions of 4x, 2x, and 1x per String
lessons.lesson_content: As you might have noticed, we assign i, m, and a fingers per string, but the thumb gets to be in control of all three of the bass strings. Because of this reason, we need to give special importance to the agility of this finger. In this lesson you will gain control over string crossing between the bass strings, and at the last bit of the exercise you will get to feel how those bassy notes vibrate and blend to each other!
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13633/G102 1 5 - Playing p while changing bass strings with repetitions of 4x 2x and 1x per string.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13633/G102 1 5 and 6 - Playing p While Changing Bass Strings With Repetitions of 4x 2x and 1x per String.xml

lessons.lesson_title: G102.1.6 – Crossing the Bass Strings With p, With Repetitions of 4x, 2x, and 1x per String (Exercise)
lessons.lesson_content:
This video is for you to play along while looking at the score explained in the previous lesson without interruption. 

Remember to rest your three fingers (i m and a) on the strings they are usually assigned to. This way you make sure that you are not plucking the string by moving your wrist or your front arm excessively. We don’t want either of them because less movement means less energy cost, so by the end of perfecting this technique you will be able to play for a longer period without getting tired!
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13634/G102 1 6 - Playing p while changing bass strings with repetitions of 4x 2x and 1x per string (Exercise).mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13634/G102 1 5 and 6 - Playing p While Changing Bass Strings With Repetitions of 4x 2x and 1x per String.xml

course_title: G102.2 – THE STRINGS’ NOTE NAMES AND NUMBERS – TREBLES WITH i,m,a
course_content:
Highlights

  • Learn the names of the strings.
  • Practice with "i, m, a" fingers.
  • Learn right hand finger exchange on two strings.

Treble strings are the ones we start playing our first melodies on. Which is why it is important to start establishing a healthy right hand technique right away!

Plenty of repertoire played on classical guitar uses exchange between two or more strings to create a smooth sound because when we play on strings interchangingly we get to let the sound stay longer and blend to each other harmoniously. In this course we will start easy and challenge ourselves bit by bit to reach a smooth transition between various string combinations.

Requirement

  • Having a classical guitar.
  • Knowing the classical guitar posture.
  • Knowing the basic rules of playing with the right hand

What's next

Next course: G102.3 - The Figueta Technique
course_short_description: Treble strings are the ones we start playing our first melodies on. Which is why it is important to start establishing a healthy right hand technique right away! In this course we will start easy and challenge ourselves bit by bit to reach a smooth transition between various string combinations.

lessons.lesson_title: G102.2.1 – Playing i m on Treble Strings With Repetitions of 4x, 2x, and 1x per String
lessons.lesson_content: In this video we will focus on how to move our index finger and our middle finger while resting the rest of our fingers on the strings they are assigned to. This way we establish finger independency in a controlled environment. The exchange between strings will get quicker as the exercise goes on, leading us to create a smooth transition between our movements.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13635/G102 1 7 - Playing i m on treble strings with repetitions of 4x 2x and 1x per string.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13635/13635 G102 1 7 and 8 - Playing i m on Treble Strings With Repetitions of 4x 2x and 1x per String.xml

lessons.lesson_title: G102.2.2 – Playing i m on Treble Strings With Repetitions of 4x, 2x, and 1x per String (Exercise)
lessons.lesson_content:
This video is for you to play along while looking at the score explained in the previous lesson without interruption. 

Don’t mind us repeating this as there is plenty to focus on and not everything can be remembered at the same time;

Pay attention to not lean down to see your fingers! You can do this control with a little bit of a head tilt at first, and sooner or later your muscle memory will establish and you will get to know where your fingers are without having the need to see them.

And, of course, touch the fingertips to your palm to make sure you are moving from the big knuckles. ;)
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13636/G102 1 8 - Playing i m on treble strings with repetitions of 4x 2x and 1x per string (Exercise).mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13636/13635 G102 1 7 and 8 - Playing i m on Treble Strings With Repetitions of 4x 2x and 1x per String.xml

lessons.lesson_title: G102.2.3 – Playing i a on Treble Strings With Repetitions of 4x, 2x, and 1x per String
lessons.lesson_content: Depending on the person, gaining control over certain fingers might feel easier than the other fingers. Usually there is a tendency to “pluck away” with the ring finger rather than plucking towards the palm of our right hands; this may be due to the visibility of the ring finger being much less than the middle finger. So while working on this exercise pay attention to not tighten your ring and little fingers, but rather aim to make a round movement.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13637/G102 1 9 - Playing i a on treble strings with repetitions of 4x 2x and 1x per string.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13637/G102 1 9 and 10 - Playing i a on Treble Strings With Repetitions of 4x 2x and 1x per String V2.xml

lessons.lesson_title: G102.2.4 – Playing i a on Treble Strings With Repetitions of 4x, 2x, and 1x per String (Exercise)
lessons.lesson_content:
This video is for you to play along while looking at the score explained in the previous lesson without interruption. 

Try to apply the movement you must have established so far with your index finger to your ring finger. Fingers can learn from each other. By discovering what is more natural for you, you can unlock a lot of levels of difficulties because the moment one finger does one thing well, it becomes the reference point.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13638/G102 1 10 - Playing i a on treble strings with repetitions of 4x 2x and 1x per string (Exercise).mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13638/G102 1 9 and 10 - Playing i a on Treble Strings With Repetitions of 4x 2x and 1x per String.xml

lessons.lesson_title: G102.2.5 – Playing m a on Treble Strings With Repetitions of 4x, 2x, and 1x per String
lessons.lesson_content: In order to perfect all sorts of right hand combinations that we will be using later on while playing melodies, this time we will focus on the plucking exchange between our middle fingers and our ring fingers. Aim for an even sound at this point as the strength we use to pluck the strings can fluctuate from one finger to the other at the beginning.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13639/G102 1 11 - Playing m a on treble strings with repetitions of 4x 2x and 1x per string.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13639/G102 1 11 and 12 - Playing m a on Treble Strings With Repetitions of 4x 2x and 1x per String.xml

lessons.lesson_title: G102.2.6 – Playing m a on Treble Strings With Repetitions of 4x, 2x, and 1x per String (Exercise)
lessons.lesson_content:
This video is for you to play along while looking at the score explained in the previous lesson without interruption. 

Fingertips to the palm, and fingers on “vacation” resting on the assigned strings in order to guarantee not moving away from the strings. You are doing a great job!
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13640/G102 1 12 - Playing m a on treble strings with repetitions of 4x 2x and 1x per string (Exercise).mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13640/G102 1 11 and 12 - Playing m a on Treble Strings With Repetitions of 4x 2x and 1x per String.xml

course_title: G102.3 – THE FIGUETA TECHNIQUE
course_content:
Highlights

  • Learn the Figueta technique.
  • Learn your first "pima" arpeggio.
  • Play with a non-fixed right hand position.

Description

One powerful and unique (and cool!) feature of guitar repertoire is that we get to play very low and very high notes “effortlessly” in comparison to many other instruments. This is because we have all these many strings at hand and of course, because we have a well established “Figueta technique”. In this course we will cover the basics necessary for us to master this wondrous technique.

Requirement

  • Knowing the classical guitar posture.
  • Knowing the basic rules of playing with the right hand.
  • Knowing the guitar string names (notes & numbers.)

What's next

Next course: G102.4 - Preparation for Arpeggio Technique
course_short_description: One powerful feature of the guitar is that we get to play very low and very high notes “effortlessly”. This is because we have all these many strings at hand and of course, because we have a well established “Figueta technique”. In this course we will cover the basics of this wondrous technique.

lessons.lesson_title: G102.3.1 – p i Figueta Technique with Repetitions of 4x, 2x, and 1x
lessons.lesson_content: We start our journey to learn the Figueta Technique by exchanging between our thumb and our index finger. During this session we will be moving our thumb between the three bass strings it is assigned to and gradually cut down on repetitions to practice a smoother transition between the strings. Pay attention to rounding up your hand and movements and rest the rest (!) of the fingers on the strings they are assigned to.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13641/G102 2 1 - P i Figueta Technique with repetitions of 4x 2x and 1x.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13641/G102 2 1 and 2 - P i Figueta Technique With Repetitions of 4x 2x and 1x V2.xml

lessons.lesson_title: G102.3.2 – p i Figueta Technique With Repetitions of 4x 2x and 1x (Exercise)
lessons.lesson_content:
This video is for you to play along while looking at the score explained in the previous lesson without interruption. 

Try not to bend towards the guitar in order to look at the strings, use a small head tilt instead, if necessary.

And remember to move your fingers from… that’s right, from the big knuckles!
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13642/G102 2 2 - P i Figueta Technique with repetitions of 4x 2x and 1x (Exercise).mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13642/G102 2 1 and 2 - P i Figueta Technique With Repetitions of 4x 2x and 1x V2.xml

lessons.lesson_title: G102.3.3 – p m Figueta Technique With Repetitions of 4x 2x and 1x
lessons.lesson_content: You might be part of a large group of people with a tendency to lift up the index finger (p) in order to control (or see) better the movement of the middle finger (m) while playing this exercise. To make sure you are not doing this, pay attention to keeping your fingers that are on vacation on or over the assigned strings.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13643/G102 2 3 - P m Figueta Technique with repetitions of 4x 2x and 1x.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13643/G102 2 3 and 4 - P m Figueta Technique With Repetitions of 4x 2x and 1x.xml

lessons.lesson_title: G102.3.4 – p m Figueta Technique With Repetitions of 4x 2x and 1x (Exercise)
lessons.lesson_content:
This video is for you to play along while looking at the score explained in the previous lesson without interruption. 

Remember to touch the finger tip of your middle finger (m) to your palm while doing this exercise! You will thank yourself later for establishing such a good and healthy technique from the start!
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13644/G102 2 4 - P m Figueta Technique with repetitions of 4x 2x and 1x (Exercise).mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13644/G102 2 3 and 4 - P m Figueta Technique With Repetitions of 4x 2x and 1x.xml

lessons.lesson_title: G102.3.5 – P a Figueta Technique With Repetitions of 4x 2x and 1x
lessons.lesson_content: This exercise will come in handy for you, if you have established a fine control over moving from the big knuckles so far. The thing to pay greater attention to is to make sure that the pinky is not going rebel while the ring finger (a) is plucking the string. Our pinkies (you know the typical “fancy tea cup hold” do like to stay apart from the rest of the fingers at times, and now is a good time to make sure that they are united.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13645/G102 2 5 - P a Figueta Technique with repetitions of 4x 2x and 1x V2.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13645/G102 2 5 and 6 - P a Figueta Technique With Repetitions of 4x 2x and 1x.xml

lessons.lesson_title: G102.3.6 – p a Figueta Technique With Repetitions of 4x 2x and 1x (Exercise)
lessons.lesson_content:
This video is for you to play along while looking at the score explained in the previous lesson without interruption. 

During the repetitions you might start to notice dynamic changes between each note. This usually happens when one finger gains better control over their actions then the other. You have been playing with your thumb way more in comparison to any other finger you have been using. So pay attention to balancing the volume of each note bit by bit.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13646/G102 2 6 - P a Figueta Technique with repetitions of 4x 2x and 1x (Exercise).mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13646/G102 2 5 and 6 - P a Figueta Technique With Repetitions of 4x 2x and 1x.xml

course_title: G102.4 – PREPARATION FOR ARPEGGIO TECHNIQUE
course_content:
Highlights

  • Learn to play the "pima" arpeggio.
  • Play with a non-fixed right hand position.

Description

Until now, all our fingers, unless needed, were resting on the strings during their vacation. This was crucial to establish a healthy right hand position. But as we go further, we will start to loosen up from this fixed position. Because we need to let the strings ring freely as well, and because in the near future we will start adjusting the angle of our right hand rather diagonally in order to create a nice and even sound throughout whole strings, and we reach this even sound by plucking the strings on an imaginary line parallel to the bridge. To get close to this, we will first learn to play on the open strings with a “non fixed” position!

Requirement

  • Knowing the classical guitar posture.
  • Knowing the basic rules of playing with the right hand.
  • Knowing the guitar string names (notes & numbers.)

What's next

Next course: G102.5 - The Arpeggio Technique
course_short_description: Until now, all our fingers, unless needed, were resting on the strings during their vacation. This was crucial to establish a healthy right hand position. But as we go further, we will start to loosen up from this fixed position. Here we will learn to play the open strings with a “non-fixed” position!

lessons.lesson_title: G102.4.1 – Playing p while changing from fixed to non-fixed position
lessons.lesson_content: First thing first; let’s analyze the difference between fixed and non-fixed position while playing with the finger we played most notes with so far! We will simply practice the transition between putting our index (i), middle (m) and ring fingers (a) on the strings as they are used to, and then raising them off the strings slightly (not away!) and repeat the same thumb movement we are used to do with this difference.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13647/G102 2 7 - Playing p while changing from fixed to non fixed position.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13647/G102 2 7 and 8 - Playing p while changing from fixed to non fixed position.xml

lessons.lesson_title: G102.4.2 – Playing p while changing from fixed to non-fixed position (Exercise)
lessons.lesson_content:
This video is for you to play along while looking at the score explained in the previous lesson without interruption. 

Remember to control your hand movement to not go away from the strings with each plucking, technically the notion of the thumb does not need to change with the alteration we did to the rest of our fingers.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13648/G102 2 8 - Playing p while changing from fixed to non fixed position (Exercise).mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13648/G102 2 7 and 8 - Playing p while changing from fixed to non fixed position.xml

lessons.lesson_title: G102.4.3 – Playing i m a with non-fixed position
lessons.lesson_content: In order to “let ring” the sound, a non-fixed position is crucial! When we rest our fingers on the strings, we stop the vibration of the string, hence cutting the sound, and to be honest this is needed in some occasions as well. So with this exercise we will learn to swap between the two different sounding techniques; we will let the sound loose with non-fixed position, and cut the sound dry with the fixed position.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13649/G102 2 9 - Playing i m a with non fixed position.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13649/G102 2 9 and 10 - Playing i m a with non fixed position.xml

lessons.lesson_title: G102.4.4 – Playing i m a with non-fixed position (Exercise)
lessons.lesson_content:
This video is for you to play along while looking at the score explained in the previous lesson without interruption. 

Even if you rest your fingers right away on the strings in fixed position, you still might need to pay attention to have a plucking starting from the big knuckles of your fingers, so keep that in mind and touch the palm!
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13650/G102 2 10 - Playing i m a with non fixed position (Exercise) V2.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13650/G102 2 9 and 10 - Playing i m a with non fixed position.xml

lessons.lesson_title: G102.4.5 – Playing p i m a (arpeggio) with non-fixed position with one bar rest in between
lessons.lesson_content: How dreamy the guitar sounds when we use all our right hand fingers and let all the notes ring as much as they can with an arpeggio, right? In order to achieve this beautiful sound, we need to start controlling our plucking with a non-fixed position, while our thumb (p) crosses from one string to the other as it is used to. Since at this point there is no more string contact to rely on, we are going to start playing these arpeggios with one bar length of rest in the middle. This way we have time to adjust our thumb (p) to the next string on the air and start the next bar with this confidence!
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13651/G102 2 11 - Playing p i m a (arpeggio) with non fixed position with one bar rest in between.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13651/G102 2 11 and 12 - Playing p i m a (arpeggio) with non fixed position with one bar rest in between.xml

lessons.lesson_title: G102.4.6 – Playing p i m a (arpeggio) with non-fixed position with one bar rest in between (Exercise)
lessons.lesson_content:
This video is for you to play along while looking at the score explained in the previous lesson without interruption. 

Attention! Do not bend over the guitar to see the strings. You might want to tilt your head a little and look down to see your fingers a little, but keep in mind, our goal is to teach our body how to play the instrument, not our eyes!
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13652/G102 2 12 - Playing p i m a (arpeggio) with non fixed position with one bar rest in between (Exercise).mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13652/G102 2 11 and 12 - Playing p i m a (arpeggio) with non fixed position with one bar rest in between.xml

course_title: G102.5 – THE ARPEGGIO TECHNIQUE
course_content:
Highlights

  • Learn many “pima” arpeggio combinations.
  • Develop a non-fixed right hand position.

Description

Harmony means the state of being in agreement or concord. A chord is any harmonic set of notes that are heard either simultaneously or in a row, in a given time. An arpeggio is a chord spread through a given time, in which the harmonious notes that compose a chord are played in a rising, descending or mixed order. Beautiful, sad, ugly, wonderful, etc.; each chord tells a story, and the story lasts longer when the chord is arpeggiated. Arpeggios can be found in accompaniments and melodies as a whole or as bits as well. Arpeggio technique is one of the most fundamental techniques of guitar playing. Be it classical music or any other genre, this technique shines out the potential and beauty of this instrument in a very complete way. And for this reason, we will start playing arpeggios right away!

Requirement

  • Knowing the classical guitar posture.
  • Knowing the guitar string names (notes & numbers).
  • Knowing the basic rules of playing with the right hand.
  • Introduced to the Figueta technique.
  • Introduced to right hand finger exchange between two strings.
  • Introduced to the basic "pima" arpeggio technique.

What's next

Next course: G102.6 - The Arpeggio Technique (more exercises)
course_short_description: Arpeggio technique is one of the most fundamental techniques of guitar playing. Be it classical music or any other genre, this technique shines out the potential and beauty of this instrument in a very complete way. And for this reason, we will start playing arpeggios right away!

lessons.lesson_title: G102.5.1 – Introduction to the Arpeggio Technique Practice
lessons.lesson_content: We have four fingers (p i m a) and six strings (E A D g b e). The number of combinations that fall under the arpeggio technique with the given fingers and strings is not infinite, but it surely is plenty! Before introducing any challenge with our left hand fingers that eventually will lead us to play wonderful melodies, we will first establish a strong connection to arpeggiation with our right hand.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13653/G102 3 1 - Introduction to the Arpeggio Technique Practice.mp4

lessons.lesson_title: G102.5.2 – Four Finger Arpeggio Technique – p i m a
lessons.lesson_content: In this lesson we will get used to preparing our thumb in advance while playing the arpeggio that we have worked on in the last step of the previous course, but this time with no interruption! Letting the strings ring and preparing the fingers in this process will create a smooth and connected sounding arpeggio.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13654/G102 3 2 - Four Finger Arpeggio Technique - p i m a.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13654/G102 3 2 and 3 - Four Finger Arpeggio Technique - p i m a. V2xml.xml

lessons.lesson_title: G102.5.3 – Four Finger Arpeggio Technique – p i m a (Exercise)
lessons.lesson_content:
This video is for you to play along while looking at the score explained in the previous lesson without interruption. 

From this exercise on; the repetitions are going to be longer. This is how a musician or a musician candidate would normally practice; by repeating something over and over. You might make a mistake here and there as you play, as there are many repetitions. This is okay. These exercises are recorded with this length so that you also practice “getting on your feet again”, and there is no other way of practicing this skill besides making a few mistakes here and there. So if you fail to play a note or two, instead of pausing the video, catch up with it whenever you can.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13655/G102 3 3 - Four Finger Arpeggio Technique - p i m a (Exercise).mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13655/G102 3 2 and 3 - Four Finger Arpeggio Technique - p i m a. V2xml.xml

lessons.lesson_title: G102.5.4 – Four Finger Arpeggio Technique – p a m i
lessons.lesson_content: The motion of p a m i actually comes in “handier” then the p i m a, since it is very similar to how we would naturally close our fingers to make a fist. Of course, in this case our hand is not going to become as tight as if we are making a fist, but you can explore this motion on your hand and then try to apply it to the exercise.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13656/G102 3 4 - Four Finger Arpeggio Technique - p a m i.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13656/G102 3 4 and 5 - Four Finger Arpeggio Technique - p a m i.xml

lessons.lesson_title: G102.5.5 – Four Finger Arpeggio Technique – p a m i (Exercise)
lessons.lesson_content:
This video is for you to play along while looking at the score explained in the previous lesson without interruption. 

While we repeat an exercise, we train our mind to think and recall certain information, and by the end of the repetition cycle, the information gets to be learned by and saved partially to our muscle memory. Our “muscle memory” learns much slower than the “mental memory” but on the plus side, once it figures something out, it can hardly forget it!

As you play, aim for an even sound and try to distribute your hand’s strength evenly between your fingers to pluck each string with equal attitude.

Careful to not curve your back to see your fingers! :)
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13657/G102 3 5 - Four Finger Arpeggio Technique - p a m i (Exercise).mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13657/G102 3 4 and 5 - Four Finger Arpeggio Technique - p a m i.xml

lessons.lesson_title: G102.5.6 – Four Finger Arpeggio Technique – p i m a p a m i
lessons.lesson_content: In this lesson we will start forming longer lasting patterns with our finger combinations by uniting the p i m a pattern with the p a m i pattern. Plucking with the ring finger (a) coming from the thumb  (p) and coming from the middle finger (m) are totally different experiences, so pay attention to how you reach the 6th string.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13658/G102 3 6 - Four Finger Arpeggio Technique - p i m a p a m i.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13658/G102 3 6 and 7 - Four Finger Arpeggio Technique - p i m a p a m i.xml

lessons.lesson_title: G102.5.7 – Four Finger Arpeggio Technique – p i m a p a m i (Exercise)
lessons.lesson_content:
This video is for you to play along while looking at the score explained in the previous lesson without interruption. 

While playing try to see the similarities and differences between the movements of your fingers; does your index (i) feel more confident plucking after the thumb (p) or after the middle finger (m)? Whichever feels smoother, try to apply the motion to the other one as well.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13659/G102 3 7 - Four Finger Arpeggio Technique - p i m a p a m i (Exercise).mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13659/G102 3 6 and 7 - Four Finger Arpeggio Technique - p i m a p a m i.xml

lessons.lesson_title: G102.5.8 – Four Finger Arpeggio Technique – p a m i p i m a
lessons.lesson_content: In this lesson we will swap the order of combination. Time in music changes things magically; simply by starting our phrase in this order, the sensation you will have will be altered in comparison to the previous exercise. You might feel the cycle shifting to a more melodic pattern in this one rather than sounding “complete” in each group of two bars like the previous step.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13660/G102 3 8 - Four Finger Arpeggio Technique - p a m i p i m a.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13660/G102 3 8 and 9 - Four Finger Arpeggio Technique - p a m i p i m a.xml

lessons.lesson_title: G102.5.9 – Four Finger Arpeggio Technique – p a m i p i m a (Exercise)
lessons.lesson_content:
This video is for you to play along while looking at the score explained in the previous lesson without interruption. 

While we pay attention to detail, we all tend to lose control of our breathing. Now that you are getting used to playing long lasting pieces, it is a nice moment to introduce this awareness to your practice habits. Try to see if this helps the notes sound smoother.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13661/G102 3 9 - Four Finger Arpeggio Technique - p a m i p i m a (Exercise) V2.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13661/G102 3 8 and 9 - Four Finger Arpeggio Technique - p a m i p i m a.xml

course_title: G102.6 – THE ARPEGGIO TECHNIQUE (more exercises)
course_content:
Highlights

  • Learn many “pima” arpeggio combinations.
  • Develop a non-fixed right hand position.

Description

G102.6 - THE ARPEGGIO TECHNIQUE (more exercises)

Requirement

  • Knowing the classical guitar posture.
  • Knowing the guitar string names (notes & numbers).
  • Knowing the basic rules of playing with the right hand.
  • Introduced to the Figueta technique.
  • Introduced to right hand finger exchange between two strings.
  • Introduced to the basic "pima" arpeggio technique.

What's next

Next course: G103 (soon to be released)
course_short_description: In this course you will be playing the rest of the beautiful sounding p i m a arpeggio combinations, designed to help you master finger independence on your right hand. After a certain point the combinations will start involving note repetitions, leading you to discover various melodic patterns.

lessons.lesson_title: G102.6.1 – Four Finger Arpeggio Technique – p i a m (exercise)
lessons.lesson_content: From this lesson on, the scores are self explanatory as they follow the approach presented in the previous course. Try to pay attention to details such as plucking the strings with a motion that starts from the big knuckles and keep your front arm steady and relaxed.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13662/G102 3 10 - Four Finger Arpeggio Technique - p i a m.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13662/G102 3 10 - Four Finger Arpeggio Technique - p i a m.xml

lessons.lesson_title: G102.6.2 – Four Finger Arpeggio Technique – p m i a (exercise)
lessons.lesson_content: With p m i a combination, our attention needs to last well until the ring finger (a), pay attention to not tighten up your pinky in order to pluck the 1st string and rather close your pinky towards your palm, following your ring finger (a).
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13663/G102 3 11 - Four Finger Arpeggio Technique - p m i a.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13663/G102 3 11 - Four Finger Arpeggio Technique - p m i a.xml

lessons.lesson_title: G102.6.3 – Four Finger Arpeggio Technique – p a i m (exercise)
lessons.lesson_content: Using our index finger (i) right after our ring finger (a) may feel alien at first; the reason for this is that the tendon to the index finger is usually separate from the other three (middle-ring-pinky) related to the muscle/bone connection, hence the sensation of smoothness needs practice when a and i are used in a row.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13664/G102 3 12 - Four Finger Arpeggio Technique - p a i m.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13664/G102 3 12 - Four Finger Arpeggio Technique - p a i m.xml

lessons.lesson_title: G102.6.4 – Four Finger Arpeggio Technique – p m a i (exercise)
lessons.lesson_content: In this lesson you will perfect the relation between the ring finger (a) and the index finger (i) with a preparation coming from the middle finger (m), most important thing to pay attention to during this exercise is to remember not to tighten up the little finger during playing and aim for even amount of pressure/strength/speed on each plucking!
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13665/G102 3 13 - Four Finger Arpeggio Technique - p m a i.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13665/G102 3 13 - Four Finger Arpeggio Technique - p m a i.xml

lessons.lesson_title: G102.6.5 – Three Finger Arpeggio Technique – p i m i (exercise)
lessons.lesson_content: From this lesson on we will start repeating notes instead of covering the whole p i m a combination. Each exercise will provide a different melodic feel to the playing, very enjoyable on their own. Try to pay attention to your emotions and chase the feelings you get in certain note combinations as a pre-exercise to learning about intervals in the future.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13666/G102 3 14 - Three Finger Arpeggio Technique - p i m i.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13666/G102 3 14 - Three Finger Arpeggio Technique - p i m i.xml

lessons.lesson_title: G102.6.6 – Three Finger Arpeggio Technique – p m i m (exercise)
lessons.lesson_content: Each hand being different, each finger also has a different length, strength and skill control level. Try to focus your attention on making each middle finger (m) plucking sound even throughout the exercise. There is a strong chance that your approach to plucking with middle finger (m) will have slight differences when coming from the thumb (p) or from the i (index finger). Oftentimes we will want at least a dynamic difference between repeating notes to provide musical richness to a melody, but in order to control such subtle differences, we first have to perfect our capability to playing even sounding notes.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13667/G102 3 15 - Three Finger Arpeggio Technique - p m i m.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13667/G102 3 15 - Three Finger Arpeggio Technique - p m i m.xml

lessons.lesson_title: G102.6.7 – Three Finger Arpeggio Technique – p i a i (exercise)
lessons.lesson_content: In this exercise you will work the relationship between the index finger (i) and the ring finger (a). As with the previous exercises we will repeat one note twice to explore yet another variation that can be performed with less strings. Pay attention to preparing your thumb to move onto the next string while playing the index finger.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13668/G102 3 16 - Three Finger Arpeggio Technique - p i a i.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13668/G102 3 16 - Three Finger Arpeggio Technique - p i a i.xml

lessons.lesson_title: G102.6.8 – Three Finger Arpeggio Technique – p a i a (exercise)
lessons.lesson_content: It is a good moment to point out some good old reminders; make sure to move from large knuckles and don’t let your pinky escape into different worlds! Don’t bend towards the guitar in order to see the strings but rather use your “already getting established” muscle memory and maybe look down to the guitar by tilting your neck -just a little!
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13669/G102 3 17 - Three Finger Arpeggio Technique - p a i a.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13669/G102 3 17 - Three Finger Arpeggio Technique - p a i a.xml

lessons.lesson_title: G102.6.9 – Three Finger Arpeggio Technique – p m a m (exercise)
lessons.lesson_content: Keeping up with the reminders; make sure to breathe in and out steadily during this exercise. Let the air fill your body in general, not just the upper part of your lungs. Remember, it is okay to make mistakes as it is always good to practice “catching up” and “not letting go”, and focus on producing an even sound with your middle finger (m) both after the thumb (p) and after ring finger (a).
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13670/G102 3 18 - Three Finger Arpeggio Technique - p m a m.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13670/G102 3 18 - Three Finger Arpeggio Technique - p m a m V2.xml

lessons.lesson_title: G102.6.10 – Three Finger Arpeggio Technique – p a m a (exercise)
lessons.lesson_content: In the final chapter of this course we will cover the last basic arpeggiation combination possible with the p i m a! We hope your right hand fingers gained quite some independence by now and your muscle memory is “cooking” to a point where you can perform these melodious exercises literally “with your eyes closed” :).
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13671/G102 3 19 - Three Finger Arpeggio Technique - p a m a.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13671/G102 3 19 - Three Finger Arpeggio Technique - p a m a.xml

course_title: Get Better at Slurred String Changes
course_content:
Highlights

  • Executing chromatic musical lines.
  • Controlling string crossings with efficient elbow moves.

Description

The end goal of this step-by-step guide is to play a lovely Valse that has a very bright and bittersweet melody, and exercises leading to it will give every player the comfort to execute the piece as delicately as it needs to be. The melody contains quite a few string crossings and a bit of chromatism but they are all reachable goals for a person that gained experience over valse rhythm, slurring notes and G major melodies.

Requirement

  • Proficiency in 3/4 time signature.
  • Mobility of left hand for diagonal shapes (rapid shifts or maintaining intervals between strings).
  • Swift string crossing abilities.
  • Proficiency in half, quarter, eight and dotted notes.

What's next

Next course: Perfect Your Classical Music Phrasing
course_short_description: The end goal of this step-by-step guide is to play a lovely Valse that has a very bright and bittersweet melody, and exercises leading to it will give every player the comfort to execute the piece as delicately as it needs to be.

lessons.lesson_title: Introduction to ‘Get Better at Slurred String Changes’
lessons.lesson_content: The end goal of this step-by-step guide is to play a lovely Valse that has a very bright and bittersweet melody, and exercises leading to it will give every player the comfort to execute the piece as delicately as it needs to be. The melody contains quite a few string crossings and a bit of chromatism but they are all reachable goals for a person that gained experience over valse rhythm, slurring notes and G major melodies.

lessons.lesson_title: Left Hand Workout – Speeding up Fingers (C Major) – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

While playing this exercise players must be careful about tilting the bow so the hair faces the player near the frog, and straightening the bow to widen the point of contact towars the tip. Meanwhile, the left elbow should be relaxedly hanging from the hand and left hand fingers can optionally hammer each note.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12133/3702 Left Hand Workout - Speeding Up Fingers (C Major).mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12133/3702 Left Hand Workout - Speeding up Fingers (C Major).xml

lessons.lesson_title: Case Specific – String Crossing – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

This is a good exercise to gain awareness about how much bow is used and when during playing various lenghts. Long notes should not be played in a way that they finish the bow, there needs to be at least a 3rd of the left for the last beat. Because when string cross happens at the tip of the bow the maneuver can be done only by the front arm.

lessons.lesson_title: Case Specific – String Crossing 3 – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

This a little “out of the ordinary” pattern is good to coordinate the right hand. Remembering that string crossing is a vertical move rather than horizontal can be helpful to leave a good amount of bow for the long note that will follow the string crossing.

course_title: Get Better at String Crossing Melodiously
course_content:
Highlights

  • Ending phrases with a decrescendo.
  • Controlling string crossings with efficient elbow moves.
  • Learning the tension-resolution sound of dominant and tonic chords.

Description

This course prepares the learner to play a melodic etude by Dancla from his book of 36 Easy and Melodic Studies, Op. 84. Each step leads the player to gain ease at the tonality, the rhythmic content and the specific challenges the player has to achieve successfully to play the piece with comfort and joy.

Requirement

  • Novice level of score reading ability. (slow but steady deciphering skills for the notes that coincide 1st position on the violin fretboard)
  • Proficiency in half and quarter notes.
  • Mobility of 2nd finger. (to switch between 1-23 / 12-3 hand positions)

What's next

Next course: Learn to Perform Musical Phrases Clearly
course_short_description: This course prepares you to play an etude by Dancla from '36 Easy and Melodic Studies, Op. 84'. Each step will lead you to gain ease at the tonality, the rhythmic content and the specific challenges to play the piece with comfort and joy.

lessons.lesson_title: Introduction to ‘Get Better at String Crossing Melodiously’
lessons.lesson_content: This course prepares the learner to play a melodic etude by Dancla from his book of 36 Easy and Melodic Studies, Op. 84. Each step leads the player to gain ease at the tonality, the rhythmic content and the specific challenges the player has to achieve successfully to play the piece with comfort and joy.

lessons.lesson_title: Bow Workout – String Crossing 2
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

This exercise should be carried on with a very slow and careful bow stroke. One must remember that crossing the string can be a vertical move rather than a horizontal move that in this case is mainly done by the front arm, meaning the right elbow does not need to move much. Make sure to twist the bow for the hair to face the player when approaching the frog while playing up bow, and twist the palm back towards the floor while playing down bow.

lessons.lesson_title: C Major Scale – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Playing the scale of the music piece is a very healthy workout for keeping the intonation clean from the first place. While playing C Major in this octave, the learner can use open strings or 4th finger, but the main goal is to realize and carry out the nearness of the 1st and 2nd fingers. The two fingers should touch each other rather than having a gap in between.

lessons.lesson_title: C Major Arpeggio and Inversions – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Various inversions starting from C are good for getting used to certain interval jumps and to reassure the tonal center. Players can prepare the finger position of the next note while playing the current note. This way of thinking can be applied to the string crossings as well.

lessons.lesson_title: Available notes in 1st position – C Major – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Available notes of a key on a violin’s certain position is very essential in cases where we play a piece that is in a key but goes above or below the general scale that we are used to play. This way we learn the correct pitch of notes of the key outside the field that the scale limits us to. For the curious ones: this practice system is commonly used in the Galamian method.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12177/3651 12177 Available Notes In 1St Position C Major.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12177/3651 Available notes in 1st position - C Major.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Case Specific – Open String Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

This exercise is eliminating the notes of the introduction phrase by making the string crossings the one and only challenge to face. One can play it without slurs first just to get the string cross coordination right, and then introduce the slurs the piece indicates. You can apply this way of practice to all hard passages you encounter, omit the challenge of the left hand to focus on the right hand.

lessons.lesson_title: Case Specific – Open String Exercise 2
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

This exercise is eliminating the notes of the second half of the introduction phrase by making the string crossings the one and only challenge to face. One can play it without slurs first just to get the string cross coordination right, and then introduce the slurs the piece indicates. This practice technique is recommended to apply to other passages as well.

lessons.lesson_title: Intonation Workout – Semitones on E String
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

To play a semitone in the 1st position, on most violins, one must feel the nail of the previous finger over the tip of the next finger. This tension can sound harsh in the beginning but if the second note is “aimed”, the resolution comes out and it sounds lovely. Make sure that your left elbow is not near your chest but rather pointing away from your body.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12164/3666 12164 Intonation Workout Semitones on E String.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12164/3666 Intonation Workout - Semitones on E String.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Intonation Workout – G Dominant Chord
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

From a harmonic perspective, this chord may sound surprising to learners of the violin. The tension that happens between the notes B and F needs to be realized for tuning it well. The diagonal relation of the 2nd and 1st finger is an essential workout for fine tuning the pitch. To tune them well on most violins the fingers would be so close that they could pushing each other.

course_title: Get Fluent at Slurring 4 Notes
course_content:
Highlights

  • Executing long lasting phrases that include fast bow strokes.
  • Playing eight note runs.
  • Learning to play long phrases that include slurs.
  • Learning to extend the 3rd finger to gain 12-34 hand position.

Description

This method uses a step-by-step guide prepared by the ScoreWind teachers to introduce the players to slurring longer passages than 2 notes. Goal piece at the end of the workout exercises is a wonderful musical piece, Number 5 from the Melodic Studies op.84 by C. Dancla. Although the name indicates serious practice, the pieces in this book have a lovely classical musical quality!

Requirement

  • Novice level of score reading ability. (slow but steady deciphering skills for the notes that coincide 1st position on the violin fretboard)
  • Proficiency in half, quarter, eight and dotted notes.
  • Mobility of 2nd finger. (to switch between 1-23 / 12-3 hand positions)
  • Proficiency in using 4th finger.
  • Proficiency in slurring 2 to 4 notes in one bow evenly.

What's next

Next course: Become Better at Long Lasting 8th Note Phrases
course_tag: half dotted quarter and eighth notes
course_short_description: This method uses a step-by-step guide prepared by the ScoreWind teachers to introduce the players to slurring longer passages than 2 notes. At the end of the exercises you will play Etude N. 5, Op.84 by C. Dancla.

lessons.lesson_title: Introduction to ‘Get Fluent at Slurring 4 Notes’
lessons.lesson_content: This method uses a step-by-step guide prepared by the ScoreWind teachers to introduce the players to slurring longer passages than 2 notes. Goal piece at the end of the workout exercises is a wonderful musical piece, Number 5 from the Melodic Studies op.84 by C. Dancla. Although the name indicates serious practice, the pieces in this book have a lovely classical musical quality!

lessons.lesson_title: Available notes in 1st position – D Major – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Normally when you hear something in D major you can often hear something starting in D, or maybe from A. It is exactly the point of this scale to start from the lowest possible note you can get on the violin that belongs to the scale of D major. This means that our first note will be the low G. This “taking you out of the traditional perception of tonality” helps you to learn what each pitch really sounds like. On a more technical end, make sure your elbows follow each other parallelly as you go up and down the scale.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13489/3649 13489 Available Notes in 1st Position D Major.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13489/3649 Available notes in 1st position - D Major.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Intonation Workout – Open String Checking for D Major – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

In this exercise the player gains confidence on placing the notes correctly, with or without the previous notes placed on the fingerboard. Hearing the open strings can train the ear and tune one’s ear to the tonal center. Using 4th finger is not necessary but recommended. When placing 2nd or 3rd finger, imagining the placement of the previous fingers can help.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12156/3678 12156 Intonation Workout Open String Checking for D Major.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12156/3678 Intonation Workout - Open String Checking for D Major.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Available notes in 1st position – G Major – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Available notes of a key on a violin’s certain position is very essential in cases where we play a piece that is in a key but goes above or below the general scale that we are used to play. This way we learn the correct pitch of notes of the key outside the field that the scale limits us to.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12178/3648 12178 Available Notes in 1st Position G Major.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12178/3648 Available notes in 1st position - G Major.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Left Hand Workout – Speeding up Fingers (G Major) – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

When playing this exercise learners must remember that the bow stroke is a simple long bow stroke and keep the left hand fingers as round as possible for precision of timing the 8th notes. Although hammering each note may not be necessary it can be useful to gain strength. Make sure to not press the strings to the fingerboard more than necessary. The tip of the finger and nail should not go all white but stay clear.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12154/3680 12155 Left Hand Workout Speeding up Fingers G Major.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12154/3680 Left Hand Workout - Speeding up Fingers (G Major).xml

lessons.lesson_title: Left Hand Workout – Speeding up Fingers (D Major) – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

It is important to remember that the bow stroke in this exercise is a simple long bow stroke, and the amount of notes played on it has no effect on how that movement goes. The left hand fingers must be as round as possible for precision of timing the 8th notes. Although hammering each note may not be necessary, it can be useful to gain strength. Make sure to not press the strings to the fingerboard more than necessary. The tip of the finger and nail should not go all white.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12155/3679 12155 Left Hand Workout Speeding up Fingers D Major.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12155/3679 Left Hand Workout - Speeding up Fingers (D Major).xml

lessons.lesson_title: D Major Scale with Slurs of 4 – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

When playing this exercise, try to use the entire bow divided into four equal parts for learning how to use the bow economically. String changes can be prepared while playing the last notes of the slur. Make sure to tilt the bow near the frog and straighten it towards the tip to have an even sounding bow stroke.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12180/3646 12180 D Major Scale with Slurs of 4.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12180/3646 D Major Scale with Slurs of 4.xml

course_title: Getting Familiar With Melodic Arpeggios and Thirds
course_content:
Highlights

  • Ascending and descending melodic arpeggios.
  • Slow to fast rhythmic challenges.
  • Closed and open broken thirds.

Description

This step by step method will help you practice an etude composed by Fernando Sor, with which you can explore ascending and descending melodic arpeggios, slow to fast rhythmic challenges, as well as both closed and open broken thirds.

Requirement

  • Completion of course: ‘First Position Fondations’.
  • Novice level of score reading ability. (slow but steady deciphering skills for the notes that coincide 1st position on the guitar fretboard)
  • Proficiency in quarter and eight notes.
  • Novice level of using the 4th finger.
  • Beginner level in left hand vertical finger extension.

What's next

Next course: Introduction to Chords and Arpeggios
course_short_description: This step by step method will help you practice an etude composed by Fernando Sor, with with you can explore ascending and descending melodic arpeggios, slow to fast rhythmic challenges, as well as both closed and open broken thirds.

lessons.lesson_title: Introduction to “Getting Familiar With Melodic Arpeggios and Thirds”
lessons.lesson_content: This step by step method will help you practice an etude composed by Fernando Sor, with which you can explore ascending and descending melodic arpeggios, slow to fast rhythmic challenges, as well as both closed and open broken thirds.

lessons.lesson_title: G Major Scale in First Position Two Octaves
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Practice this scale to get familiar with the notes that you will use on the piece. Follow the fingerings given by the score, paying special attention to the coordination between the second and third fingers when playing on the first string.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12110/12110 3740 G Major Scale 2 Octaves First Position.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12110/3740 G Major Scale in First Position (2 octaves).xml

lessons.lesson_title: Open Single Strings Speed and Rhythm – Guitar Exercises
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

In this exercise you will focus on the speed and coordination of you i-m, and m-i throughout the six strings. The short speed bursts are meant to teach your fingers to play faster and keep stability in quick changes between slower and faster rhythm.
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12109/3741 Open Single Strings Speed and Rhythm.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Arpeggio Right Hand Technique 1 – Guitar Exercises
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

In this step you can work the good positioning of your right hand, because p-i-m-a arpeggios require a stable and rounded placement of hand and fingers. Changing between strings, as given in the exercise, will add an extra level of challenge to keep that stability.

lessons.lesson_title: Open Broken Thirds All Available Notes of  C major – Guitar Exercises
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

This exercise will help you to get familiar with the technical challenges over the vertical finger extensions existing in this type of intervals. Make sure to feel comfortable playing them, because they often appear throughout the music of this era.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13547/13547 3743 Broken Open Thirds All Available Notes C Major.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13547/3743 Open Broken Thirds All Available Notes of C major.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Close Broken Thirds in G major – Guitar Exercises
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Close thirds do not require large finger extensions, as the open thirds usually do, but they often bring uncomfortable finger placement, and challenging finger independence for the left hand. Practice carefully this exercise and the thirds of the music piece will become easier for you.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13548/13548 3744 Broken Close Thirds G Major Start On D.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13548/13548 3744 Broken Close Thirds G Major Start On D.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Case Specific – Finger Independency in Intervals – Guitar Exercises
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

In the following exercise you will be focusing on intervals changes that might might be challenging in the piece. Your main focus should be to teach your fingers exactly where they should go, keeping a good legato and volume balance.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12107/12107 3745 Case Specific Etude 1 Op 44 Sor Focus On Passage.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12107/3745 Case Specific - Finger Independency in Intervals.xml

course_title: Introduction to Chords and Arpeggios
course_content:
Highlights

  • Focus on melody/harmonic treatment.
  • Left hand’s movement in chord blocks.
  • Right hand flow through technical arpeggios.

Description

Explore essential chords and arpeggios in this step by step method ideal for beginner players. In this etude the arpeggios have a more harmonic treatment, even though the intervals are also the melody of the piece. The goal is to move the left hand fingers in blocks of chords, while keeping a flowing movement of the right hand fingers through the strings to play the arpeggio.

Requirement

  • Completion of course: ‘Getting Familiar With Melodic Arpeggios and Thirds’
  • Novice level of score reading ability.
  • Beginner level in right hand arpeggiation.
  • Beginner level in using the right hand’s ring finger (a)
  • Stable tempo, and stable 8th notes on 2/4 bars.
  • Beginner level in left hand vertical finger extension.

What's next

Next course: Classical Homophony and Arpeggiation
course_short_description: Explore essential guitar chords and arpeggios in this step by step method ideal for beginner players. The etude by Fernando Sor focuses on the harmonic treatment of arpeggios. The main goal is to develop the right hand arpeggio technique.

lessons.lesson_title: Introduction to “Introduction to Chords and Arpeggios”
lessons.lesson_content: Explore essential chords and arpeggios in this step by step method ideal for beginner players. In this etude the arpeggios have a more harmonic treatment, even though the intervals are also the melody of the piece. The goal is to move the left hand fingers in blocks of chords, while keeping a flowing movement of the right hand fingers through the strings to play the arpeggio.

lessons.lesson_title: D Dominant Arpeggio in First Position with La Extention
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

This arpeggio might be challenging at first, for your fingers have to spread through the frets so that the 4th finger reaches well to the mid Fa# and the high La. Pay attention to the different sonority of this arpeggio as you reach to do, the 7th note that gives the dominant aspect to the chord.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12106/12106 3747 D Dominant Arpeggio With A Extension.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12106/3747 D Dominant Arpeggio in First Position with La Extention.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Case Specific – Arpeggio Right Hand Technique 2 – Guitar Exercises
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

In this step you can practice a chord change present on the piece while playing through its way of arpeggiating. In this case you need to have full control of your 'p-i, a, m' combination, and keep a precise rhythm.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12105/12105 3748 Case Specifit R H Arpeggio Technique 1.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12105/3748 Case Specific - Arpeggio Right Hand Technique 1.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Case Specific – Arpeggio Right Hand Technique 3 – Guitar Exercises
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

This exercise follow the same harmonic structure as the previous step, and the goal is also to gain control over the arpeggiation of the notes with the right hand, as well as getting familiar with this chord change, so common in that period.
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12104/3749 Case Specific - Arpeggio Right Hand Technique 2.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Broken Sixths in first position in C Major – Guitar Exercises
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Like the broken thirds, passages of intervals of sixths are pretty common in this music style. This exercise is ideal for the coordination of the fingers of the left hand, and for gaining control over playing with thumb-index, or thumb-middle, fingers of the right hand.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12103/12103 3750 Broken Sixths In First Position In C Major.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12103/3750 Broken Sixths in first position in C Major.xml

course_title: Introduction to D Major Fingerings
course_content:
Highlights

  • D major foundations.
  • Second position playing.
  • Ballance and use of all left hand fingers.
  • Broad scales, arpeggios, homophonic voicing, single slurs.
  • Thumb and bass line practice.

Description

This step by step method will help you building the foudantions for playing pieces in D major. Playing a piece in this tonality means that you will be practicing second position fingerings. It can be more challenging than playing in first position, because you have less access to open strings, which would help the left hand. Now you will be using in a constant your four fingers (1, 2, 3, 4), and here the secret for a good hand position is to make sure that your 4th finger is always near the fretboard, and horizontally aligned with your 1st finger. Specifically with this etude by Fernando Sor, you will practice scales of a broad range, homophonic voicings, arpeggios, single slurs, position changes, and fast flowing basslines.

Requirement

  • Beginner-intermediate level of score reading ability.
  • Beginner level in position changes.
  • Proficiency in 1st position scales.
  • Proficiency in the fast exchange between index and middle fingers (i,m).
  • Proficiency in stable left hand and control of all four fingers.
  • Comfortable with two parallel voice leading.
course_tag: half dotted quarter eighth and sixteenth notes
course_short_description: This step by step method will help you build the foudantions for playing in D major. Playing in this tonality means that you will be practicing second position fingerings. This tonality workout includes scales of a broad range, homophonic voicings, arpeggios, single slurs, position changes, and fast flowing basslines.

lessons.lesson_title: Introduction to “Introduction to D Major Fingerings”
lessons.lesson_content: This step by step method will help you building the foudantions for playing pieces in D major. Playing a piece in this tonality means that you will be practicing second position fingerings. It can be more challenging than playing in first position, because you have less access to open strings, which would help the left hand. Now you will be using in a constant your four fingers (1, 2, 3, 4), and here the secret for a good hand position is to make sure that your 4th finger is always near the fretboard, and horizontally aligned with your 1st finger. Specifically with this etude by Fernando Sor, you will practice scales of a broad range, homophonic voicings, arpeggios, single slurs, position changes, and fast flowing basslines.

lessons.lesson_title: D Major Scale on Second Position
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Playing D major scale on second position frees you from always having to play on the first position. Allow space between your left hand fingers and keep them horizontally aligned. Make use of the open strings to help you through this scale. If you want to go to the next level of difficulty, we suggest you practice it without any open strings. That will greatly improve the strength and agility of your left hand, as well as giving you a fingering model of a major scale that can be applied to any position of the fretboard. (Yes! No matter where you start your scale, if you play this same fingering without the open strings, it will always be a major scale!)
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12092/12092 3776 D Major Scale on Second Position.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12092/3776 D Major Scale in Second Position.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Scale of Available Notes of D Major on 2nd Position
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

This scale gives you the whole spectrum of notes that you can play of a D major scale on the second position. Make use of the open strings to help you play through the scale. Keep your left hand fingers horizontally aligned, and allow plenty of space between themselves. That solid hand disposition will promote stability and increase your speed.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12091/12091 3777 Scale of Available Notes of D Major on 2nd Position.mp4

lessons.lesson_title: D Major Arpeggio on Second Position
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Keep your left hand fingers rounded and always prepared right on top of each fret. If you directly play this arpeggio from the 2nd position, you won't have to be jumping between 1st to 2nd position. You can choose to play the low D on the 5th string, as that will give you the fingering model to play a major arpeggio enywhere on the fretboard.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12090/12090 3778 D Major Arpeggio on Second Position.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12090/3778 D Major Arpeggio in Second Position.xml

lessons.lesson_title: A Dominant Arpeggio
lessons.lesson_content:
A Dominant Arpeggio

This arpeggio is very similar with the A Major one, but here we add the 7th note of the chord, G natural; that turns the arpeggio into an A Dominant chord. You can use the G in the open third string to change your hand position as you play through the low to high registers of the arpeggio and back again to the low notes. This is a wide range arpeggio, therefore you have to find the right balance between finger extension and minor to major elbow and wrist adjustments. Throughout the video you will see how different the arm and hand look as I play in the low-mid-high registers.

lessons.lesson_title: E Major Arpeggio – Guitar Exercises
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

E major arpeggio on first position is one of the most full bodied chords for the guitar. The 4-2-3 finger extention on the low notes can be quite challenging, so make sure you get used to opening as much as possible your left hand fingers. You can play with the flow movement of your hand to support the adjustment of the 4th finger in both low and high G#'s.

lessons.lesson_title: Rhythm and Subdivision Workout
lessons.lesson_content:
Rhythm and Subdivision Workout

In this exercise you get to practice various subdivisions of the beat. We will always play the same note (D on fourth string), but we will progressively change it from quarter notes, to eighth notes, to sixteenth notes, and ending on a single half note. Besides caring about the precision of the subdivision and keeping the beat, you can focus on the exchange of your right hand fingers. You can do this exercise with the index-middle fingers only, but I would like to invite you to practice with every finger combination, and in the following order: m-i; i-a; a-i; a-m; m-a; (i-index; m-middle; a-ring finger or “anular”).

lessons.lesson_title: Slurred Appoggiaturas
lessons.lesson_content:
Slurred Appoggiaturas

Here you will practice slurred appoggiaturas with every single finger (1, 2, 3, 4), linking the slur to the open first string. In order to sound like an appoggiatura, the slur must be played really fast, like a small decoration on top of the main note, which is the open E. The slur must be clear. Don’t pull with too much strength, nor hit the fingerboard with your finger. That will make it sound dirty. Find the midpoint between releasing and pulling the string in order to reach a good sounding slur.

lessons.lesson_title: Case Specific – Extensions in Fast Passages
lessons.lesson_content:
Case Specific - Extensions in Fast Passages

In this exercise you have the chance to prepare yourself to play one of the hard passages of the piece. Take all the time you need before venturing into the piece. Speed and extensions are the two elements that together create this challenging passage. I recommend you to scan your posture note by note, and  find the places that will help your fingers the most. Your knuckles are the reference; are they too far or too close from the note you’re pressing? Adjusting your shoulder, elbow and wrist will certainly help you have a well rounded hand that can easily run through the passage.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13523/13523 Case Specific - Extensions In Fast Passages.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13523/13523 Case Specific - Extensions in Fast Passages.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Parallel Thirds in D Major
lessons.lesson_content:
Parallel Thirds in D Major

The most effective way to master this exercise is to make sure you keep your fingers prepared at all times. This means that each one of your fingers will be “floating” just above each of the four frets you will be using (from 2nd to 5th fret). This is most important when you’re playing in the low registers. If it is too tiring for your hand to stay wide open through the whole exercise, you can relax it once you reach the first two strings. That window will allow you to regain the strength you need to finish the exercise with a good hand.

lessons.lesson_title: Introduction to Barre of Two and Three Strings
lessons.lesson_content:
Introduction to Barre of Two and Three Strings

It is possible that you will be making your very first barré with this exercise; meaning that you will be pressing more than one string with just your first finger. Barrés can be done by pressing all the 6 strings with the index, but you can have smaller barrés, such as the two and three strings barrés. Because this is just an introduction exercise, we will only be practicing the barrés of two and three strings. The pressure must be even between the strings you’re pressing. Make sure that every note sounds clean. If this is not the case, you must find a different way to place your finger. Check out the video for the visual reference!
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13527/13527 Introduction To Barre Of Two And Three Strings.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13527/13527 Introduction to Barre of Two and Three Strings.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Case Specific – Divide Hard Passage 1
lessons.lesson_content:
Case Specific - Divide Hard Passage 1

The more we practice a piece, the more we get to know it, but there are of course different ways of practicing and how to approach a specific difficult passage. Here we get to learn first how to play the chromatic bassline, with its most efficient fingering, and then we add the melody on top of it. In classical guitar playing we can get to play many voices at the same time, but do we always know exactly what each voice is doing? Here you have the chance to really get to know the bass of this incredible musical moment.

course_title: Introduction to Piano With Romantic Era Etudes – Part 1 (Demo)
course_content:
Highlights

  • Playing accompaniment lines with the left hand.
  • Getting better at recognizing "call and response" style phrasing.
  • Making melodic arpeggios with the right hand.
  • Introduction to articulation in phrasing (slurred phrasings and staccato technique).
  • Playing dyads on the left hand (two notes played at the same time).

Description

This series of pieces are all in C Major, written by some of the most famous composers for piano pedagogy. They introduce elements that are used throughout the life of a piano player; accompaniment lines, melodic phrases and various ornamental phrases that are part of classical music. They train the two hands to work simultaneously while sharing the melody and they individually accompany each other in some others; all in a very accessible way. Although technical difficulties of each piece are rather similar within this collected group of pieces, they are not meant to be played precisely with the given order. Yet they can help each other out; since learning classical vocabulary is like learning a new language; knowing one piece WILL make it easier to learn the next one. There is a difficulty level rise to some extent towards the last pieces. You can listen to the whole set of pieces and start from whichever piece you feel the interest for. 

Requirement

  • Novice level of score reading ability (Reading notes on G clef).
  • Knowing basic note values (quarter, half, whole notes).
  • Novice level autonomy in both hands.
  • Familiarity with C Major key in mid register.

What's next

Next course: Introduction to Piano With Romantic Era Etudes - Part 2
course_short_description: In this piano course demo you will find pieces in C Major, written by some of the most famous composer for piano pedagogy. They introduce elements that are used throughout the life of a piano player.

lessons.lesson_title: Introduction to ‘Introduction to Piano With Romantic Era Etudes – Part 1 (Demo)’
lessons.lesson_content:
