Although technical difficulties of each piece are rather similar within this collected group of pieces, they are not meant to be played precisely with the given order. Yet they can help each other out; since learning classical vocabulary is like learning a new language; knowing one piece WILL make it easier to learn the next one. There is a difficulty level rise to some extent towards the last pieces. You can listen to the whole set of pieces and start from whichever piece you feel the interest for.

lessons.lesson_title: Practical Exercises for Beginners, Op. 599 – Etude No. 1
lessons.lesson_content:
by Carl Czerny

If you are right at the beginning of your path on learning how to play the piano, then this etude will be perfect for you. Here you will learn how to play five different notes with both hands and in different octaves. While playing this piece the learner can focus on the hand that is moving while the other one is resting on a long note.

lessons.lesson_title: Practical Exercises for Beginners, Op. 599 – Etude No. 2
lessons.lesson_content:
by Carl Czerny

In this step, you will explore a wider octave range of the notes you have played on the previous etude. You will start playing notes simultaneously, the half notes, and from time to time one hand moves individually. Try feeling the distinction between the functions of  the melody and bass line.

lessons.lesson_title: Practical Exercises for Beginners, Op. 599 – Etude No. 3
lessons.lesson_content:
by Carl Czerny

This piece is a nice introduction to a motif and technique that often appears in piano playing; where the left hand "echoes" the melody of the right hand soon after, which gives a sensation that can be described as "call and response". Here you will also have access to more notes.

lessons.lesson_title: Practical Exercises for Beginners, Op. 599 – Etude No. 5
lessons.lesson_content:
by Carl Czerny

In this etude the right hand gains autonomy and starts to play more active lines than the left hand. Accompaniment line is repetitive so it is aimed to not challenge the player much, but to teach the values of notes on both hands can alter. Here you also have the chance to work on your first melodic arpeggios on the right hand.

lessons.lesson_title: 100 Progressive Studies, Op. 139 – Etude No. 2
lessons.lesson_content:
by Carl Czerny

In this piece the chords are introduced for the left hand, but almost more importantly, the phasing of the right hand starts to cross the barline. Listening to the example, the learner can hear that the melody doesn't start on the 1st beat but rather starts in the previous bar and "falls" to the first beat of the next bar.

course_title: Introduction to Piano With Romantic Era Etudes – Part 2
course_content:
Highlights

  • Playing 8th notes.
  • Playing longer lasting slurred phrases.
  • Playing dyads on the right hand (two notes played at the same time).
  • Speeding up the right hand.
  • Playing basic arpeggiated accompaniment lines with the left hand.
  • Playing "alberti bass" accompanying figures with the left hand.
  • Playing a piece in 3/4 measure (ternary pulse).

Description

This series of pieces are all in C Major, written by some of the most famous composers for piano pedagogy. They introduce elements that are used throughout the life of a piano player; accompaniment lines, melodic phrases and various ornamental phrases that are part of classical music. They train the two hands to work simultaneously while sharing the melody and they individually accompany each other in some others; all in a very accessible way. Although technical difficulties of each piece are rather similar within this collected group of pieces, they are not meant to be played precisely with the given order. Yet they can help each other out; since learning classical vocabulary is like learning a new language; knowing one piece WILL make it easier to learn the next one. There is a difficulty level rise to some extent towards the last pieces. You can listen to the whole set of pieces and start from whichever piece you feel the interest for.

Requirement

  • Novice level of score reading ability (Reading notes on G clef).
  • Knowing basic note values (quarter, half, whole notes).
  • Novice level autonomy in both hands.
  • Familiarity with C Major key in mid register.

What's next

Next course: Scales and Finger Speed for Piano – Part 1
course_short_description: In this piano course (part 2) you will find pieces in C Major, written by some of the most famous composer for piano pedagogy. They introduce elements that are used throughout the life of a piano player.

lessons.lesson_content:

course_title: Learn to Perform Musical Phrases Clearly
course_content:
Highlights

  • Proficiency in dotted rhythms.
  • Slurring notes over the beat.
  • Performing a piece that includes a section in the relative minor key.
  • Executing clear sounding musical phrases.

Description

Number 4, from Dancla's Easy and Melodic Studies Op. 84, is a great piece of music for one to start with following when a phrase begins and ends. Phrases in music are like sentences that we speak, they start and they finish. In this piece, the arch shape phrases beginning calmly, opening up and landing down at a lower note than anything that happened before them show a very clear line of their structure. Try to fade out each ending note for the music to gain shape.

Requirement

  • Novice level of score reading ability. (slow but steady deciphering skills for the notes that coincide 1st position on the violin fretboard)
  • Mobility of 2nd finger. (to switch between 1-23 / 12-3 hand positions)
  • Proficiency in half, quarter and eight notes.
  • Proficiency in slurring 2 to 4 notes in one bow evenly.

What's next

Next course: Get Fluent at Slurring 4 Notes
course_tag: half dotted quarter and eighth notes
course_short_description: Number 4 from Dancla's Easy and Melodic Studies op.84 is a great piece of music for one to start with following when a phrase begins and ends. Phrases in music are like sentences that we speak, they start and they finish.

lessons.lesson_title: Introduction to ‘Learn to Perform Musical Phrases Clearly’
lessons.lesson_content: Number 4, from Dancla's Easy and Melodic Studies Op. 84, is a great piece of music for one to start with following when a phrase begins and ends. Phrases in music are like sentences that we speak, they start and they finish. In this piece, the arch shape phrases beginning calmly, opening up and landing down at a lower note than anything that happened before them show a very clear line of their structure. Try to fade out each ending note for the music to gain shape.

lessons.lesson_title: Rhythm Workout – 4th notes and 8th notes Combination 1
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

This exercise is eliminating the notes and making the rhythm the only challenge to face. Quarter notes should be played with a long bow stroke and the 8th notes with a short stroke that is mainly led by the wrist, palm and fingers.
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12162/3672 Rhythm Workout - 4th notes and 8th notes Combination 1.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Rhythm Workout – Dotted notes – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Dotted notes gain half the value of the note they would be without the dot. In order to learn when to finish them, this exercise places a rest in the space of the gained value so that the next note can start well on time. In the second step the value of the note can be played as it is.

lessons.lesson_title: Bow Workout – Staccatos 1
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Besides sounding shorter than the original value, staccato notes also have a specific way of starting. Player can try to use their index finger to start the motion on each staccato note. Notes should be played as evenly sounding as possible.

lessons.lesson_title: Bow Workout – Staccattos 2
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Stacatto notes need to start strong but they don't have to finish with a sudden cut like a shortened note. How to end them is as important as how to begin them. Players must try to relax their right hand right after the first attack. The note on the down bow should be played with a longer stroke to gain space.

lessons.lesson_title: Bow Workout – Staccattos 3
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Playing stacatto notes in a row can be challenging but once the start and end of each note individually is established it is a matter of combining. Practice these notes calmly and pay attention to your front arm muscles, they should not stay stiff at the end of a not or certainly not at the end of a passage.

lessons.lesson_title: Case Specific – Dotted quarter note combination
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

In this exercise the bow stroke is a simple long bow stroke and the player must keep the left hand fingers as round and ready as possible for precision of timing of the 8th notes. Although hammering each note may not be necessary it can be useful to gain strength.
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12157/3677 Case Specific - Dotted quarter note combination.xml

course_title: Master The Classical Guitar Arpeggios – Part 1
course_content:
Highlights

  • Developing a solid right hand arpeggio technique.
  • Executing Alberti bass style accompaniment.
  • Executing arpeggio accompaniment with thumb only.
  • Performing triplets.

Description

The part 1 of this course will progressively lead you through beginner-intermediate level in arpeggio technique of the Classical-Romantic era (over 200 years ago!) of the classical guitar.  With each one of these five etudes you will be introduced to the common arpeggio practice and how the composers applied it in their compositions. Stylistically and technically speaking, the guitar arpeggios of this era are characterised by combinations of the right hand finger that create complex textures out of a series of chord progressions. This means that throughout this method you will not be practicing horizontal arpeggios produced by the left hand, but the vertical textures offered by the right hand. The method consists of a selection of etudes from Le Papillon, Op. 50 by Mauro Giuliani, and 24 Progressive Lessons Op. 31 by Fernando Sor. There is a continuous rise in the difficulty level throughout the method, so it is recommended that you feel comfortable playing the etudes from the first steps before engaging on a harder piece of a later step. You can listen to the whole set of pieces and understand that they do share similar classical vocabulary, therefore knowing one piece WILL make it easier to learn the next one.  If you wish to further explore the classical arpeggio technique, check out our “Master the Classical Guitar Arpeggios – Part 2” available on Scorewind’s methods page.

Requirement

  • Intermediate level of score reading ability.
  • Familiarity with melodic arpeggios.
  • Fluency in melody playing in first position.
  • Fluency in playing chords.
  • Ability to play pieces in C, G and D Major.
  • Experience in performing parallel voices.

What's next

Next course: Master the Classical Guitar Arpeggios - Part 2

lessons.lesson_title: Introduction to ‘Master the Classical Guitar Arpeggios – Part 1’
lessons.lesson_content:
The part 1 of this course will progressively lead you through mid-beginner to intermediate levels in arpeggio technique of the Classical-Romantic era (over 200 years ago!) of the classical guitar.  With each one of these five etudes you will be introduced to the common arpeggio practice and how the composers applied it in their compositions. Stylistically and technically speaking, the guitar arpeggios of this era are characterised by combinations of the right hand finger that create complex textures out of a series of chord progressions. This means that throughout this method you will not be practicing horizontal arpeggios produced by the left hand, but the vertical textures offered by the right hand.

The method consists of a selection of etudes from Le Papillon, Op. 50 by Mauro Giuliani, and 24 Progressive Lessons Op. 31 by Fernando Sor.

There is a continuous rise in the difficulty level throughout the method, so it is recommended that you feel comfortable playing the etudes from the first steps before engaging on a harder piece of a later step. You can listen to the whole set of pieces and understand that they do share similar classical vocabulary, therefore knowing one piece WILL make it easier to learn the next one. 

If you wish to further explore the classical arpeggio technique, check out our “Master the Classical Guitar Arpeggios – Part 2” available on Scorewind’s methods page.

lessons.lesson_title: Le Papillon, Op. 50 – No. 3
lessons.lesson_content:
by Mauro Giuliani

This first etude is an ideal introduction to the world of the classical arpeggio. Of beginner level difficulty, the etude consists of the repetition of a simple, yet beautiful, harmonic progression. Note how you get to play the same chords in four different styles of arpeggio, and in a progressive manner as well, reaching to a faster playing everytime you repeat the sequence.

lessons.lesson_title: Le Papillon, Op. 50 – No. 11, Grazioso
lessons.lesson_content:
by Mauro Giuliani

In this etude you will work on a single arpeggio texture. It is one of the most common arpeggiated accompaniment, called the Alberti bass. It works very well for the guitar, for it allows the performer to still play long lyrical melodies above it. If you control this technique well, you will be able to play a lot of repertoire of that era.

lessons.lesson_title: Le Papillon, Op. 50 – No. 12, Alegretto
lessons.lesson_content:
by Mauro Giuliani

Similarly to the Alberti bass, this arpeggio combines a triad accompaniment with a lyrical melody. One of the challenges of this piece is to keep the stable beat of the 6/8 bar and differentiate singing melody and the arpeggiated accompaniment through the control of dynamics.

lessons.lesson_title: Le Papillon, Op. 50 – No. 13, Allegro
lessons.lesson_content:
by Mauro Giuliani

This etude from Giuliani is one of the most loved ones by the modern guitarists. The composer successfully wrote an etude with fairly accessible difficulty that allows very virtuosic results even at beginner level. In this case, the bass line is the leading melody and the higher register gives the harmonic functions.

lessons.lesson_title: 24 Progressive Lessons, Op. 31 – Etude No. 6, Andante
lessons.lesson_content:
by Fernando Sor

This beautiful etude is a representative jewel of Sor’s arpeggiated ballads and laments. The bass line carries the most predominant melody, in which you can notice how it flows through the triads of the chords. Nevertheless, the notes played on the first string create a long melodic arc throughout the harmonic progression. Thus, pay attention to the voicings and dynamics.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13097/2281 24 Progressive Lessons, Op. 31 - Etude No. 6, Andante-1.mp4

course_title: Master The Classical Guitar Arpeggios – Part 2
course_content:
Highlights

  • Accompanying with the right hand.
  • Playing long lasting melodious bass lines.
  • Gaining proficiency in thumb arpeggio technique.
  • Applying pppima pattern to the arpeggios.
  • Placing the accompaniment to the middle voice.
  • Connecting the arpeggiated lines from bass to melody.
  • Developing an understanding for complex chord fingerings.

Description

The part 2 of this course will progressively lead you through intermediate level in arpeggio technique of the Classical-Romantic era (over 200 years ago!) of the classical guitar. With each one of these five etudes you will be introduced to the common arpeggio practice and how the composers applied it in their compositions. Stylistically and technically speaking, the guitar arpeggios of this era are characterised by combinations of the right hand finger that create complex textures out of a series of chord progressions. This means that throughout this method you will not be practicing horizontal arpeggios produced by the left hand, but the vertical textures offered by the right hand. The method consists of a selection of etudes from 24 Progressive Lessons Op. 31 by Fernando Sor and Le Papillon, Op. 50 by Mauro Giuliani. There is a continuous rise in the difficulty level throughout the method, so it is recommended that you feel comfortable playing the etudes from the first steps before engaging on a harder piece of a later step. You can listen to the whole set of pieces and understand that they do share similar classical vocabulary, therefore knowing one piece WILL make it easier to learn the next one.  If you wish to further explore the classical arpeggio technique, check out our “Master the Classical Guitar Arpeggios – Part 3” available on Scorewind’s methods page.

Requirement

  • Intermediate level of score reading ability.
  • Familiarity with melodic arpeggios.
  • Advanced level in melody playing in first position.
  • Fluency in playing chords.
  • Ability to play pieces in C, G, D, A and E Major.
  • Fluency in playing Alberti bass.
  • Fluency in performing parallel voicings (up to 3 voices).

lessons.lesson_title: 24 Etudes, Op. 35 – Etude No. 17, Moderato
lessons.lesson_content:
by Fernando Sor

An all time favorite for guitarists out there! This etude is one of the most oftenly played pieces by intermediate level students. It’s writing style differs from the etudes presented in Part 1 of our arpeggio method, but you will see that it works in a very similar way. Here the melody is more fluid than before, so pay attention to how it flows, and how the arpeggiated accompaniment can help you to lead the melody even better. Be precise with the slurs by the end of the etude.

course_title: Master The Classical Guitar Arpeggios – Part 4
course_content:

  • Exchanging between E Major and E minor tonalities within a piece.
  • Developing concentration skills through long lasting pieces.
  • Further development of barré and half-barré techniques.
  • Working on position shifting.
  • Development of dynamic range.
  • Introduction to tremolo.
  • Playing up till 8th position.
  • Executing single slurs in fast tempo passages.

course_content:
Highlights

  • Perfecting wide dynamic range.
  • Unraveling complex musical textures.
  • Establishing connection between contrasting musical ideas.
  • Developing drama in interpretation.
  • Further developing arppegiated barré chords.
  • Maintaining stable tempo and attitude in fast and long pieces.
  • Perfecting long arpeggio patterns.
  • Gaining expertise in position shifting.

lessons.lesson_title: Theme varies et 12 Minuets, Op. 11 – Menuet No. 7, Andante
lessons.lesson_content:
by Fernando Sor

The first etude of this method is a window to the operatic language of Fernando Sor. You can hear the drama, the scenes unfolding, the moment of romantic tragedy. Enjoy the discovery of new arpeggio styles and chord fingerings that make the deep harmonics of the guitar sound.

lessons.lesson_title: 24 Progressive Lessons, Op. 31 – Etude No. 18, Moderato
lessons.lesson_content:
by Fernando Sor

This slow ballad will give you the chance to work on bringing melodies that are integrated on the arpeggio forward. Image the clear voice of a singer only accompanied by her arpeggiated guitar. Meanwhile, careful with those barrés and keep the melody legato ;).

course_title: Master the Classical Guitar Arpeggios – Part 6
course_content:
Highlights

  • Gaining expertise in arpeggio techniques within parallel voicings.
  • Developing drama in interpretation.
  • Further developing arppegiated barré chords.
  • Maintaining stable tempo and attitude in fast and long pieces.
  • Perfecting long arpeggio patterns.
  • Gaining expertise in position shifting.

he part 6 of this course will progressively lead you through intermediate-advanced levels in arpeggio technique of the Classical-Romantic era (over 200 years ago!) of the classical guitar. With each one of these four etudes you will be introduced to the common arpeggio practice and how the composers applied it in their compositions. The course consists of a selection of etudes from 12 Etudes, Op. 29 and 24 Etudes, Op. 35 by Fernando Sor. There is a continuous rise in the difficulty level throughout the method, so it is recommended that you feel comfortable playing the etudes from the first steps before engaging on a harder piece of a later step. You can listen to the whole set of pieces and understand that they do share similar classical vocabulary, therefore knowing one piece WILL make it easier to learn the next one.

  • Advanced level in melody playing in various position.
  • Proficiency in right hand arpeggio techniques.
  • Proficiency in barré technique.
  • Proficiency in position changing.
  • Advanced level in playing chords.
  • Ability to play pieces in C, G, D, A and E Major.

course_title: Mid-Beginner Guitar Pieces From the Classical Era – Part 1 (Demo)
course_content:
Highlights

  • Learning to make notes last while the melody goes on on other voices.
  • Playing melody and bass line simultaneously.
  • Obtaining basic right hand arpeggio technique.
  • Developing the melodic arpeggio phrasings.
  • Applying voice leading to melodic phrases.
  • Playing a piece in 3/8 measure.
  • Obtaining basic left hand slur technique.

Description

This course (part 1) introduces the basic vocabulary of the classical romantic guitar, music that has been played for 200 years! Throughout the next 5 pieces you will greatly improve your skills on C major and G major tonalities. By practicing these etudes you will not only explore tonalities, but you will be progressively working on a wide range of scales, homophonic voicing, arpeggios, single slurs, position changes, and fast flowing bass-lines. The method consists of an etude selection from Le Papillon, Op. 50 by Mauro Giuliani, 24 Very Easy Exercises, Op. 35, and 24 Short Progressive Pieces, Op. 44 by Fernando Sor.

There is a continuous rise in the difficulty level throughout the method, so it is recommended that you feel comfortable playing the etudes from the first steps before engaging on a harder piece of a later step. You can listen to the whole set of pieces and understand that they do share similar classical vocabulary, therefore knowing one piece WILL make it easier to learn the next one.

Requirement

  • Intermediate level of score reading ability.
  • Familiarity with melodic arpeggios.
  • Familiarity with C, G, and D Major tonalities.
  • Fluency in melody playing in first position.
  • Familiarity with playing more than one note at the same time.

What's next

Next course: Mid-Beginner Guitar Pieces From the Classical Era - Part 2

course_title: One, two, three, waltz, two, three!
course_content:
Highlights

  • Executing vibrato on long notes.
  • Executing a 3/4 piece.
  • Executing dynamic changes per bar for musical phrasing.
  • Controlling half tone changes of 1st finger.
  • Getting used to feeling the pulse of the music.

Description

Valse (waltz) and other forms of 3/4 compasses play an important part in the classical repertoire. Most of us start playing an instrument with 4/4 pieces, which means getting into the rhythmic pulse of waltzes can take some little time to adapt. This method helps players to feel the 3 beat long bars and adds some new scales to the game.

Requirement

  • Intermediate level of score reading ability.
  • Mobility of 1st finger to extend backward.
  • Mobility of 2nd and 3rd fingers.
  • Proficiency in using 4th finger.
  • Relaxed right hand in order to execute dynamics.
  • Proficiency in half, quarter, eight and dotted notes.

What's next

Next course: Contrasting Musical Ideas

lessons.lesson_title: Introduction to ‘One, Two, Three, Waltz, Two, Three!’
lessons.lesson_content: Valse (waltz) and other forms of 3/4 compasses play an important part in the classical repertoire. Most of us start playing an instrument with 4/4 pieces, which means getting into the rhythmic pulse of waltzes can take some little time to adapt. This method helps players to feel the 3 beat long bars and adds some new scales to the game.

lessons.lesson_title: F Major Scale – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

F major uses lowered 1st finger and this causes the hand to expand to a position in which all 1st, 2nd and 3rd fingers are separated from each other. If this position is hard for the player, warming up the hand and stretching the fingers before holding the violin is recommended.

lessons.lesson_title: Bow Workout – Appoggiaturas – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

The slurred appoggiatura phrasing given in this exercise is very common to find in various classical music pieces. While executing such passages one should keep in mind that first note of each group can be played with a gesture as if one is “handing down” something to the next note.

lessons.lesson_title: Rhythm Workout – 3/4 – 1 – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

3/4 is not a complex timing, in fact, it almost corresponds to how our heart beat sounds! But training in 4/4 pieces at all times, one might want to take time to adapt to this pulse. While playing the notes, the players can count out loudly or in their minds till 3 to get used to the feeling of three beats in a bar.

lessons.lesson_title: Rhythm Workout – 3/4 – 2 – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Many 3/4 pieces include this rhythmic variation. Because in 3/4 bars, we tend to give more importance and show the 1st beat and the 3rd beat more than we show the 2nd beat. Getting used to the rhythm pattern, the player can start to feel the connection to the next bar via the 3rd rhythm and the figure becomes more circular than many very cornered 4/4 rhythmic patterns.

lessons.lesson_title: Bow Workout – Dynamic Changes – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Dynamic bow workout can be rather relaxing. It is very rewarding to focus on the breathing while playing since this helps out about the bow hand being relaxed. Players can explore the speed of bow throughout the dynamic change and alter their speed for gaining balance control.

lessons.lesson_title: Case Specific – Chromatism Intonation – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

When there is a challenge that takes us out of our comfort zone in two or more fronteers, it is good to eliminate the various difficulities and focus on only one element at a time. With this exercise we eliminate the rhythmic content of the piece and focus on semitone intonation.

lessons.lesson_title: Case Specific – Passage Practice – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

When you have a challenging passage, it's very good to work on practicing the various parts of the passage individually. Starting by playing the first note only, then playing the first note followed by the second note; starting from the beginning and adding the third; and then the fourth note, and so on. This way you are going forward in the passage and you reinforce what you just learned previously. You can do this with and without a bpm feeling, which will give you more, or less time to pause between the various parts of the passage. In this video we chose to make the exercise following the beat, but you are free to choose what works best for you.

course_title: Parallel Voicing in the Classical Era for Guitar – Part 1
course_content:
Highlights

  • Executing ornamentations.
  • Developing dotted rhythm reading and performing skills.
  • Performing lines with closed parallel 3rds in 1st and 2nd position.
  • Shifting to 5th position.
  • Getting better at chromatic shifts.

Description

With this course you will be practicing the art of playing parallel voices, which is one of the most used techniques in the classical-romantic repertoire. Specially throughout the music of Fernando Sor, you can easily find passages of parallel thirds, and sixths (both with close and open position), and also parallel octaves, though this is a more common practice of Mauro Giuliani. Therefore this method consists of an etude selection from Fernando Sor’s 24 Very Easy Exercises, Op. 35, 6 Divertimentos, Op. 2, and 24 Short Progressive Pieces, Op. 44. There is a continuous rise in the difficulty level throughout the method, so it is recommended that you feel comfortable playing the etudes from the first steps before engaging on a harder piece of a later step. You can listen to the whole set of pieces and understand that they do share similar classical vocabulary, therefore knowing one piece WILL make it easier to learn the next one.

Requirement

  • Fluency in G and D Major scales.
  • Experience in playing in 1st and 2nd position.
  • Proficiency in performing basic rhytmic values (quarter, 8th, half, whole notes).
  • Familiarity with playing chords.
  • Experience in performing passages with voice leading technique.

What's next

Next course: Parallel Voicing in the Classical Era for Guitar - Part 2
course_short_description: With this method you will be practicing the art of playing parallel voices, which is one of the most used techniques in the classical-romantic repertoire.

lessons.lesson_title: Introduction to ‘Parallel Voicing in the Classical Era for Guitar – Part 1’
lessons.lesson_content:
With this course you will be practicing the art of playing parallel voices, which is one of the most used techniques in the classical-romantic repertoire. Specially throughout the music of Fernando Sor, you can easily find passages of parallel thirds, and sixths (both with close and open position), and also parallel octaves, though this is a more common practice of Mauro Giuliani.

You can listen to the whole set of pieces and understand that they do share similar classical vocabulary, therefore knowing one piece WILL make it easier to learn the next one.

lessons.lesson_title: 24 Etudes, Op. 35 – Etude No. 3 Larghetto
lessons.lesson_content:
by Fernando Sor

In this first etude you will be mostly playing close position thirds and sixths in first position, but search for the position changes by the end of the etude and be careful with the legato. Of accessible difficulty, this piece is ideal to start exploring dotted rhythm playing. If you want to explore more about dotted rhythm check out our method specially made to practice dotted figures.

1 page

lessons.lesson_title: 6 Divertimentos, Op. 2 – No. 1
lessons.lesson_content:
by Fernando Sor

Throughout this etude you will have to consider which voice is the most important in the passage that you are playing. Sometimes the leading voice is found in the bass line, as you can see in the beginning of the piece. You will also be working on position changes as you do the descending thirds from seventh to first position.

lessons.lesson_title: 24 Etudes, Op. 35 – Etude No. 6 Andantino
lessons.lesson_content:
by Fernando Sor

This is a great etude to practice parallel thirds on first and second strings. Quite often it will require frequent position changes, so make sure they sound light and legato. Practice slowly the middle part of the etude, where you have a passage that requires intense left hand finger independence.

lessons.lesson_title: 24 Short Progressive Pieces, Op. 44 – Etude No. 7, Andante allegro
lessons.lesson_content:
by Fernando Sor

Here you are introduced to dotted rhythm written with smaller figures. It is recommended to practice them slowly, so that you can achieve a good legato through the position changes within the parallel voicing of the dotted rhythm.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13079/2306 24 Short Progressive Pieces, Op. 44 - Etude No. 7, Andante Allegro-1.mp4

lessons.lesson_title: 24 Short Progressive Pieces, Op. 44 – Etude No. 8, Allegretto
lessons.lesson_content:
by Fernando Sor

With this etude you will be developing your closed parallel thirds in second and third position. You will see how the composed focused on the changes between positions, here including first position. Make sure to distinguish well the singing melodies from the accompaniment.

4 pages

course_title: Parallel Voicing in the Classical Era for Guitar – Part 2
course_content:
Highlights

  • Perfecting chromatic passages in parallel voice leading.
  • Perfecting passages with dotted rhythm.
  • Exploring closed and open parallel 3rds.
  • Performing parallel 6ths.
  • Practicing parallel voicing up to 3 notes.
  • Exploring parallel voicing within accompaniment.
  • Developing the sense of appogiaturas.

Description

In this course you continue to practice the art of playing parallel voices, which is one of the most used techniques in the classical-romantic guitar repertoire.  Fernando Sor composed some of the most beautiful etudes of that era, and his approach to parallel voicing is rather unique, both in musicality and in technique development.

Therefore this method consists of an etude selection from Fernando Sor’s 24 Very Easy Exercises, Op. 35, 6 Divertimentos, Op. 1, 6 Short Pieces, Op.32, and 24 Short Progressive Pieces, Op. 44.

There is a continuous rise in the difficulty level throughout the method, so it is recommended that you feel comfortable playing the etudes from the first steps before engaging on a harder piece of a later step. You can listen to the whole set of pieces and understand that they do share similar classical vocabulary, therefore knowing one piece WILL make it easier to learn the next one.

Requirement

  • Fluency in G and D Major scales.
  • Fluency in playing melodies in higher positions (until 5th).
  • Proficiency in performing basic rhytmic values (quarter, 8th, half, whole notes)
  • Familiarity with playing chords.
  • Experience in performing passages with voice leading technique.

What's next

Next course: Parallel Voicing in the Classical Era for Guitar - Part 3
course_short_description: In this course you continue to practice the art of playing parallel voices, which is one of the most used techniques in the classical-romantic guitar repertoire.

lessons.lesson_content:

You can listen to the whole set of pieces and understand that they do share similar classical vocabulary, therefore knowing one piece WILL make it easier to learn the next one.

course_title: Parallel Voicing in the Classical Era For Guitar – Part 3
course_content:
Highlights

  • Introduction to counterpoint.
  • Exchanging between parallel 3rds and 6ths.
  • Development of fast position change in lines with parallel voicing.
  • Perfecting the tempo stability during continuous parallel voice playing.
  • Developing drama in interpretation.
  • Gaininig expertise in chromatic shifts within voicings.
  • Executing harmonics.

Description

With this course (part 3) you will be practicing the art of playing parallel voices, which is one of the most used techniques in the classical-romantic repertoire. Specially throughout the music of Fernando Sor, you can easily find passages of parallel thirds, and sixths (both with close and open position), and also parallel octaves, though this is a more common practice of Mauro Giuliani.  Therefore this method consists of an etude selection from Fernando Sor’s 12 Etudes, Op. 6, 24 Progressive Lessons, Op. 31, and 24 Very Easy Exercises, Op. 35. There is a continuous rise in the difficulty level throughout the method, so it is recommended that you feel comfortable playing the etudes from the first steps before engaging on a harder piece of a later step. You can listen to the whole set of pieces and understand that they do share similar classical vocabulary, therefore knowing one piece WILL make it easier to learn the next one.

Requirement

  • Fluency in G, D, A and E Major scales.
  • Fluency in playing melodies in higher positions (until 5th).
  • Proficiency in performing basic rhytmic values (quarter, 8th, half, whole notes).
  • Proficiency with playing chords.
  • Fluency in performing passages with voice leading technique.

What's next

Next course: Parallel Voicing in the Classical Era for Guitar - Part 4
course_short_description: With this course (part 3) you will be practicing the art of playing parallel voices, which is one of the most used techniques in the classical-romantic repertoire.

lessons.lesson_title: Introduction to ‘Parallel Voicing in the Classical Era for Guitar – Part 3’
lessons.lesson_content:
With this course (part 3) you will be practicing the art of playing parallel voices, which is one of the most used techniques in the classical-romantic repertoire. Specially throughout the music of Fernando Sor, you can easily find passages of parallel thirds, and sixths (both with close and open position), and also parallel octaves, though this is a more common practice of Mauro Giuliani. 

Therefore this method consists of an etude selection from Fernando Sor’s 12 Etudes, Op. 6, 24 Progressive Lessons, Op. 31, and 24 Very Easy Exercises, Op. 35.

There is a continuous rise in the difficulty level throughout the method, so it is recommended that you feel comfortable playing the etudes from the first steps before engaging on a harder piece of a later step. You can listen to the whole set of pieces and understand that they do share similar classical vocabulary, therefore knowing one piece WILL make it easier to learn the next one.

lessons.lesson_title: 12 Studies, Op. 6 – No. 8
lessons.lesson_content:
by Fernando Sor

One of the main characteristics of this etude is its style of voicing, which hints to the sonority of Baroque counterpoint. You will have to be careful with the overall leading of the voices, which means to take in consideration which voice is the most important at all times, for it changes throughout the piece. On the parallel voicings, practice slowly between the ending of the 4th bar up to the beginning of the 8th bar.

lessons.lesson_title: 24 Progressive Lessons, Op. 31 – Etude No. 8, Andante
lessons.lesson_content:
by Fernando Sor

This etude is a perfect representation of Sor’s musical identity. You can feel it in his unique harmonic/melodic treatment, in which he frequently uses the parallel sixths to transmit emotional weight. Make sure that the position changes of the parallel thirds by the end of the second part of the piece are well connected, smooth and clean.

lessons.lesson_title: 12 Studies, Op. 6 – No. 9
lessons.lesson_content:
by Fernando Sor

If you felt that the parallel sixths in the previous etude were very effective then this etude is for you. Sor brings the emotional weight of melody to a higher level, thanks to his chromatic melody that is always doubled with a parallel sixth. Release the two singers within those parallel voices, and do not speed up!

lessons.lesson_title: 24 Etudes, Op. 35 – Etude No. 21, Andante
lessons.lesson_content:
by Fernando Sor

This etude lets you comfortably explore the fingerings of parallel thirds in A major. Make sure to articulate the melody well every time the initial motif of the piece shows up again on the piece. Use this etude to fully integrate good shifts between the first and the fifth positions. Keep an eye to the hidden thirds and sixths throughout the accompaniment lines.

lessons.lesson_title: 24 Progressive Lessons, Op. 31 – Etude No. 10, Cantabile
lessons.lesson_content:
by Fernando Sor

On this step you will integrate slurred thirds into your technique library - a common characteristic in Sor’s repertoire which adds in this musical context some humoristic and lighthearted content to the etude. You will also venture into ever higher positions and longer passages through parallel thirds.

2 pages

course_title: Parallel Voicing in the Classical era For Guitar – Part 4
course_content:
Highlights

  • Alternating between rhythm patterns in parallel voicing.
  • Further development on position shifts within parallel voicing.
  • Working on chromatism within parallel voicings (6ths).
  • Mastering the position shifts.
  • Mastering the parallel 3rds.

Description

With this course (part 4) you will be practicing the art of playing parallel voices, which is one of the most used techniques in the classical-romantic repertoire. Specially throughout the music of Fernando Sor, you can easily find passages of parallel thirds, and sixths (both with close and open position), and also parallel octaves, though this is a more common practice of Mauro Giuliani.  Therefore this method consists of an etude selection from Fernando Sor’s 24 Very Easy Exercises, Op. 35, 8 Short Pieces, Op. 24, and 12 Etudes, Op. 6. There is a continuous rise in the difficulty level throughout the method, so it is recommended that you feel comfortable playing the etudes from the first steps before engaging on a harder piece of a later step. You can listen to the whole set of pieces and understand that they do share similar classical vocabulary, therefore knowing one piece WILL make it easier to learn the next one.

Requirement

  • Fluency in F, G, D, A and E Major scales.
  • Expertise in playing melodies in higher positions (until 5th).
  • Excellence in performing basic rhytmic values (quarter, 8th, half, whole notes).
  • Expertise with playing chords.
  • Experience in performing passages with voice leading technique.
course_short_description: With this course (part 4) you will be practicing the art of playing parallel voices, which is one of the most used techniques in the classical-romantic repertoire.

lessons.lesson_title: Introduction to ‘Parallel Voicing in the Classical Era for Guitar – Part 4’
lessons.lesson_content:
With this course (part 4) you will be practicing the art of playing parallel voices, which is one of the most used techniques in the classical-romantic repertoire. course_title: Perfect Your Classical Music Phrasing
course_content:
Highlights

  • Executing double stops.
  • Executing chords.
  • Executing long lasting 8th note runs.
  • Gaining proficiency in classical era musical phrasing.

Description

This course builds its direction towards a well known melody by the one and only W.A. Mozart. It is a piece that has a bit of everything for a mid-beginner violinist to see as achievable challenges. Staccatos on the same bow, slurred string crossings, dynamic changes, uneven phrase lengths and repeated bars that ask to be played ever so slightly differently, and as a final touch; some very achievable double stops to final the piece!

Requirement

  • Intermediate level of score reading ability.
  • Mobility of left hand for diagonal shapes (rapid shifts or maintaining intervals between strings)
  • Swift string crossing abilities.
  • Proficiency in half, quarter, eight and dotted notes.
  • Relaxed right hand in order to execute dynamics.
  • Novice experience in executing staccato technique.

What's next

Next course: Preparation for a Violin Concerto in Style of Vivaldi - Part 1
course_short_description: This course builds its direction towards a well known melody by the one and only W.A. Mozart. It is a piece that has a bit of everything for a mid-beginner violinist to see as achievable challenges.

lessons.lesson_title: Introduction to ‘ Perfect Your Classical Music Phrasing’
lessons.lesson_content: This course builds its direction towards a well known melody by the one and only W.A. Mozart. It is a piece that has a bit of everything for a mid-beginner violinist to see as achievable challenges. Staccatos on the same bow, slurred string crossings, dynamic changes, uneven phrase lengths and repeated bars that ask to be played ever so slightly differently, and as a final touch; some very achievable double stops to final the piece!

lessons.lesson_title: Double Stops 1 – Violin Exercises
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Most people think that to play double stops, they should press harder on the strings with the bow; but that is certainly not necessary to play two strings at the same time. Carefully placing the bow to have actually two points-of-contact with the strings is just enough. It is recommended to keep an eye on the bridge area for this exercise.

lessons.lesson_title: Double Stops – D Major Scale – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

When practicing a line that has double stops, it is useful to play the notes separately at first, then moving on to the combination to make sure the intonation of each note is perfect. In this exercise we use the open string at all times, but one could easily place two fingers on two strings and practice other intervals with the same way of thinking.

lessons.lesson_title: Double Stops – Octaves 1 – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Playing octaves with good intonation can be tricky at times but there is no better way to get fluent at them than playing them separately once and then the combination. It is recommended to to this exercise starting with the up bow as well to get used to the alternative bow stroke.

lessons.lesson_title: Chords – Introduction – Violin Exercises
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

When playing chords on the violin, there are more than a few ways. But at this point the goal is to establish fluency between the outer strings that are used to play the chords. The player must be aware that the middle string can sound at all times since the point of contact is never going away from it.

course_title: Practice The ‘Feeling in Three’
course_content:
Highlights

  • Ternary pulse practice
  • Introduction to small slurred passages
  • Legato workout.

Description

In this step by step method you will be practicing ternary pulse, typically called the "feeling in three", essential for any beginner players. One of the challenges of the etude on this method is to keep a stable count of 3’s required to play a 3/8 bar piece. It introduces small slur passages, but which demand the use of the fourth finger to pull the string. Try to keep the legato when changing the fingers’ position between the third and first beats of every bar.

Requirement

  • Completion of course: ‘Classical Homophony and Arpeggiation’.
  • Novice level of score reading ability.
  • Beginner level in keeping stable tempo, and stable 8th notes on a ternary piece.
  • Proficiency in playing two notes at the same time.
  • Beginner level in parallel voicing.
  • Proficiency in left hand vertical finger extension.
  • Comfortable with the frequent use of 4th finger.

What's next

Next course: Waltzing Arpeggio and Homophony
course_tag: dotted quarter eighth and sixteenth notes
course_short_description: In this step by step method to practice an etude by Fernando Sor, you will be focussing on ternary pulse, typically called the "feeling in three", essential for any beginner player. This method will also introduce slur passages for all the left hand fingers.

lessons.lesson_title: Introduction to “Practice The ‘Feeling in Three’”
lessons.lesson_content: In this step by step method you will be practicing ternary pulse, typically called the “feeling in three”, essential for any beginner players. One of the challenges of the etude on this method is to keep a stable count of 3’s required to play a 3/8 bar piece. It introduces small slur passages, but which demand the use of the fourth finger to pull the string. Try to keep the legato when changing the fingers’ position between the third and first beats of every bar.

lessons.lesson_title: B Diminished Arpeggio – Guitar Exercises
lessons.lesson_content:
There are two things that will help you play the B Diminished Arpeggio. One is working out your awareness of the chord block on your left hand. The second thing consists in preparing the fingers right on time in order to play a well connected legato.

by ScoreWind Teachers

lessons.lesson_title: Broken Open Thirds With Position Change – Guitar Exercises
lessons.lesson_content:
This exercise is ideal for practicing position changes, specifically between the 1st and the 3rd position on the fretboard. You can use the left hand's 4th finger to guide you through the changes, both going up and down the frets.

by ScoreWind Teachers
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13550/13550 3753 Broken Open Thirds With Position Change.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13550/13550 3753 Broken Open Thirds With Position Change.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Open Thirds in p-m-i Arpeggio With Position Change – Guitar Exercises
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

These are the two key things to work on this exercise; First, practice the arpeggio technique for the right hand pm-i, a very typical finger combination during this period of the classical guitar. Second, pay special attention to the transition between 1st and 3rd positions. Controlling the movement of the entire left arm will help you do the best shifts. Your elbow will serve as a pendulum that will allow you to be relaxed while changing position, and your fourth finger will be the anchor that guides the block of notes from one position to the other and back again.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13551/13551 3754 Open Thirds in p-m-i Arpeggio With Position Change.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13551/13551 3754 Open Thirds in p-m-i Arpeggio With Position Change.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Finger Slurs – 4th Finger – Guitar Exercises
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Slurs are an essential technique for all the guitarists out there, specially the slurs made with the 4th finger (they tend to always be the hardest, but you will manage it!). Placing your left hand well is half the work done. The back of your hand should face the "audience" in front of you. Regarding the slur, don't snap the string, nor just lift off your finger from it. You need to find the midpoint, in order to have a well projected, yet not dirty, slurred note. Try to even as much as possible the intensity of the note you play with the right hand, and the note you slur with your left.

lessons.lesson_title: Case Specific – 3/8 – Guitar Exercises
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

In this exercise you will practice playing with ternary feeling (counting in 1, 2, 3's).  There is a certain fall on the first beat that you must convey while playing, and then the second and the third beats are to be played lighter. Having said this, we are not talking about doing an accent on the first beat, it's rather a light fall or placing some weight on it. Following the ternary bar with the movement of your body can help you feel better this waltz-like sensation. More on the technical end, pay attention to playing the midnotes by the 3rd beat exactly at the same time, since there usually is a tendency to do the opposite. Be careful when taking the 4th finger out on the third and fourth bars; The timing for this needs to be perfect, otherwise you won't sound legato, or coordinated.

lessons.lesson_title: Case Specific – 3/8 with slurs – Guitar Exercises
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Here we keep the arpeggio from the previous exercise, and we add slurs to the beginning of each bar. Remember to not just snap the string nor lift off lightly your finger. Find the midpoint between the two. Pulling your slurring finger in a certain diagonal direction, thus not straight up, nor down, will help you reach that midpoint between projection and cleanness.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13554/13554 3757 Explanation For Case Specific 2 - 3 8 With Slurs.mp4

course_title: Preparation for a Violin Concerto in D Major by O. Rieding – Part 1
course_content:
Highlights

  • Performing pieces with long length.
  • Perfecting intonation in essential keys.

Description

This course focuses mainly on D Major and G Major pieces that have string crossing as part of their essence, and it leads to a well known concerto composed for learners by Oscar Rieding. This method is recommended for players who are fluent in music notation reading. Establishing comfort over each piece can take at least a week's time for most of the learners, so no rush! Although technical difficulties of each piece is rather similar within this collected group of pieces, they are not meant to be played precisely with the given order. Yet they can help each other out; since learning classical vocabulary is like learning a new language; knowing one piece WILL make it easier to learn the next one. There is a difficulty level rise to some extend towards the last pieces. You can listen to the whole set of pieces and start from whichever piece you feel the interest for. 

Requirement

  • Intermediate level of score reading ability.
  • Proficiency in half, quarter, eight, triplet and dotted notes.
  • Relaxed right hand in order to execute dynamics.

What's next

Next course: Preparation for a Violin Concerto in D Major by O. Rieding - Part 2

lessons.lesson_title: The Happy Farmer – Arr. for violin and piano
lessons.lesson_content:
by R. Schumann

In this piece the melodic idea starts at the end of the bar, which is called Auftakt or an Upbeat. Dotted note figures must be performed carefully, with the beat kept in mind. 8th note passages can be played with short bow strokes to ease up the string crossings that must be prepared in advance by both hands.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13386/17 Suzuki Schumann The Happy Farmer Corrected-15.mp4

lessons.lesson_title: Menuet No. 2 – Arr. for violin and piano
lessons.lesson_content:
by Johann Sebastian Bach

Menuet is a French dance style popular around 17th and 18th centuries. It has a very happy first half and the second part of the music leads to a minor key for a short period, needing an extended 3rd finger that can be altered with 4th finger if the position is uncomfortable for the player. String changes must be prepared by both front arms as efficiently as possible beforehand.

course_title: Preparation for a Violin Concerto in D Major by O. Rieding – Part 2
course_content:
Highlights

  • Performing a real concerto!
  • Maintaining concentration through a long lenght music piece.

Description

This course (part 2) focuses mainly on D Major and G Major pieces that have string crossing as part of their essence, and it leads to a well known concerto composed for learners by Oscar Rieding. This method is recommended for players who are fluent in music notation reading. Establishing comfort over each piece can take at least a week's time for most of the learners, so no rush! Although technical difficulties of each piece is rather similar within this collected group of pieces, they are not meant to be played precisely with the given order. Yet they can help each other out; since learning classical vocabulary is like learning a new language; knowing one piece WILL make it easier to learn the next one. There is a difficulty level rise to some extend towards the last pieces. You can listen to the whole set of pieces and start from whichever piece you feel the interest for. 

Requirement

  • Intermediate level of score reading ability.
  • Proficiency in half, quarter, eight, triplet and dotted notes.
  • Relaxed right hand in order to execute dynamics.

What's next

Next course: Preparation for a Violin Concerto in Style of Vivaldi - Part 1

course_title: Preparation for a Violin Concerto in Style of Vivaldi – Part 1
course_content:
Highlights

  • Performing pieces with long length.
  • Playing passages in 3rd position.
  • Learning to execute techniques required to play famous pieces by Vivaldi.

Description

This course combines rhythmic stability with Baroque era music vocabulary and leads the player to play a concerto written in the style of one of the most famous composers of all times; Antonio Vivaldi. Melodic pieces and exercises on the way mainly work on subdivision; combining quarter notes with 8th notes or 8th notes with 16th notes. It is recommended for players who are about to get fluent in music notation reading. Establishing comfort over each piece can take at least more than a weeks time, so no rush! Although technical difficulties of each piece is rather similar within this collected group of pieces, they are not meant to be played precisely with the given order. Yet they can help each other out; since learning classical vocabulary is like learning a new language; knowing one piece WILL make it easier to learn the next one. There is a difficulty level rise to some extend towards the last pieces. You can listen to the whole set of pieces and start from whichever piece you feel the interest for. 

Requirement

  • Intermediate level of score reading ability.
  • Mobility of left hand for diagonal shapes (rapid shifts or maintaining intervals between strings).
  • Swift string crossing abilities.
  • Proficiency in half, quarter, eight and dotted notes.
  • Relaxed right hand in order to execute dynamics.
  • Novice experience in executing staccato technique.

What's next

Next course: Preparation for a Violin Concerto in Style of Vivaldi - Part 2

lessons.lesson_title: Long Long Ago – Arr. for violin and piano
lessons.lesson_content:
T.H. Bayly

For some this is a very familiar song. It is a melody that has got to be represented in many forms; possibly because of its unforgettable yet very naive and simple melody. It is the introduction piece for this set of pieces due to its usage of quarter notes and 8th notes. Learners could gain more control over the rhythm by using large bow strokes for the long notes and short bow strokes for the short notes.

lessons.lesson_title: Andantino in D Major – Arr. for violin and piano
lessons.lesson_content:
Anonymous

This piece uses the same rhythmic compound and can be used as a start point for the fourth finger. Learners must pay attention to the second half where each bar contains quarter notes and to not rush them it is suggested to keep the sub-division in mind; each quarter note contains two 8th notes' value.

lessons.lesson_title: Allegretto – Arr. for violin and piano
lessons.lesson_content:
by

This piece follows the rhythmical concept of the previous piece (Andantino). The main difference is that the melodic idea starts at the second half of the bar, so the piece starts with a half length bar which is called Auftakt or Upbeat.

lessons.lesson_title: Musette in D Major – Arr. for violin and piano
lessons.lesson_content:
by

Musette is a kind of French dance popular around the 17th-18th century; which influenced classical music with its rhythm in a very strong way. The slurring ways of the groups of 8th notes are very commonly used in classical music vocabulary.

course_title: Preparation for a Violin Concerto in the Romantic Style – Part 1
course_content:
Highlights

  • Performing pieces with long length.
  • Playing passages with double stops.
  • Playing passages with chromatism.
  • Learning to execute techniques required to play many famous romantic era pieces.

Description

This course is for players to challenge themselves to a long lasting piece; a movement from a concerto by Frederich Seitz! Playing a concerto doesn’t mean playing something that is harder than before, but it needs a longer lasting concentration since the piece itself is longer. The steps on the way are selected to keep the musical ideas running, most of them are very melodic pieces and some are etudes that prepare the player to the challenges that lie ahead. Phrase lengths are rather longer towards the end, also to prepare the player to the pace of a concerto where musical phrases tend to last longer than in shorter pieces. Although technical difficulties of each piece is rather similar within this collected group of pieces, they are not meant to be played precisely with the given order. Yet they can help each other out; since learning classical vocabulary is like learning a new language; knowing one piece WILL make it easier to learn the next one. There is a difficulty level rise to some extend towards the last pieces. You can listen to the whole set of pieces and start from whichever piece you feel the interest for. 

Requirement

  • Intermediate level of score reading ability.
  • Mobility of left hand for chromatism.
  • Proficiency in half, quarter, eight and dotted notes.
  • Relaxed right hand in order to execute dynamics.
  • Novice experience with double stops.

What's next

Next course: Preparation for a Violin Concerto in the Romantic Style - Part 2

lessons.lesson_title: 36 Easy and Melodic Studies, Op. 84 – No. 1
lessons.lesson_content:
by C. Dancla

Dancla's etude no. 1 is a warm up that is useful for integrating 4th finger to the playing. When playing, one can use the variation suggestions for the bowings, or simply focus on a straight bow stroke that has a balanced tone and clean intonation.
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12087/3784 36 Easy and Melodic Studies Op 84 No 1.xml

lessons.lesson_title: 36 Easy and Melodic Studies, Op. 84 – No. 5, Moderato
lessons.lesson_content:
by C. Dancla

Number 5 includes plenty of contrasting musical ideas. Very lineal melodies are combined with scales going up and down on rapid bow strokes. The repetitive motion of the slurred notes can be seen as ornamentations that need to be played as lightly as possible to keep the forward motion.
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12083/3788 36 Easy and Melodic Studies Op 84 No 5.xml

lessons.lesson_title: 36 Easy and Melodic Studies, Op. 84 – No. 28, Moderato
lessons.lesson_content:
by C. Dancla

This etude challenges the player to keep the bow technique running without any interruptions. Players must focus on keeping their right hand as relaxed and possible; while making sure that the repeated notes are not pressed too hard on the left hand.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12059/12059 3812 36 Easy And Melodic Studies Op 84 No 28 C Dancla Corrected-1.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12059/3812 36 Easy and Melodic Studies Op 84 No 28.xml

lessons.lesson_title: 36 Easy and Melodic Studies, Op. 84 – No. 10, Moderato
lessons.lesson_content:
by C. Dancla

This piece can be practiced without slurs to get used to the notes. After the key changes and string crossings are learned the slurs can be added; one must remember that throughout most parts of the piece each bow stroke containst two beats which means the bow length must be equal on both directions.
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12078/3793 36 Easy and Melodic Studies Op 84 No 10.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Gavotte – Arr. for violin and piano
lessons.lesson_content:
by F.J. Gossec

A very melodic G Major piece to work on articulations. Contrast between staccato (dotted on top) and tenuto (lined on top) notes must be shown as much as possible. The staccato notes are to be played lightly and playfully.

course_title: Scales and Finger Speed for Piano – Part 1
course_content:
Highlights

  • Repetitive melodic patterns on the right hand.
  • Large intervals on both hands.
  • Performing 16th notes.
  • Introduction to pedal notes.
  • Articulation development (staccato and legato).
  • Learning essential right hand patterns for melodic arpeggiations.
  • Playing continuous melodic lines.

Description

This course will help you on your path to become a piano virtuoso! In this first part of the method, you will begin with etudes of easy difficulty from Carl Czerny's Practical Exercises for Beginners, Op. 599, and 100 Progressive Studies, Op. 139. You will focus on each hand individually, as you will see that most of the times the etudes are built with one hand playing a simple accompaniment so that you can focus on the other hand and work on speed and precision. In the later etudes of Part 1, both hands will begin to distribute the challenge within the same piece, but you will manage it if you work well on the first part. There is a continuous rise in the difficulty level throughout the method, so it is recommended that you feel comfortable playing the etudes from the first steps before engaging on a harder piece of a later step. You can listen to the whole set of pieces and understand that they do share similar classical vocabulary, therefore knowing one piece WILL make it easier to learn the next one.

Requirement

  • Novice level of score reading ability (Reading notes on G clef).
  • Knowing basic note values (8th, quarter, half, whole notes).
  • Novice level autonomy in both hands.
  • Fluent in C Major scale melodic lines.
  • 3 octave playing experience.

What's next

Next course: Scales and Finger Speed for Piano - Part 2
course_short_description: This course will help you on your path to become a piano virtuoso! You will begin with etudes of easy difficulty, and focus both on singles hands or with similar distribution of difficulty.

lessons.lesson_title: 100 Progressive Studies, Op. 139 – Etude No. 3
lessons.lesson_content:
by Carl Czerny

This etude is aiming to invest on the velocity of the player on the right hand while introducing a line very similar to the often used style of Alberti bass on the left hand.

2 pages

lessons.lesson_title: Practical Exercises for Beginners, Op. 599 – Etude No. 16
lessons.lesson_content:
by Carl Czerny

2 pages

In this etude, Czerny insists on the workout of the movement of the fingerings 1-2-3-4-5 and 5-4-3-2-1 - one of the most basic skills to be developed for the foundations of piano technique. Follow the articulation of each passage, by leading the slurred 16th notes to the staccato 4th note.

The left hand follows Czerny’s basic harmony, with one of the most typical accompaniment styles. Place weight on the whole bass note, and play the 4th note accompaniment lightly.

lessons.lesson_title: Practical Exercises for Beginners, Op. 599 – Etude No. 18
lessons.lesson_content:
by Carl Czerny

Here you find a mind trickster etude, since it will make you go through quick (and possibly confusing at first) changes of finger combination. It’s a very effective way of practicing finger independence, but it can be tiring for you mind, for you have to be extra sharp on your focus. It requires that you practice slowly, so you give time to both your mind and fingers to get used to the changes.

The left hand will be accompanying the melody with a simple chord progression, but keep in mind you make all the notes sound exactly at the same time.

course_title: Scales and Finger Speed for Piano – Part 2
course_content:
Highlights

  • Switching between G clef and F clef on the left hand.
  • Using dyads in left hand accompaniment.
  • Playing 8th notes and 16th notes combinations.
  • Playing parallel scales with both hands.
  • Adding dyads to the melodic lines.
  • Articulated chord accompaniment on the left hand.
  • Dynamics and accidentals.
  • Call and response in scale playing.

Description

This course will help you on your path to become a piano virtuoso! In this second part of the course, you will play etudes of easy difficulty from Carl Czerny's Practical Exercises for Beginners, Op. 599, and 100 Progressive Studies, Op. 139. This method is aiming to train players to speed up both their hands. The selected etudes inside this method have fast pace runs in various arpeggio, melodic scale and chromatic line styles. It is recommended to practice these selected pieces with the aim of playing them fast one day, which means, getting used to efficient moving even while practicing them slowly. Make sure to divide parts into passages and isolate hard parts this way. Also; only play something at a faster tempo when a certain tempo is too easy for you to play! There is a continuous rise in the difficulty level throughout the method, so it is recommended that you feel comfortable playing the etudes from the first steps before engaging on a harder piece of a later step. You can listen to the whole set of pieces and understand that they do share similar classical vocabulary, therefore knowing one piece WILL make it easier to learn the next one.

Requirement

  • Intermediate level of score reading ability (Reading notes on G clef).
  • Novice level of score reading ability (Reading notes on F clef).
  • Fluency in 16th note passages.
  • Novice level autonomy in both hands.
  • Fluent in C Major scale melodic lines.
  • 3 octave playing experience.

What's next

Next course: Scales and Finger Speed for Piano - Part 3
course_short_description: This course (part 2) is aiming to train players to speed up both their hands. The selected etudes inside this method have fast pace runs in various arpeggio, melodic scale and chromatic line styles.

  • Further working on articulation techniques.

  • Playing quadrads (chords with 4 notes).

Requirement

  • Fluency in reading score in both G and F clefs.
  • Fluency in 16th note passages.
  • Intermediate level autonomy in both hands.
  • Fluent in C, G, Bb Major scales.
  • Experience in using black keys.
  • 3 octave playing experience.

What's next

Next course: Scales and Finger Speed for Piano - Part 4

lessons.lesson_title: Practical Exercises for Beginners, Op. 599 – Etude No. 61
lessons.lesson_content:
by Carl Czerny

Subdivision is essential in this piece! Learning to omit the 1st 16th note from mostly the right hand is one of the main tasks to achieve. Learners can say outloud the first beat by calling "one" before starting to play the right hand melody when this waiting for the rest is required. Only when the both hands are able to play it at the same time, the "call" and "response" of the both hands will be cleared out, so we promise that it will get easier in time. :) Pay attention to lift up the left hand during the 8th note rests that come after the chords that must be played rather shorter than the full-beat length chords.

lessons.lesson_title: 100 Progressive Studies, Op. 139 – Etude No. 27
lessons.lesson_content:
by Carl Czerny

On the bright side, practicing one hand of this etude certainly positively effects the other hand right away, since they share the roles between themselves evenly. This means when one hand is playing the melody, the other one accompanies and they shift roles in the middle. In the staccatto notes, the player must make sure to hammer the notes rapidly and "bounce off" from the note with the strength gained from the down movement while preparing the other finger to do the exact same manouver.  As for the scale runs; we recommend practicing them in expanding groups meaning first one note, then two notes, then three notes, then four notes etc. of the run at a time.

lessons.lesson_title: 100 Progressive Studies, Op. 139 – Etude No. 29
lessons.lesson_content:
by Carl Czerny

In this etude the combination of Alberti bass, scale runs and double stop melodic lines are used. We recommend each 4 bar sections to be practiced individually by both hands and then combined. Once each passage of 4 bars is established learners can combine the 4 different ideas.

lessons.lesson_title: Practical Exercises for Beginners, Op. 599 – Etude No. 59
lessons.lesson_content:
by Carl Czerny

32nd notes are twice as fast as the 16th but like anything else, if you practice it slowly enough times you will master the speed very rapidly. Dotted notes must bounce off the piano and hammered down with the speed of lifting the hand up. In etudes like this one, both hands can share the practice session with a different approach; the learner can play the hand that has the scales and change hands when the scale line moves to the other hand. Same goes for the dotted note, double stop melodic line. 

2 pages

course_title: Scales and Finger Speed for Piano – Part 4
course_content:
Highlights

  • Playing chromatic lines.
  • Playing pieces with 3/8 measure.
  • Connecting scales with both hands (starting with left, ending with right).
  • Further working on triplet playing (applied to scales).
  • Executing sextuplets (6 notes in one beat).
  • Exectuing chromatic changes througout musical pieces.

Description

This course will help you on your path to become a piano virtuoso! In this fourth part of the course, you will play etudes of easy difficulty from Carl Czerny's Practical Exercises for Beginners, Op. 599, and 100 Progressive Studies, Op. 139. This course is aiming to train players to speed up both their hands. The selected etudes inside this method have fast pace runs in various arpeggio, melodic scale and chromatic line styles. It is recommended to practice these selected pieces with the aim of playing them fast one day, which means, getting used to efficient moving even while practicing them slowly. Make sure to divide parts into passages and isolate hard parts this way. Also; only play something at a faster tempo when a certain tempo is too easy for you to play! There is a continuous rise in the difficulty level throughout the method, so it is recommended that you feel comfortable playing the etudes from the first steps before engaging on a harder piece of a later step. You can listen to the whole set of pieces and understand that they do share similar classical vocabulary, therefore knowing one piece WILL make it easier to learn the next one.

Requirement

  • Expert in reading score in both G and F clefs.
  • Fluency in 16th note passages.
  • Intermediate level autonomy in both hands.
  • Fluency in chromatic score reading.
  • 3 octave playing experience.
course_short_description: This course (part 4) is aiming to train players to speed up both their hands. The selected etudes inside this method have fast pace runs in various arpeggio, melodic scale and chromatic line styles.

It is recommended to practice these selected pieces with the aim of playing them fast one day, which means, getting used to efficient moving even while practicing them slowly. There is a continuous rise in the difficulty level throughout the method, so it is recommended that you feel comfortable playing the etudes from the first steps before engaging on a harder piece of a later step. You can listen to the whole set of pieces and understand that they do share similar classical vocabulary, therefore knowing one piece WILL make it easier to learn the next one.

course_title: Scales, Arpeggios and  Flowing Bass Lines!
course_content:
Highlights

  • Descending and ascending scales.
  • Right hand’s index-middle finger workout.
  • Thumb and bass line practice.
  • Introduction to essential chords.
  • Playing three notes at the same time.

Description

This etude by Fernando Sor, prepared with our step by step exercises, introduces a wide variety of descending and ascending scale like passages, along with engaging melodic lines in the bass line. These two musical aspects require a good coordination of index-middle fingers (aka: i-m) for the scale like parts, and a good control of the thumb (p) to be able to play the melody of the bass line. You will also find some of the most common arpeggios played on the guitar, namely E minor, A minor, and B dominant chords.

Requirement

  • Beginner-intermediate level of score reading ability.
  • Proficiency in two voice treatment.
  • Proficiency in melodic arpeggios.
  • Proficiency in 1st position scales.
  • Proficiency in left hand chord fingerings.
  • Comfortable in playing with the thumb.
  • Familiar with playing two notes at the same time.

What's next

Next course: Sor's Gallant Dotted Rhythm
