lessons.lesson_content: This etude by Fernando Sor, prepared with our step by step exercises, introduces a wide variety of descending and ascending scale like passages, along with engaging melodic lines in the bass line. These two musical aspects require a good coordination of index-middle fingers (aka: i-m) for the scale like parts, and a good control of the thumb (p) to be able to play the melody of the bass line. You will also find some of the most common arpeggios played on the guitar, namely E minor, A minor, and B dominant chords.

lessons.lesson_title: E Minor Scale in First Position (2 octaves)
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

The E minor tonality stands out from any other tonality throughout the history of the classical guitar, tagging this scale as one of the most essential for any guitarist, of any level. This two octave scale leads you to play from the lowest open E on the sixth string to the highest open E on the first string. Having to play F# on the fourth string will require that your 4th finger stays close to the fretboard, and horizontally aligned with your 1st finger.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12099/12099 3766 E Minor Scale 2 Octaves First Position.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12099/3766 E Minor Scale in First Position (2 octaves).xml

lessons.lesson_title: A Minor Arpeggio on 1st Positon
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

A minor is one of the most common arpeggios to be played on the guitar. Yet, it comes with a high degree of challenge if you want to make it right and, eventually, effortlessly. It's very important to have a well ronded left hand when playing this or any other melodic arpeggio. Reserve your 4th finger to play the low C on the 5th string, and the high A on the 1st string. If you place this finger well (close to the fretboard and horizontally aligned with the 1st finger) you will see that the rest of your fingers will follow the good positioning, and playing this arpeggio will become much easier.

lessons.lesson_title: E Minor Arpeggio on First Position
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

This is a fairly accecible arpeggio that will give you the full sound potential of your guitar. The frequent use of the open strings helps creating that full bodied sound in which the notes are also perfectly connecting to each other. These are the things to keep in mind: keep your left hand well ronded when playing this melodic arpeggio. Reserve your 4th finger to play the low G on the 6th string, and the high G on the 1st string. The secret for the good hand hand positioning is to place the 4th finger close to the fretboard and horizontally aligned with the 1st finger (even if you're currently not playing with it). By doing this alignement you will be helping your 2nd and 3rd finger's positioning.

lessons.lesson_title: B Dominant Arpeggio
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

B Dominant arpeggio is excellent to open up the finger placement of your left hand, since the notes of this arpeggio are place quite faraway from each other on the fretboard, and you also have less access to open strings that could help you transitioning from one note to the other. Focus on having a good horizontal alignement between the 1st and 4th finger, and that there is always a fair amount of space between your fingers (this will help you a lot, not only in this case, but for your whole left hand positioning foundation). Make the change for the hight D# with your 3rd finger, so that you lead your 1st and 4th finger to a stable second position on the first string.

lessons.lesson_title: Arpeggio Technique Exercise in E minor
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

This arpeggio will help you develop a fuller sound produced by your right hand. Play loud, full, and deep. Allow your instrument to reverberate in this arpeggio, so representative of the classical guitar sonority. Regarding the left hand, you can help the transition between the two chords by adjusting the position of your elbow in the right moments. Thus, the elbow's timing and placement!

lessons.lesson_title: Case Specific: Slur in Fast Passage
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

One of the challenging moments of the etude of this method is it's fast slur passage. In this exercise we isolate that difficutly, so that you can focus on it with your full attention, without having to worry about the rest of the piece. As you practice this exercise, try to match the volume levels between the slured and the not-slured notes. When doing the slur, pull the string just enough to hear the note at the right level. If you pull with too much strength, you risk making a very noisy slur which might interfer with the brightness of your performance.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12097/12097 3770 Case Specific Slur In Fast Passage.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12097/3770 Case Specific - Slurs in Fast Passages corrected.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Case Specific: Melodic Bass Workout
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

There is a tendency in almost every guitarist to care less about what their thumb is doing. This may bring problems anytime a demanding thumb based passage comes along. We selected this case specific because we care about your thumb's potential, and you will see too what a joy is it to play exciting melodic bass lines with 'p'! Besides the special thumb workout, this exercise is also demanding for the left hand. Allow space between your fingers and keep them prepared over each one of the first four frets. This will help you with the repetitive and undulating melody, as well as keeping the long notes clear.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12096/12096 3771 Case Specific Melodic Bass Line In 3 4.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12096/3771 Case Specific - Melodic Bass Line in 34.xml

course_title: Sor’s Gallant Dotted Rhythm
course_content:
Highlights

  • Specialized dotted rhythm workout.
  • Melodic and rhythmic treatment of dotted rhythm.
  • Triplet elements on melody.
  • Descending parallel voicing.

Description

This method, arranged with our step by step model, will guide you in learning how to play correctly music with dotted rhythm. It is an increadibly powerful rhythmic figure, but it takes great effort in perfecting. Once it's finally under your grasp, you will have access to its dramatic musical effect. Dotted rhythm is present from the beginning to the end of this etude, so you will have plenty of opportunities to practice it in various fingering contexts. Keep in mind to not rush, because there usually is the tendency to do so in pieces of this kind. Also alter your musical intention for when the dotted rhythm sounds more melodic or more rhythmic.

Requirement

  • Beginner-intermediate level of score reading ability.
  • Familiar with playing dotted rhythm.
  • Familiar with playing three notes at the same time.
  • Proficiency in 1st position scales.
  • Comfortable with rhythmic variety within a piece.
  • Proficiency in the frequent use of 4th finger.

What's next

Next course: Introduction to D Major Fingerings
course_tag: half dotted quarter eighth and sixteenth notes
course_short_description: This method, arranged with our step by step model, will guide you in learning how to play correctly music with dotted rhythm. It is an increadibly powerful rhythmic figure, but it takes great effort in perfecting. Once it's finally under your grasp, you will have access to its dramatic musical effect.

lessons.lesson_title: Introduction to “Sor’s Gallant Dotted Rhythm”
lessons.lesson_content: This method, arranged with our step by step model, will guide you in learning how to play correctly music with dotted rhythm. It is an increadibly powerful rhythmic figure, but it takes great effort in perfecting. Once it’s finally under your grasp, you will have access to its dramatic musical effect. Dotted rhythm is present from the beginning to the end of this etude, so you will have plenty of opportunities to practice it in various fingering contexts. Keep in mind to not rush, because there usually is the tendency to do so in pieces of this kind. Also alter your musical intention for when the dotted rhythm sounds more melodic or more rhythmic.

lessons.lesson_title: A Minor Scale Two Octaves in First Position
lessons.lesson_content: This is one of the most important scales for guitar, because a lot of repertoire uses this scale and its fingerings. Having control over the A minor scale will help you overcome many of the obstacles you can find throughout the repertoire for our instrument. The biggest challenge you will encounter in this scale is the incredible extension in the first string between the notes e, f, g, a; an up to the fifth fret stretch. The key here is to open up your left hand knuckles as you reach to the f, in order to be prepared to play the g and the a, and later be ready to descend on the scale. With this type of preparation you will be saving time and effort. As you can see in the video, my elbow is nearly touching the guitar, and I even bring my left shoulder slightly down to keep my fourth finger with a well rounded shape as I reach to the A on the fifth fret.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13528/13528 A Minor Scale Two Octaves In First Position.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13528/13528 A Minor Scale Two Octaves in First Position.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Dotted Rhythm Workout
lessons.lesson_content:
Dotted Rhythm Workout

Most of the times when you find these small dots right next to the notes, you know that you will be playing dotted rhythm (other cases include ways of writing in complex bars such as 12/8). This means that you're going to add half of the value of the duration of the note that the dot belongs to. It is always the same rule, independently of the original duration of the note. It is always that one value (a half, quarter, eight, sixteenth note) plus its half; so, one and a half value every time. In this case our dotted rhythm will be done with 8th and 16th notes. First you will only play a base of 8th notes, then you’ll subdivide every second 8th note into two 16th notes, and finally you will omit the first 16th note and add the value of that note to the 8th note that you just played. This way, you progressively learn how to play dotted rhythm and understand how it is created.

lessons.lesson_title: A Minor Scale with Dotted Rhythm
lessons.lesson_content:
A Minor Scale with Dotted Rhythm

Applying dotted rhythm to almost any passage you’re practicing, including scales such as the one on this exercise, will help you bring your technique level one step forward. Doing this also contributes to practicing the dotted rhythm, which in itself can be challenging to grasp. Adding the “and’s” to your counting (so: 1, and, 2, and,3, and,4, and), will help you subdivide the beat and find the correct place to play the 16th notes.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13530/13530 A Minor Scale With Dotted Rhythm.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13530/13530 A Minor Scale with Dotted Rhythm.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Slurred Appoggiaturas
lessons.lesson_content:
Slurred Appoggiaturas

Here you will practice slurred appoggiaturas with every single finger (1, 2, 3, 4), linking the slur to the open first string. In order to sound like an appoggiatura, the slur must be played really fast, like a small decoration on top of the main note, which is the open E. The slur must be clear. Don’t pull with too much strength, nor hit the fingerboard with your finger. That will make it sound dirty. Find the midpoint between releasing and pulling the string in order to reach a good sounding slur.

lessons.lesson_title: Parallel Thirds E Minor in Closed Position
lessons.lesson_content:
Parallel Thirds E Minor in Closed Position

We recommend you to keep your fingers prepared at all times when playing parallel thirds. Making sure that your knuckles are open wide and that the fingertips are just ready to drop on the strings, will help you successfully play parallel thirds. This will avoid lack of legato and eliminate the chance of producing noisy notes. When you have position changes, keep in mind to make the shifts quickly, otherwise you lose legato or it will sound to glissando technique. Remember that making quick shifts doesn’t mean the same as playing fast through the exercise. The beat and the duration of the notes should stay stable.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13531/13531 Parallel Thirds E Minor In Closed Position.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13531/13531 Parallel Thirds E Minor in Closed Position.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Dotted Parallel Thirds E Minor in Closed Position
lessons.lesson_content:
Dotted Parallel Thirds E Minor in Closed Position

When you add dotted rhythm to any passage you’re practicing, you increase the difficulty level of that passage. This is a common tool used to increase the comfort levels at the time of playing any passage with their original rhythm. In this case, we add dotted rhythm to a passage that would otherwise be written in 8th notes. With the new rhythm, you get less time to change between notes, and therefore you need to be extra careful with things such as finger preparation and fast position changes.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13532/13532 Dotted Parallel Thirds E Minor In Closed Position.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13532/13532 Dotted Parallel Thirds E Minor in Closed Position.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Parallel Thirds E Minor in Open Position
lessons.lesson_content:
Parallel Thirds E Minor in Open Position

You might find it hard to keep the notes connected throughout the whole exercise, due to the long period of playing of these wide intervals. The secret is to keep your fingers prepared at all times. Those knuckles cannot stay cramped together, but open wide and rounded. Keep an eye for the position change when you reach the first string. In order to keep the legato running, the position shifts must be done quickly, lightly ,and cleanly. The mental equation to help you with the various stages is: “…play - wait - change and play - wait”. This must happen within the correct rhythm and pulse.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13533/13533 Parallel Thirds E Minor In Open Position.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13533/13533 Parallel Thirds E Minor in Open Position.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Dotted Parallel Thirds E Minor in Open Position
lessons.lesson_content:
Dotted Parallel Thirds E Minor in Open Position

If your fingers are ready and well positioned at all times, you will play this exercise the most efficient way possible. The difference between this exercise and common exercise of parallel thirds is that here you practice them in dotted rhythm. This will give you more waiting time in the first note to think what’s going to happen next, but then, when you play the 16th note you are forced to think and act faster in order to successfully change to the next interval. Adding dotted rhythm to a passage helps you get better faster when playing the passage with the original rhythm.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13534/13534 Dotted Parallel Thirds E Minor In Open Position.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13534/13534 Dotted Parallel Thirds E Minor in Open Position.xml

course_title: Starting with Minor Pieces
course_content:
Highlights

  • Executing delicate ornamentations.
  • Playing staccato notes.

Description

Minor keys are introduced to players only after they are used to certain major keys. There are a few reasons for that; firstly minor is often associated with "less youthful" emotions, which asks for a certain amount of maturity from the player, and secondly the finger positioning mainly requires the 1st finger to have a backward step, to be placed right next to the upper bridge (the small bump at the top end of the finger board), which may not come as easy at the very beginning. This method provides the required tonality preparation for the players to get eased with the intonation control of a very delicate and romantic melody that is presented at the final step.

Requirement

  • Intermediate level of score reading skills
  • Mobility of left hand for diagonal shapes (rapid shifts or maintaining intervals between strings)
  • Proficiency in half, quarter, eight and dotted notes.
  • Relaxed right hand.
  • Swift string crossing abilities.

What's next

Next course: One, two, three, waltz, two, three!
course_short_description: This method provides the required tonality preparation for the players to get eased with the intonation control of a very delicate and romantic melody that is presented at the final step.

lessons.lesson_title: Introduction to ‘Starting With Minor Pieces’
lessons.lesson_content: Minor keys are introduced to players only after they are used to certain major keys. There are a few reasons for that; firstly minor is often associated with "less youthful" emotions, which asks for a certain amount of maturity from the player, and secondly the finger positioning mainly requires the 1st finger to have a backward step, to be placed right next to the upper bridge (the small bump at the top end of the finger board), which may not come as easy at the very beginning. This method provides the required tonality preparation for the players to get eased with the intonation control of a very delicate and romantic melody that is presented at the final step.

lessons.lesson_title: G Minor Natural Scale starting on G String – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

G minor in 1st position, just like B♭ major, includes a passage in which all 1st, 2nd and 3rd fingers are separated from each other. If this position is hard for the player, warming up the hand and stretching the fingers before holding the violin is recommended.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12186/3640 12186 G Minor Natural Scale Starting on G String.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12186/3640 G Minor Natural Scale starting on G String.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Bb Major Scale Starting on G String – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

B♭ major uses lowered 1st finger and this causes the hand to expand to a position in which all 1st, 2nd and 3rd fingers are separated from each other. If this position is hard for the player, warming up the hand and stretching the fingers before holding the violin is recommended.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12187/3639 12187 Bb Major Scale Starting On G String.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12187/3639 Bb Major Scale Starting on G String.xml

lessons.lesson_title: G Minor Harmonic Scale starting on G String – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Harmonic scales use the natural minor content with an addition of the leading tone that we find in the Major scale with the same name (the F♯ that exist in G Major in this case). The augmented interval between 1st and 2nd fingers may feel uncomfortable to the muscles at first and can sound with a little too much tension but it has a very specific flavor that is considered possibly too sharp by many Western Classical era composers which tend to go for melodic minor instead.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12185/3641 12185 G Minor Harmonic Scale Starting on G String.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12185/3641 G Minor Harmonic Scale starting on G String.xml

lessons.lesson_title: G Minor Melodic Scale starting on G String – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Playing a melodic scale, the player must be very careful about the 6th and 7th notes of the scale since they will be altering between directions. This scale is often used in classical music since it keeps the tonality minor and the harmonic tension within melody is distributed evenly.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12184/3642 12184 G Minor Melodic Scale Starting on G String.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12184/3642 G Minor Melodic Scale starting on G String.xml

lessons.lesson_title: G Minor Arpeggios and inversions starting on G String – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

For beginners arpeggios of minor scales are slightly harder than the major ones because the interval between fingers are larger. In this arpeggios the player should be aware that there will be a diagonal and larger gap between the 2nd and 3rd finger in the 1st inversion and 2nd and 1st finger in the 2nd inversion.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12171/3657 12171 G Minor Arpeggios And Inversions Starting On G String MEWTWO.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12171/3657 G Minor Arpeggios and inversions starting on G String.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Bb Major Arpeggio and Inversions – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Arpeggios are a good work out to play with various interval jumps. Throughout the inversions the player must be careful about the gap that occurs diagonally between the fingers. In B♭major arpeggios the 1st finger can always use the upper bridge as reference.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12172/3656 12172 Bb Major Arpeggio And Inversions MEWTWO.mp4

lessons.lesson_title: Bow Workout – String Crossing 3 – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teahcers

When changing strings relatively rapidly, the right elbow should find a middle ground to “hang” between the position of two individual strings and avoid doing large shifts. The right wrist and the front arm needs to prepare the shifts in advance as well. Players can realize in time that the right hand is actually drawing a figure 8.

lessons.lesson_title: Case Specific – Staccatos & String Crossing – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Playing the strings with a bow angled as close to the other string as possible can be very helpful here. Instead of dropping the right elbow on the A string and lifting it up on the D string, players should keep their elbows in a position where minimum movement is required. Start of each stacatto note can be marked with the index finger, which should be followed by a relaxation of the whole hand rather than staying stiff.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12145/3689 12145 Case Specific Stacattos And String Crossing MEWTWO.mp4

course_title: The Virtuoso Thumb for Classical Guitar – Part 1
course_content:
Highlights

  • Developing arpeggiated thumb technique.
  • Placing ornamentations without shaking the tempo of the piece.
  • Learning to stop the sound with the thumb.
  • Developing the figuetta technique.
  • Executing triplets with the thumb.
  • Drone playing with thumb.

Description

With this method you can greatly improve the dexterity of your right hand’s thumb. It is a finger that is often neglected during practice, as the study focus tends to direct to i, m, a, or to the left hand fingers. The repertoire of the Classical era of the guitar is filled with beautiful bass lines, and there are plenty of passages which are filled with challenging virtuosity. Thus this method will guide you progressively through some of the best examples out there, so that your thumb becomes as accurate as any other of your fingers, which will ultimately give you a well balanced control over the different voices of the music you play. The method consists of an etude selection from Le Papillon, Op. 50 by Mauro Giuliani, and 8 Short Pieces, Op. 24, by Fernando Sor. There is a continuous rise in the difficulty level throughout the method, so it is recommended that you feel comfortable playing the etudes from the first steps before engaging on a harder piece of a later step. You can listen to the whole set of pieces and understand that they do share similar classical vocabulary, therefore knowing one piece WILL make it easier to learn the next one.

Requirement

  • Intermediate level of score reading ability.
  • Familiarity with melodic arpeggios.
  • Advanced level in melody playing in first position.
  • Fluency in playing chords.
  • Ability to play pieces in C, G, D, A and E Major.
  • Fluency in playing Alberti bass.

What's next

Next course: The Virtuoso Thumb for Classical Guitar - Part 2

course_short_description: With this course you can greatly improve the dexterity of your right hand’s thumb. It is a finger that is often neglected during practice, as the study focus tends to direct to i, m, a, or to the left hand fingers.

lessons.lesson_title: Introduction to ‘The Virtuoso Thumb for Classical Guitar – Part 1’
lessons.lesson_content:
With this method you can greatly improve the dexterity of your right hand’s thumb. It is a finger that is often neglected during practice, as the study focus tends to direct to i, m, a, or to the left hand fingers. The repertoire of the Classical era of the guitar is filled with beautiful bass lines, and there are plenty of passages which are filled with challenging virtuosity. Thus this method will guide you progressively through some of the best examples out there, so that your thumb becomes as accurate as any other of your fingers, which will ultimately give you a well balanced control over the different voices of the music you play.

The method consists of an etude selection from Le Papillon, Op. 50 by Mauro Giuliani, and 8 Short Pieces, Op. 24, by Fernando Sor.

There is a continuous rise in the difficulty level throughout the method, so it is recommended that you feel comfortable playing the etudes from the first steps before engaging on a harder piece of a later step. You can listen to the whole set of pieces and understand that they do share similar classical vocabulary, therefore knowing one piece WILL make it easier to learn the next one.

lessons.lesson_title: Le Papillon, Op. 50 – No. 4
lessons.lesson_content:
by Mauro Giuliani

In this etude you will play the arpeggiated accompaniment always with your thumb. It will help you improve the thumb’s sense of location through the bass strings. It is an excellent etude to warm up your thumb muscles, for the direction of the accompaniment leads the thumb to make wide and round movements.

lessons.lesson_title: Le Papillon, Op. 50 – No. 8
lessons.lesson_content:
by Mauro Giuliani

Here you will also play with your thumb through an arpeggiated accompaniment. In itself, it still consists as a warm up for the finger and it will improve the agility of swapping between strings. The greater challenge of this etude is to maintain the extensions of the chords for the left hand, and manage to play the melody without getting mixed in the remaining right hand fingers.

lessons.lesson_title: Le Papillon, Op. 50 – No. 28, Andantino
lessons.lesson_content:
by Mauro Giuliani

This time you will be changing between playing an arpeggiated accompaniment, with your thumb, and simultaneously playing two notes with p-i fingering (thumb and index finger). Make sure your bass line does not cover the importance of the main melody, and try to play the p-i notes exactly at the same time.

lessons.lesson_title: Le Papillon, Op. 50 – No. 9
lessons.lesson_content:
by Mauro Giuliani

You can divide this etude into two sections. In the first part, the bass line (which you will be playing with your thumb!) has a responsive and rhythmic presence in the piece, so make sure to add that character to it. On the second part, the bassline receives the main role, as the melody is transferred to the bass in the more virtuosic passage. Remember that the arpeggio needs to sound clear while you sing the melody with your thumb.

course_title: The Virtuoso Thumb for Classical Guitar – Part 2
course_content:
Highlights

  • Perfecting Alberti bass technique.
  • Perfecting fast note repetitions with thumb.
  • Perfecting figuetta technique.
  • Playing continuous melodic bass lines (melismatic) with the thumb.
  • Developing the octave technique.

Description

With this course you can greatly improve the dexterity of your right hand’s thumb. It is a finger that is often neglected during practice, as the study focus tends to direct to i, m, a, or to the left hand fingers. The repertoire of the Classical era of the guitar is filled with beautiful bass lines, and there are plenty of passages which are filled with challenging virtuosity. Thus this method will guide you progressively through some of the best examples out there, so that your thumb becomes as accurate as any other of your fingers, which will ultimately give you a well balanced control over the different voices of the music you play. The method consists of an etude selection from Le Papillon, Op. 50 by Mauro Giuliani, 25 Etudes Melodiques, Op. 60, by Matteo Carcassi, and 12 Etudes, Op. 6 by Fernando Sor. There is a continuous rise in the difficulty level throughout the method, so it is recommended that you feel comfortable playing the etudes from the first steps before engaging on a harder piece of a later step. You can listen to the whole set of pieces and understand that they do share similar classical vocabulary, therefore knowing one piece WILL make it easier to learn the next one.

Requirement

  • Intermediate level of score reading ability.
  • Familiarity with melodic arpeggios.
  • Advanced level in melody playing in first position.
  • Fluency in playing chords.
  • Ability to play pieces in C, G, D, A and E Major.
  • Fluency in playing Alberti bass.
  • Fluency in performing parallel voicings (up to 3 voices).

course_title: V101.1 – INTRODUCTION TO VIOLIN
course_content:
Highlights

  • Discovering the parts of the violin & the bow.
  • Learning about strings, mutes, shoulder rests, and rosin.
  • Tips on how to maintain strings and bow hair.

Description

This method was specially designed for those who have a violin (of any kind), but have no experience whatsoever with the instrument. You will learn the names of the various parts of the violin and the bow which is essential for the future lessons as these parts will be mentioned during your training a lot in order to describe correct posture and correct playing tips; you will also learn about tools and aids surrounding a violin such as mutes, rosins, shoulder rests and more; and how to take care of your instrument.

Requirement

  • Having a Violin.

What's next

Next course: V101.2 - Position: How to Hold the Violin
course_short_description: This method was specially designed for those who have a violin (of any kind), but have no experience whatsoever with the instrument. You will learn the names of the various parts of the violin, the bow and other tools related to violin which are essential for the future lessons as these parts will be mentioned during your training; you will also learn about how to take care of your instrument.

lessons.lesson_title: V101.1.1 – Introduction to Violin – Parts of the Violin
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

In this video you will learn the names of the parts of the instrument which are mainly the sound box, sound holes (f or s holes), neck, fingerboard, scroll, tuning pegs, fine tuners, bridge, upper bridge, tail piece and chinrest. Getting to know the names of these parts is essential for the following lessons since they will be referred to very often.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13597/01 - Violin 101 - Introduction to violin - parts of the violin.mp4

lessons.lesson_title: V101.1.2 – Strings and Mutes
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

In this video you will briefly learn about strings and how to track down the brand of the strings that came with your instrument if you want to buy the same brand again. Also types of mutes and when and how to use them will be introduced. Important: Having a practice mute doesn’t mean that you should use it every time you practice!

lessons.lesson_title: V101.1.3 – Introduction to Violin – Parts of the Bow
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

In this video you will be introduced to the names of various parts of the bow and although there aren’t many parts to the bow itself, there are many names for the same part of the bow; Frog, Frock, Heel, Nut, Talon, Tallone (We will go with Frog). Another essential part of the learning process since the direction of the bow stroke and the location of the bowing area will be often referred to in the following lessons.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13599/03 - Violin 101 - Introduction to violin - parts of the bow.mp4

lessons.lesson_title: V101.1.4 – Shoulder Rest
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

A very important part of the violin learning process is to obtain a healthy posture. Current style of violin playing majorly requires a shoulder rest for the maximum comfort of the player. Here you will be introduced to how to put the shoulder rest on your violin, how to explore your own preferences and what adjustments to your shoulder rest can make your violin playing experience even more enjoyable.

lessons.lesson_title: V101.1.5 – String and Bow Hair Maintenance
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Common rules that we all know imply that both hair and strings need to be changed every 6 months, but that doesn’t have to apply to everyone! In this video you will learn about when to start thinking about a rehairing or a string change.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13601/05 - Violin 101 - String and bow hair maintenance.mp4

lessons.lesson_title: V101.1.6 – Rosin – (The Shiny Thing That Comes In The Tiny Box)
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

If you have a brand new violin and a bow, most likely you will have to rosin your bow a lot! Rosin on the bow hair creates friction between the bow hair and the strings, and that vibration leads to a clear (and loud!) sound. In this video you will learn about how to put your rosin and get introduced to the types of rosin.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13602/06 - Violin 101 - Rosin - the shiny thing that comes in the tiny box.mp4

course_title: V101.2 -POSITION: HOW TO HOLD THE VIOLIN
course_content:
Highlights

  • How to hold the violin.
  • Placing the left hand on the violin.
  • Relaxation and lower back awareness.

Description

It’s essential that you get to learn the healthy posture and movement types before you engage in making some music! Not everyone has the same physical futures; may it be long arms, short necks, wide palms; but even so, there are a few pointers that all body types can benefit from which orbit around a healthy and relaxed back and a healthy rib cage position when it comes to how to hold the instrument.

Requirement

  • Having a violin.

What's next

Next course: V101.3 - Left Hand and Arm
course_short_description: It’s essential that you get to learn the healthy posture and movement types before you engage in making some music! Not everyone has the same futures; may it be long arms, short necks, wide palms; but even so, there are a few pointers that all body types can benefit from which orbit around a relaxed back and a neutral rib cage position.

lessons.lesson_title: V101.2.1 – How to Hold the Violin
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

From this video on, you will be introduced to the essentials of a healthy posture while playing the violin. This starts with a relaxed back and neck. When we hold the violin, we actually tuck it in between our shoulder and clavicle and our neck without making any extra pressure from either side which will be shown in detail. Comfort of this position can improve with correct angled/adjusted shoulder rests and chin rests; or for the time being with a piece of cloth or two!
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13603/07 - Violin 101 - How to hold the violin.mp4

lessons.lesson_title: V101.2.2 – Left Hand While Holding the Violin
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Here you will focus on where to place the thumb and the index finger on the neck of the violin, and what the wrong positioning can cause. The joint between index finger and palm can help the grip while the thumb needs to be on the side of the neck, slightly carrying the weight of the instrument from below. This position creates a small gap between the neck of the violin and the connection between your thumb and index finger which will be needed for mobility of all the fingers while playing the instrument.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13604/08 - Violin 101 - Left hand while holding the violin.mp4

lessons.lesson_title: V101.2.3 – Relaxation and Lower Back Awareness While Holding the Violin
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Good and healthy posture starts way before holding the violin. In this video, you will learn to keep a good sitting or standing position while holding the instrument. Most of us have seen charichaturistic images or videos of many violin players with extremely tight and erect postures, and again most of us have a tendency to keep a kyphotic (stiff back, neck falls front) or hyperlordotic (stiff back, lower back sticks out) posture. With suggestions in this video you can gain awareness and avoid any of these postures and stay grounded, energetic and connected while playing your new instrument.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13605/09 - Violin 101 - Relaxation and Lower Back Awareness while holding the violin.mp4

lessons.lesson_title: V101.2.4 – Things to Pay Attention to While Holding the Violin
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

In this video you will learn a few things to keep in mind for when you hold the violin. These include not tightening your shoulders, not placing the violin’s pin too deep into your neck, not raising the violin above the parallel line to the ground, and allowing yourself room to move with your instrument, since playing the violin equals plenty of body movement.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13606/10 - Violin 101 - Things to pay attention to while holding the violin.mp4

lessons.lesson_title: V101.2.5 – Basic Exercise for Violin Holding
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

What you will be doing for the most part of your playing the violin will start with holding the instrument. Each time you stop to check something on your score, or to grab your water, or to pause a little, you will be exercising how to grab the instrument back again, where you might not be so careful since your aim would be to play right away. :) So why not focusing on how to hold our instrument before anything else?
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13607/11 - Violin 101 - Basic execrise for violin holding.mp4

course_title: V101.3 – POSITION: LEFT HAND AND ARM
course_content:
Highlights

  • Practice holding the violin.
  • Discover finger hammering.
  • Gain awareness of your left elbow.

Description

Obtaining a healthy position from the start has multiple advantages; by learning it from the start we allow our future experiences to go smoother and most importantly, we don’t get to feel tired quickly! Because sharing the muscular work needed to play the violin around various areas of your arms and your body in general, you get to practice and play for longer times without having specific locations feeling more tired than others. Besides transmitting physical effort from one muscle group to many; we also learn how to use speed instead of strength at times, especially with our left hand fingers.

Requirement

  • Having a violin.

What's next

Next course: V101.4 - Position: How to Hold the Bow
course_short_description: Obtaining a healthy position from the start has multiple advantages. Most importantly, we don’t get to feel tired quickly! Because by sharing the muscular work needed to play the violin around various areas you get to practice and play for longer times without having specific locations feeling more tired than others. In these lessons we also learn how to use speed instead of strength at times with our left hand fingers.

lessons.lesson_title: V101.3.1 – Basic Exercise for Thumb Positioning While Holding the Violin
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

A lot of learning can be done by eliminating surrounding challenges and focusing on one thing. In this exercise we will let go of the shoulder and neck awareness and simply focus on our thumbs motion. With the help of gravity, the pendulum movement of our hand will be transmitted to our thumbs, making it roll relaxedly over the violin’s neck, as it should be.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13608/12 - Violin 101 - Basic execrise for thumb positioning while holding the violin.mp4

lessons.lesson_title: V101.3.2 – Combining Violin Holding and Left Hand Positioning
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

In this video we will combine our violin holding position with a relaxed left shoulder which provides mobility to our hand; we will hold our instrument with the left hand as we learned before, and apply the thumb rolling movement while violin is in its place. This time without the help of gravity, the motion will require a little bit more arm power and we will work on flexibility of our hand. Easy as it looks; keeping your muscles relaxed and having smooth movements is the only challenge.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13609/13 - Violin 101 - Combining Violin Holding and Left Hand Positioning.mp4

lessons.lesson_title: V101.3.3 – Left Elbow Exercise (Teeny Tiny Forest Creature Sleeping) and On Knowing When to Pause
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Although the violin neck is so slim, we do have plenty of movement to cover when crossing from one string to the other. Oftentimes our focus is limited to the fingers and their point-of-contact with the strings. But in order to keep our wrists smooth and steady, we need to angle our elbows in a suitable position with our hands’ angle based on which string our fingers are going to land on. This video includes a very calming exercise for this awareness to develop without thinking much technical about it; simply imaging a cute and sleepy creature curling up on the inside of our elbows will help us swing our elbows gently, like a pendulum under control of the gravity, and relax our left wrist to its optimum while technically scanning through the range of all strings we have at hand.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13610/14 - Violin 101 - Left elbow exercise and on knowing when to pause_1.mp4

lessons.lesson_title: V101.3.4 – Left Hand Finger Hammering Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

We do have to shorten the string’s length in order to higher the pitch thus play a different note than the open string can give - that’s how stringed instruments work. But oftentimes we tend to place our fingers on the fingerboard with more pressure than needed. With this exercise you will be practicing using speed instead of localized pressure when placing your fingers on the fingerboard, which on the long run, requires less strength, hence tires you less!
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13611/15 - Violin 101 - left hand finger hammering exercise.mp4

lessons.lesson_title: V101.3.5 – Exercise for Hammering Fingers Systematically
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Fixing your hand to one position and doing the same workout helps you to develop your speed/strength collaboration and helps create a more stable technique. We don’t directly start with this exercise because the previous exercise naturally gives you a more relaxed approach to the hammering movement. Although your hand is fixed to one place at this point, try to keep the palm and wrist as relaxed as it was in the previous exercise.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13612/16 - Violin 101 - Exercise for hammering fingers systematically.mp4

lessons.lesson_title: V101.3.6 – Combining Everything: Holding the Violin and Placing the Fingers on All Strings
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

With these two exercises we prepare ourselves to play our first notes! First one combines hammering with the actual violin position; and the goal is to stay as relaxed as possible as the previous two exercises, this time while our left arm and thumb are doing their work by helping the chin and shoulder to hold the violin. In the next step we place our fingers over the fingerboard with two different positionings which help us align our left elbow to the optimum place while all strings are within reachable distance.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13613/17 - Violin 101 - combining everything- holding the violin and placing the fingers on all strings_1.mp4

course_title: V101.4 – POSITION: HOW TO HOLD THE BOW
course_content:
Highlights

  • Learn how to play with the bow.
  • Preparatory exercises for familiarity with the bow.
  • How to warm up and cool down.

Description

Hello, and welcome to the fourth course of the "Violin 101" method. In this course you are introduced to how to hold the bow.

Requirement

  • Having a violin.

What's next

Next course: V101.5 - Combined Exercise Executing Session
course_short_description: These videos are to be enjoyed repeatedly, even months or years after starting to play the violin; as what is mentioned in the lessons of this course are the key to having a clear sound. Left hand awareness and intonation control can be mastered one finger at a time, but having a healthy bow holding posture is a journey that starts as a whole and very naturally perfecting the position will take longer time than the videos can show.

lessons.lesson_title: V101.4.1 – Introduction to Bow
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Holding the bow well and relaxed is essential for a long lasting practice session. To be able to reach that quality, we will work on the bow positioning with the same principle we had before; eliminating other challenges from the scene for the time being and focusing on the bow only. Rounding up our fingers is the first step in this approach, because although the bow does have a very slim shape, the bow grip requires very rounded fingers.

lessons.lesson_title: V101.4.2 – Exercise for First Contact With the Bow
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

In order to have the most contact surface with the bow, we must make sure that all four of our fingers are touching the bow’s upper surface well. Reaching “up” for the bow can help you feel how natural this actually can be. This way we eliminate trying to hold the “tiny object” with the fingertips as some of us have a tendency to do so. This video also emphasizes the role of violin when it comes to carrying the bow’s weight.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13615/19 - Violin 101 - Exercise for first contact with the bow.mp4

lessons.lesson_title: V101.4.3 – How to Place the Fingers on the Bow – The Bunny
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

In this video you will learn a healthy bow grip in the most fun way; by shaping your fingers like a bunny. Funny as it sounds, the “bunny position” helps us learn the correct positioning of each finger in a very detailed way.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13616/20 - Violin 101 - How to Place the Fingers on the Bow - The Bunny.mp4

lessons.lesson_title: V101.4.4 – Tendencies We All Have – The Duck Position
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

This video is to make you feel “less lonely” in your potential wrong bow grips. It is also important to be aware of the “wrong positions” so that when you are on your own you can address what needs to be corrected.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13617/21 - Violin 101 - Tendencies We All Have - The Duck Position.mp4

lessons.lesson_title: V101.4.5 – Where to place the Fingers on the Bow in Detail
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

In this video we assure the correct positioning of the fingers on the bow in a more detailed approach. You will learn to avoid certain assumptions that might lead you to an uncomfortable bow grip in the long run. We will learn why we are holding the bow the way we do, how close our fingers must be and where to place them.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13618/22 - Violin 101 - Where to place the Fingers on the Bow in Detail .mp4

lessons.lesson_title: V101.4.6 – Details and Tool Suggestions For the Right Hand Pinky
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Using external aid tools to ease up the bow grip can lead to “learn-unlearn-relearn”, which is something we would like to avoid; and having an awareness of a healthy and relaxed position from the beginning can help us with that. But in some cases, the pinky on the bow might need a little bit of support if it needs time to develop strength. For this, a very common house tool can help us out.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13619/23 - Violin 101 - Details and Tool Suggestions For the Right Hand Pinky.mp4

lessons.lesson_title: V101.4.7 – Exercise for right hand – The Spider and The Caterpillar
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

With this exercise we get to be in contact with the bow without worrying about the correct position and we learn first-handedly that the weight of the bow changes from one point to the other while strengthening our fingers. Crawling up and down and side by side on the bow, the fingers also learn how to move freely; since a good bow grip is an elastic one depending on the directioning, speed and weight of the bowing.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13620/24 - Violin 101 - Exercise for right hand - The Spider and The Caterpillar.mp4

lessons.lesson_title: V101.4.8 – Exercise for Right Hand Finger Strengthening – 90 Degrees and the Pizza Slice
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

With this exercise we get to learn how to move our fingers as relaxed as possible in various angles while holding the bow with the bow grip we learned in the previous videos. Moving only our fingers and a little bit of our palm, we can change the bow angle in so many ways. Knowing this will help you gain the required elasticity while playing the violin with the bow, since all these angle changes will be executed on one single bowing.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13621/25 - Violin 101 - Exercise for Right Hand Finger Strengthening - 90 Degrees and the Pizza Slice.mp4

lessons.lesson_title: V101.4.10 – Exercises for Right Hand – 180 Degrees (Thumb Control) and on How to Transmit Power
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

This exercise helps you help yourself and gain awareness of the amount of point-of-contact you can establish with your bow. It also gives us a window to observe the positioning of our thumbs while holding the bow, and gives us the opportunity to fix our “tight” thumbs to the correct relaxed position.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13623/27 - Violin 101 - Exercises for Right Hand - 180 Degrees (Thumb Control) and on How to Transmit Power.mp4

course_title: V101.5 – COMBINED EXERCISE EXECUTING SESSION
course_content:
Highlights

  • Discovering the parts of the violin & the bow.
  • Learning about strings, mutes, shoulder rests, and rosin.
  • Tips on how to maintain a healthy violin.

Description

This method was specially designed for those who have a violin (of any kind), but have no experience whatsoever with the instrument. You will learn the names of the various parts of the violin and the bow which is essential for the future lessons as these parts will be mentioned during your training a lot in order to describe correct posture and correct playing tips; you will also learn about tools and aids surrounding a violin such as mutes, rosins, shoulder rests and more; and how to take care of your instrument.

Requirement

  • Having a Violin.

What's next

Next course: V101.2 - Position: How to Hold the Violin
course_short_description: In this chapter we revise what we have learned so far and execute all the exercises in a row, ending it with a informative video about how to warm up to a practice and how to cool down from it.

lessons.lesson_title: V101.5.1 – Combined Exercise Executing Session
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

In this video we run through all the exercises that we have seen so far related to the violin holding position and arm/elbow/finger usage. It is a good video to watch on occasion and repeat the movements to remember things that we might forget in the long run.

lessons.lesson_title: V101.5.2 – Combined Exercise Executing Session 2 – Bow
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

In this video we run through all the exercises that we have seen so far related to the bow grip and finger strength/elasticity. It is a good video to watch on occasion and repeat the movements to remember things that we might forget in the long run.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13624/Extra - Violin 101 - Combined Exercise Executing Session 2 - Bow.mp4

lessons.lesson_title: V101.5.3 – Warm Up and Cool Down Movements
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

This is a video to watch on occasion as well which includes some useful movements to execute before and after your practice sessions.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13626/Extra - Violin 101 - Warm Up and Cool Down Movements.mp4

course_title: Waltzing Arpeggio and Homophony
course_content:
Highlights

  • Focus on melodic arpeggios.
  • Practicing homophonic phrasing.
  • Ternary pulse workout.
  • Dotted rhythm elements.

Description

This step by step method will guide you through the practice of an etude by Fernando Sor. This etude is a beautiful combination of melodic arpeggios and homophonic phrasing, which will help you to develp exactly those specific playing skills, so typical for the classical guitar. Keep a stable count of the triple meter, and work on giving the waltz feeling to your interpretation. Be very precise when playing the dotted rhythm passages, and repeat slowing every 8th note passage so that you gain a relaxed flowing motion of those notes.

Requirement

  • Beginner-intermediate level of score reading ability.
  • Proficiency in keeping stable tempo on a ternary pulse.
  • Proficiency in switching between half, quarter, and eight notes.
  • Beginner level in melodic arpeggios.
  • Familiar with two voice leading.

What's next

Next course: Flow of one Single Melody Line

lessons.lesson_title: Case Specific – Dotted Rhythm – Guitar Exercises
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

This exercise is specially written to practice and understand dotted rhythm. Each bar follows a progressive path that helps you to decode the infamous rhythmic element. Your left hand will be placed pretty much all the time in the same place (on a G major chord position), and it is your fourth finger that will be doing most of the tricky bits. In order to connect the notes well, you need to pay attention to the coordination of your hands. The movements of your fingers have to happen almost at the same time.

lessons.lesson_title: Case Specific – Flow of Left hand fingers – Guitar Exercises
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Here we took an excerpt from the end of the piece itself and we made an individual exercise dedicated to practice this complex passage. Here you learn how you can practice challenging fast passages that might not feel natural in the first place. We break down the passage by adding repetition between the notes of the original excerpt, and then playing the unaltered passage isolated from the context of the piece.
